PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform honourable senators that His Excellency the Governor-General has today appointed the Hon. Ralph Willis as Treasurer, the Hon. Kim Beazley as Minister for Finance and the Hon. John Kerin as Minister for Transport and Communications.

PARA.TAB: I also inform the Senate that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, will be absent from the chamber this week. Senator Button is overseas on Government business. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Button in relation to his portfolio should be directed to Senator Cook. Any questions in relation to those portfolios he represents, namely, the Prime Minister's, the Treasurer's and Finance, should be directed to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence over all other business to a motion of censure of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We take this unusual course of action today because Australia is in crisis. It is an unnecessary crisis; a crisis in which nearly a million Australians are now unemployed, where another half a million comprise those who are either underemployed or alternatively—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not resist the procedural motion. We will take the censure motion if Senator Hill wants to move it immediately; but, of course, that is at the expense of Question Time.
—I take that as an invitation to proceed with the substantive motion, which I will do. The issue of Question Time can wait until later consideration.
—You don't need to speak to it.

—That is right, but the issue of Question Time will be determined in due course; that is a decision for the chamber, not for Senator Evans. Those opposite have a view that questions are a privilege; we have a view that questions are a right—this is our opportunity.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:
That a motion to censure the Government be moved forthwith and have precedence over all other business till determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate censures the Government for:
(a)the misery and heartache caused to hundreds of thousands of Australians as a result of its economic incompetence; and
(b) its failure to offer Australians any alternative to the Coalition's `Fightback' program as it desperately and selfishly clings to power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell the truth? Call it a consumption tax.

—We will tell the truth, which is more than we are getting from the Government side. This last weekend, rather than attempt to debate the coalition's Fightback program on its merits, Mr Hawke stooped to the lowest level imaginable by seeking to attack it as un-Australian. In doing so, in exhibiting that level of desperation, he forfeited the last shreds of legitimacy that he might have to the highest office in government.

PARA.TAB: It was an action lower than his lies to the Australian people over his secret deal with Paul Keating, which he of course welshed upon when it came to the crunch. It was even lower than when he cut John Kerin's throat last Friday in an enfeebled attempt to answer the charge of old jellyback which is so often deliberately put to him by his own colleagues. In attacking the Opposition with no substantial economic argument, offering no alternative but rather labelling us and the millions of Australians we represent as un-Australian, he sought to invoke the deepest fears in ordinary Australians, and sank to the lowest level of shame in doing so.

He does not want an economic debate. He does not want a political debate. He is now a man who has lost touch with reality—a man who has told himself so often that he has a special relationship with the Australian people that he now believes it, a man whom his mates call `little Caesar' and who now sees himself as an emperor, and a man who sees a threat to his leadership as a threat to Australians. That is the trouble with Hawke. He now personifies himself so much with the future of this country that he sees a threat to his leadership as a threat to Australia.

This man, who has built his appeal about personifying so much of what is good about Australia—the outdoor spirit, a certain sense of larrikinism, a happy-go-lucky atmosphere —and out of it claiming that the Australian people have vested in him a certain trust, has betrayed that trust. He has led the Australian people down a path of hopelessness and despair and yet he does not understand that. He has led Australia, potentially one of the richest countries in the world, into the worst recession in 60 years—with, as I said a minute ago, a million unemployed. Government members can grin about it if they like, but there are a million unemployed and another half a million underemployed who have given up. Thirty per cent of young people in Australia are unable to find a job. Australia is a country with a now frightening level of foreign debt. There is so much misery and heartache and all Government members can do is laugh about it. Senator Collins is laughing about it now.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are laughing at you, you great dolt.
—All he can offer in answer—
—On a point of order—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators —What is the point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I say to those honourable senators on my left that I will decide when somebody sits down. I call Senator Cook.

—My point of order is that there was an assertion that all the Government can do is laugh at the proposition of unemployment. This is a highly theatrical performance by the Opposition. The Government, of course, brought down a job statement just some weeks ago. That is a very positive agenda for change and improvement that at least ought to be acknowledged by the Opposition. The fact that it has not indicates that the Opposition is not interested in putting forward the true case in these circumstances.
—Order! There is no point of order, but I had great difficulty in hearing Senator Cook.

—All Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, can offer in answer to the comprehensive policy program we have put down—a program designed to restore hope and opportunity—is to accuse us of being un-Australian. For years under Hawke, Australians have heard about the need to share the burden, the need to share the bad times and accept the falling standard of living because the good times are just ahead. He has done his deals with vested interests such as the ACTU and done deals with his rich mates—three men in a boat and all that—whilst he has said to ordinary Australians, `I am really one of you'.

PARA.TAB: By saying he is an Australian, does Mr Hawke mean sharing the pain and misery that he has inflicted upon Australians; sharing the disappointment and shattered dreams—shattered dreams from record bankruptcies—that he would not understand because he has never been out there? He has never known what it is like to write a cheque to pay somebody's wages. Does Mr Hawke know what that is like? Is that what he says should be the dreams of ordinary Australians? Is that what he really offers Australia? True it might be that Paul Keating was the principal architect of this disaster, but Mr Hawke was his leader. How often over the years did we hear, `Hawke and Keating are a team. Hawke and Keating are a special team.'?

It is not often that I agree with Mrs Kirner, the Premier of Victoria, but when she stuck up for Mr Kerin on Friday she was right. How could Mr Kerin be expected to communicate a message when there was no policy? Why should he be labelled a failure for telling the truth? He had the nerve to say that Australia was in its worst recession for 60 years and was condemned by his colleagues for saying so—condemned by his colleagues for being honest. Unfortunately, honesty has suffered. Honesty is a victim of the paranoia of this Government to remain in power. Why should Mr Kerin be blamed for an economic catastrophe which is primarily the result of Keating and Hawke, set in train months, if not years, ago? Mr Kerin was to be the scapegoat. He was sacrificed so that the Government could gain breathing space, yet Mr Hawke muffed it again. When Senators Ray and Richardson went to see Mr Hawke last week, they told him—

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you know?

—How do I know? I will tell Senator Ray how I know. They told him that what the Government needed was new life and new people at the top, not just a reshuffling at the top. How do we know? We know because we read it in the Sydney Morning Herald. Senator Richardson doubted whether the Prime Minister had the courage to do it, so he gave the paper the story. What happened when it came to the crunch? Even with this public prompt, the Prime Minister was not prepared to do it.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, the advice he was given was to get rid of Gerry Hand, who was just marking time, whose factional leader, Mr Howe, stooped to one of the lowest levels of degradation in the Parliament last week—and let us see any Government member support that; and get rid of Senator Button, who has been humiliated so often. I remind the Senate that Mr Keating described Senator Button as a `do nothing Minister'; Mr Hawke ripped the industry statement off him in March, to his embarrassment; the IAC was taken away from him; and now even Austrade has been taken away from him and given to Senator Evans, of all people.

In the end, even with the public prompt, Old Jellyback could not do it because he feared that it would hasten the inevitable second challenge. The key element again was Mr Hawke's personal survival and his determination to hang on to power no matter what the cost. That was the determining factor yet again. The irony is that his failure again to take the hard decision has probably brought closer his demise.

Mr Hawke praised Mr Kerin on Friday. He said he was a big man who was prepared to put the interests of the Government ahead of any individual. On the same test, Mr Hawke is a small man, because if he was prepared to put the interests of the Government against any individual he would resign. Mr Kerin can stand proud alongside Mr Hawke. The one reason Mr Hawke finds it so difficult to address the Opposition's Fightback program in rational terms is that he supports the core of the package, the GST. In 1985 he said not only that a GST was essential but also that it should have the broadest possible base—including the taxing of food—and that only he and his Government would have the courage to implement it. Courage? Not Old Jellyback. When faced with opposition from the ACTU and from a few interest groups, he buckled again and his courage wilted.

Almost all the industrialised world now has a tax upon consumption. It recognises the need to tax consumption. From a position of economic failure—a voice from the past in the back ranks over there—Mr Hawke must now argue why we are better off not going down the path he knew was right. It is not an easy task, but it is no justification for him attacking our patriotism or that of the millions of Australians who support us.

It is the Opposition's desire to give Australians a new opportunity, a new basis for optimism and hope for the future. That is what has led us to put this policy package before the Australian people. We want it debated comprehensively on rational grounds. This package provides a program that takes responsibility from government and gives it back to individuals. It is a program that is designed to provide two million new jobs before the turn of the century. Is it un-Australian to provide jobs for two million unemployed Australians? It is a program that reorders tax with at least some of the burden being switched from production to consumption in order to increase incentive. Is that un-Australian? It is a program designed and independently assessed to give proportionately greatest benefit to the lower and middle income groups. Is it un-Australian to target those particular groups which have suffered so much under Mr Hawke? It is a program that is designed to encourage savings as opposed to expenditure to build the capital base of this nation and give individuals some chance to plan for their future. Is that being un-Australian? It is a program which is unashamedly pro-family, and I refer to those who will have their family allowances doubled as just one example.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about the 15 per cent on food?

—Senator Burns objects to that, does he? It is a program which encourages change through incentive and encouragement rather than directed outcomes, which is the way of this Government. It is a program which provides an enormous boost to business to enable it to grow, employ and produce the wealth that is essential for government to meet its responsibility to the poor, to the infirm and to the sick. It is a program which is designed to give world-class education to this country. Is that being un-Australian? It is a program designed to get people out of the public hospital queues and into private hospital beds. It is a program which will end the employment-sapping taxes of Labor, such as payroll tax. It is a program to end the insidious effect on individuals of bracket creep and automatic indexation of excise duties with which Hawke has ripped billions of dollars off ordinary Australians. Is this the policy package that Mr Hawke calls un-Australian?

PARA.TAB: Mr Hawke deserves to be condemned for seeking to pump up fear as a base of opposition to this package. This motion will test the Australian Democrats as well. Will they weasel out again? Will they take the money and run as they did last week? Is there an ounce of the legacy of the principle of Chipp still left in the Democrats? If they stand for anything, they will support this censure motion today.

Mr Hawke has often said that he has enormous faith in the good sense of ordinary Australians. He should apologise to Australians for the insult he does them in seeking to debase this debate in terms of what is more or less patriotic, then apologise for all the misery and suffering he has caused, and then resign and put his record against our Fightback program to the test. He should put it before the ordinary commonsense of the Australian people. But he will not because he lacks the courage. I commend this motion to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard more noise from Senator Hill today in the last 15 minutes than we have heard from him in the last two years. I can understand his preoccupation with leadership because there is one bit of leadership that is on the line, and it is in this place right now—that is, the leadership of Senator Hill. What we heard today was panicky noise and ersatz noise.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I expected this debate to be robust, but I think there are too many interjections from both sides.

—Mr President, I will let you into a little secret as to what one of Senator Hill's colleagues said to me the other day. One of Senator Hill's colleagues said to me that getting Senator Hill to demonstrate effective leadership in this place is like trying to push a wet noodle uphill. That is what those opposite have said about Senator Hill, and that is the sort of thing they are saying about the rest of their leadership—and that is the foundation of the motion before the Senate today.

PARA.TAB: The leadership that we have seen from the Opposition side has produced a policy package which is un-Australian. It is un-Australian because it is based on a series of myths about the problems with this country at the moment. It is based on a series of utterly inaccurate, unsubstantiated and unsustainable assertions about what this package will do for the economy; and it is based on a series of completely and utterly false assertions about what this package will do for ordinary Australians.

Let me demonstrate what is the matter with this particular policy package. The myths it is based upon are the myth that this country is a big government country; the myth that this country is a high tax country; the myth that this is a country which is excessively dependent upon income tax; the myth that this country has an external debt which is getting out of control; the myth that competitiveness is decreasing; and the myth that living standards are falling. The whole premise of this policy package is utterly falsifiable on every one of those counts.

It is utterly and completely falsifiable to the extent that, of the 16 OECD countries for which data exists, Australia has the second smallest government, Australia is the second lowest taxing country in the OECD and Australia is less reliant on income tax than just about any other country in the OECD. Our external debt is amply under control at the moment—well within that safety zone which the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, has himself indicated.

Australian competitiveness has increased by something like 17 per cent over the last few years. Australian living standards have not fallen, with real household disposable income rising by 24 per cent and by 10 per cent in per capita terms. That is the first set of things that are wrong; that is the first set of things that are un-Australian about this particular package.

More substantially and more immediately, of course, we have to deal with the claim that the gouge and screw tax strategy will do something for the Australian economy that is not being done by the Australian Government's present policy. Let me deal with what this particular tax package and the surrounding policy prescriptions will do for this country. As far as jobs are concerned, far from increasing the number of jobs, the Opposition Leader has conceded, acknowledged and accepted that employment will decrease—unemployment will increase—as a result of this package.

The claim is made that there will be about two million new jobs by the year 2000. When one examines that claim it becomes immediately apparent that, far from there being two million jobs that would not otherwise be created, the claim is being made only that there will be just over 300,000 jobs that would not otherwise be created. It is acknowledged in the Opposition's own policy package that, on the low case scenario, around 1.7 million would be jobs created anyway over the next decade.

We are a government that has created 168,000 jobs on average each year since we came to office. All those opposite are claiming in their own policy package is that they will do better than that, over the course of a decade, by 300,000 jobs. What a pathetic little claim that is. It has nothing to do with the claim of two million; it is just not substantiated even in the Opposition's documentation.

The Opposition claims that real wages will decrease. It spends time in the beginning of the package document deploring the way in which real wages have declined, but makes that a central element of its own policy package. It does it in a way which does not make any compensating provision, and provides nothing in the way of a safety net and nothing in the nature of a social wage to compensate for that deterioration in real wages.

The Opposition claims that it will increase productivity, yet its own policy package demonstrates that there will be a decrease in productivity over the course of the next decade with this package. On page 16 of its package, the Opposition identifies productivity gains over the last seven years as having been 0.9 per cent. On page 342 it states that over the next decade productivity gains will average 0.8 per cent under this package.

The Opposition talks about inflation. It has to acknowledge—and does acknowledge in its own policy document, at page 23 of the supplementary document—that, irrespective of the impact of this particular goods and services tax, there will be an inflationary increase running at the rate of 7.7 per cent in 1994-95. Add to that the 4.7 per cent that the Opposition has acknowledged is directly attributable to this package, and we are talking about inflation of over 12 per cent—12 per cent inflation according to the documents which the Opposition has put into the public domain. And it says that that is not un-Australian!

The Opposition has not talked about interest rates, but it should talk about interest rates because interest rates simply cannot be sustained at any kind of reasonable level in that sort of inflationary environment. The Opposition has talked about, as it has to talk about, the need to maintain firm monetary policy in this sort of environment. And it will have to be firm monetary policy if, with that inflation rate, it does not want to see the whole economy spiralling totally out of control. Syntec has estimated that that interest rate increase will be running at the rate of 13 to 16 per cent.

At the end of the day, what will this package do for Australia's external debt situation? This is the most fascinating part of this particular package. This is the most fascinating concession of all. What will the Opposition's package do about the fundamental structural flaw that is alleged to exist in the Australian economy? Australia's net external debt at the moment is 35 per cent of GDP. What will Australia's external debt be at the end of the century, in the year 2000, under the Opposition's particular package? Those opposite should look at page 342 of their own document and they will see that they acknowledge that it will increase to 54 per cent. The Opposition is talking about a debt of 35 per cent of GDP becoming a massive debt, a net external debt, of 54 per cent, on its own document.

If honourable senators opposite look at what will happen to jobs, if they look at what will happen to real wages, if they look at what will happen to productivity, if they look at what will happen to inflation, if they look at what will happen to interest rates, if they look at what will happen to debt—if they look at every one of those things—they will find themselves showing—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from my left.

—So what this tax package will do to the Australian economy on all those fronts—jobs, real wages, interest rates, inflation, productivity, external debt—is palpably and disgustingly un-Australian and it deserves every bit of criticism that it has had. And it is obviously un-Australian in the terms of the Opposition's own document.

PARA.TAB: But then the Opposition goes on to argue that the GST package will make individuals, ordinary Australians, better off. Let us test that particular part of this package. The GST itself, the gouge and screw tax, the consumption tax, will not make anyone better off. It will create an environment where on every product, whether it is haircuts, vegetables, school clothes or school buses, every Australian will be paying 15 per cent. Okay, the wholesale sales tax goes, but a 30 per cent tax on luxuries will be eliminated so a 15 per cent tax can be applied on necessities. That is what the Opposition is doing as far as the guts of the proposal is concerned.

The Opposition then claims that is all okay, that is all defensible, that is all legitimate, because there will be compensation with the income tax cuts and there will be compensation with the pensions, the family allowances and the rest of those increases. Let me say something about that compensation package. In the first place, in so far as the income tax cuts themselves are concerned, they will not be fair. They are regressive income taxes, and the benefit will be manifestly less for those at the lower end of the scale.

If a person has an income of under $20,000, what will he benefit so far as his income is concerned? He will benefit to the extent of 4.8 per cent. Under the Opposition's tax scales, that is the extent of the increase in his after tax income if he has an income of under $20,000. If a person has an income at the average weekly earnings level of around $30,000, he benefits to the extent of 6.8 per cent. But if a person has an income of $75,000, 2 1/2 times the average weekly earnings, he benefits to the extent of 14.7 per cent. That is the kind of regression that is involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: Senator Evans has been on his feet for 10 minutes addressing the censure motion and not once has he addressed himself to the matter at hand, which is the censure of this Government. He has only spoken about certain policy proposals of the Opposition, on which he is not doing well at all. He has brought scattered notes with him to which he is referring, but not once has he defended the Government; not once has he said what this Government is doing. Mr President, I ask you to ask Senator Evans to address the motion before this Senate.

—Order! There is no point of order. If Senator Teague had taken the trouble to read the Opposition's own censure motion, moved by Senator Hill, it specifically mentions the coalition's Fightback program and there cannot be a point of order.
—It censures the Government.

—Yes, for providing no alternative to the Opposition's package—and I will tell those opposite why. We do not need to adopt any of the coalition's package because our own policy strategy is much better designed to improve this country. What is the matter with this compensation package? For a start, as I have said, the income tax side of it is hopelessly inequitable and hopelessly regressive. The only way the arithmetic begins to add up on the compensation package is with the $10 billion worth of expenditure cuts. We will hear a little more about that from Ralph Willis this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: The point can be made that, firstly, it is unlikely the Opposition can meet the savings needed to cover the gap from the savings that have been identified and, secondly, to the extent that there are those savings, their impact on ordinary Australians is disgusting. That will become more and more apparent as the months go by. Moreover, there is a whole heap of hidden additional imposts in the coalition's package which will make its impact on ordinary Australians devastating: the road charges will mean an increase in registration of three times the present rate; the inflationary impact of the health package is just not built into the Opposition's package; the impact that all this will have on interest rates has not been built into any calculations; and the impact it will have on State government taxes and charges has been ignored. What we have here is a package which is un-Australian in every conceivable respect—in its negative impact on the economy and in its negative impact on ordinary Australians.

The Government's policy approach, by contrast, is one which we can be genuinely proud of. We have put in place policy settings which are designed to and will achieve sustainable employment growth and sustainable economic growth in this country. We have beaten inflation in a way that the Opposition, when in government, was never able to do. We have pulled interest rates back in a way that the Opposition, when in government, was never able to do—9.5 points in the past 18 months.

We have held wages growth in check through an accord that the Opposition has never been able to negotiate and will never be able to adhere to because it does not understand, as Nick Greiner said, that we have a system in Australia which is based on cooperation rather than confrontation; a system which he said in Tokyo a couple of weeks ago is an economic system and an economic record that all Australians can be proud of. Nick Greiner, the Liberals' own State Premier, undermined the basics of the Opposition's claims.

We have a package that is based on a responsible fiscal policy and a responsible monetary policy; a policy that is designed to achieve and is achieving reductions in the current account deficit and with that the stabilisation of the external debt, something the Opposition has acknowledged its policy package will allow to disappear into the stratosphere. We have accompanied that policy with a substantial and far-reaching program of micro-economic reform which is designed to produce the structural flexibility that this economy needs and which will deliver results. We have put in place a safety net of labour programs, massively expensive but massively sensible programs, which are designed to ensure that the skill base is there to take advantage of the recovery which is now under way.

This has been a debate about leadership—about political leadership and about economic leadership. We have not seen any from Senator Hill in this place, and today he did not break his duck. We have not seen any from Dr Hewson, whose sole contribution to the leadership of this country has been to gather around him a collection of morally emasculated choirboys to sing in unison, `Greed is good; greed is good'. That is all that those opposite have been able to contribute to the policy debate in this country. That is the sort of leadership that we have seen. It is insensible; it makes no attempt to come to grips with the real issues that are determining the future of this country.

This is a censure motion which was born of the Opposition's despair of its inability to have any impact on the policy processes and politics of this country; born of its despair of six years of revolving door lightweight leadership with a new brand of lightweight leadership in two Houses. It is the politics and a political package born of the Opposition's despair of its incompetence and its inability to alter the future course of this country for ordinary Australians, other than manifestly for the worse. It is not the Government that should be censured for this assault; it is the Opposition. Those opposite ought to hang their heads in shame for a failure of leadership, a failure of understanding and a failure to appreciate what the future of this country and its people is all about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The hypocrisy of the Government—of the Opposition—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not a freudian slip. As I have said before, both sides of this chamber deserve very heavy censure because they are driven by exactly the same economic rationalist, deregulatory policies and philosophy. The Opposition has shown incredible intolerance during this debate so far. When Senator Bolkus came over to speak to us, I was surprised to see even Senator Patterson, who is normally better behaved than Senator Kemp, catcalling when Senator Bolkus was asking about the health of Senator Kernot's mother. That is what Senator Bolkus was over here asking about; it had nothing to do with this debate at all.

PARA.TAB: If we are going to have any sensible debate about this Fightback package at all, the Opposition must move away from regarding its package as some sort of holy book which is beyond criticism. As soon as anybody raises a point of criticism, the Opposition takes points of order and argues that its document is sacrosanct and is totally beyond criticism.

There is also an element of hypocrisy in Senator Hill's raising this matter this afternoon. Quite clearly, the strategy of the Opposition is to disrupt the processes of this Parliament as much as it possibly can between now and the time at which this Parliament is due to rise. That is what it did the other day. It knows very well that it can be supported by its rich mates who can buy it as much advertising time as it needs. It does not like the idea that advertising time during elections should be determined in a democratically fair way. That is what the Opposition does not like. That is why it attempted a filibuster in the debate the other day and that is precisely why it is continuing with a filibuster this afternoon. This is the second time in a week that the Opposition has delayed Question Time. That is almost without precedent.

There is further hypocrisy in Senator Hill's defending Mr Kerin and saying that Mr Hawke and Mr Keating are responsible for the plight in which we find ourselves. I see Senator Hill nodding his head. I wonder whether Senator Hill remembers that his former shadow Treasurer, Mr Howard, said that the reason Mr Keating had had such an easy run was that most of the policies being implemented by the Government were precisely the policies that would be followed by the Opposition. Mr Howard is on record as making that comment.

Since 1983 the Government has been following a policy of deregulation, `leave it to the market', and so-called economic rationalism, which should really be called economic irrationalism. There is nothing rational about leaving the welfare and the future of Australian society to an unregulated market. It simply does not work; it cannot work; it has been shown theoretically not to work and it has been shown in practice not to work. The deregulation policies which the Opposition would simply extend in its Fightback package are the reason that we have over one million people unemployed, the reason that we have a large foreign debt, the reason that we have a shift of wealth from the poor to the wealthy and the reason that we have a shift of wealth into speculation rather than productive investment.

I could do no better than quote Professor Mathews, Emeritus Professor from the Australian National University, former Director of the Centre for Research on Federal Financial Relations and a former member of the Commonwealth Grants Commission. In a recent report in the Canberra Times he catalogued the failure of the Government. To that extent, I agree with the first part of the Opposition's motion. Professor Mathews said:

The economic policies of governments could not have been more successful if they had deliberately set out to impede economic progress, make it more difficult for businesses to operate profitably, encourage high levels of private consumption for most people while accepting homelessness and poverty for others, reduce the level and quality of public services, encourage imports and discourage exports, discriminate Australian investment whilst supporting foreign take-overs of Australian property, destroy the competitive edge of Australia's super-efficient farm and mining industries, prevent manufacturing industries from becoming more efficient, continue to degrade the natural environment, and tolerate massive levels of unemployment.
Yet these are the results that the free market policies have achieved.

When the horrible consequences of these failed policies are so apparent, not only to those who have had to suffer their consequences but to any intelligent observer it is necessary to ask why they continue to be tolerated?

SPEECH.PARA: He concludes by saying:

PARA.TAB: The final factor which has led to acceptance of the disastrous consequences of free-market policies is a political one, which has effectively stymied the democratic processes.
The political spectrum in Australia and the rest of the world has moved so far to the right that electors no longer have a choice over most aspects of economic policy.
In Australia, for example, both governments and oppositions enthusiastically support free-market policies.

Their only quarrels are about the interpretation of these policies and the extent to which they should be pushed, for example with respect to marginal interest rate changes, the limits of privatisation and the role of deregulation in the labour market.

SPEECH.PARA: That is mainly what the debate has been about until recent days when most of it has really been about leadership. There is nothing in the Opposition's Fightback! document—`Frightpack' or `Flightback' are some of the other terms that are more appropriate. Ross Gittins writing in the Sydney Morning Herald the other day pointed out that the policies are more appropriate to the 1950s and 1960s than they are to the 1990s or to the years which we face after the turn of the century—which will redress any of the problems which we currently face. It is simply a belief in the deregulated market with certain tax changes bringing about those desirable changes in society. The market simply cannot do that without reintroducing regulation.

PARA.TAB: To the extent that we look at the details of the package, our position is consistent in that we reject that deregulatory market driven approach. We argue very strongly that there should never be taxes on the necessities of life. We have pointed out the way in which, if the Opposition were to win government after the next election, we would move to ensure that those taxes on food, clothing and shelter were not put in place.

Moreover, to the extent that the Opposition nowhere addresses the environmental problems, ecologically sustainable development is apparently totally beyond its ken. Those opposite, like many economists, say that they will come out with environmental packages later on, indicating that they are not an essential part of their economic program. This has led them to fall into the trap of intending to reduce the price of petrol, thereby increasing the consumption of that fuel. At the same time, the Opposition's other programs undoubtedly will increase the cost of fares through the GST for people who use public transport. Undoubtedly, its cutback in government expenditure in other areas will lead to many disadvantaged people having to use private transport. This would of course increase air pollution in cities, which is a major problem in this country and adds very considerably to the problem of greenhouse gas emissions.

The Opposition is not the least concerned about the environment—it never has been and never will be. Basically, it is committed to the economic rationalist view that the relationships between people in our society should be predicated entirely on economic criteria. People are to be bought and sold, body and soul, within that package.

The processes which are being used this afternoon are disgusting. There are alternative opportunities available to the Opposition, through urgency motions and MPIs. The Democrats find totally objectionable the determined attempt by the Opposition to disrupt the Parliament rather than to debate the substantive issues and we totally dissociate ourselves from those processes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill, in his motion to censure the Government for the misery and the hardship caused to millions of Australians by the policies of this Government and for the failure to offer Australians any alternative to the vision and the hope that the coalition's Fightback proposals offer.

PARA.TAB: In the last few days we have witnessed the death throes of a dying government. Prime Minister Hawke is a political carcass, swinging in the breeze. We are now waiting for the heavyweights of the Australian Labor Party to cut him down—but, more likely, just to give him a little tap on the shoulder. Two or three of the biggest heavyweights are on the other side of this chamber. If they participate in the debate later on, perhaps they will tell us just when that tap will come.

We have a country in crisis because we have a government in crisis. We have a crisis-ridden government; we have a government that is so divided that it has paralysed its ability to make policy; we have a government that is only concerned with one job—the job of the Prime Minister. If anything is un-Australian, it is that. For any government to be concerned with its own internal fighting, feuding, bickering and division, with the bottom line being who is going to be the Prime Minister, is more un-Australian than anything that I can think of. That is what disgusts the 1 1/2 million unemployed and underemployed Australians and the millions of other Australians who have seen their living standards, their quality of life—particularly that of young Australians—derided and eroded progressively throughout the period of this Government, particularly in the last couple of years.

That is happening not by any accident or by any mischance; it is happening as a result of the deliberate creation by the Government—as a result of massive policy incompetence—of the worst recession in Australia in more than 60 years. In the last 12 months alone more than 300,000 jobs have been destroyed. During the life of this Government, our debt to the rest of the world has risen sixfold. We now rank about third in the world amongst the great debtors of history. We have seen all Australians, particularly lower and middle income earners, face a rising and crippling debt burden; our productivity growth has been destroyed; our savings and investment have collapsed; and the hopes and aspirations of the Australian people have been shattered. We have all that in the face of the most monstrous lies told by politicians in Australia's history. Let us have a look at some of them over the last couple of years. Let us see what this Government was saying to the Australian people before the 1990 election. The day before the election last year, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have in place a coherent, inter-related strategy to deal with the debt problem of Australia.
In his election policy speech on 8 March last year, the Prime Minister said:
My Friends, Fellow Australians. The message I bring to you today is a message of confidence in the future of Australia, and a renewed commitment to a better, fairer future for all Australians.
Just before that the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, said:
The principal promise in 1983 was to bring down unemployment, restore economic growth and to bring a deceleration in inflation, and we've done all three.
Done all three? What has he done with unemployment? He has raised unemployment to amongst the highest levels in our history. He has done it all in a period of 18 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will go higher.

—It will go higher, as my Leader, Senator Hill says. There is no way in the world that that unemployment figure is not going to go higher. For the fifth successive month, the job ads figures that were announced today fell—to a level 22 per cent below what they were a year ago. Those figures are one of the leading indicators of the future course of the Australian economy. Those job ad figures have today confirmed what we on this side of the chamber know—and what I think all Australians, other than the bunch opposite who claim to run the country, know—that this country is in such deep crisis that the prospect for jobs and future employment is not improving and has not bottomed; it is getting progressively worse.

PARA.TAB: `Restore economic growth', the former Treasurer said. What has he done? The Government has produced five successive quarters of negative growth, largely due to the policies which the heir apparent to the throne, Paul Keating, put in place. As a member of the Government, Paul Keating was the principal architect and implementer of those policies. There have been seven successive quarters of negative growth out of the last eight. We have seen a collapse in investment in eight quarters out of the last nine. What has that done to economic growth? That has put economic growth at its lowest level for 60 years—because it is not growth; it is negative. The economy is shrinking day by day.

I recognise that the Government has reduced the rate of inflation, but how has it achieved that? It has reduced the rate of inflation by bludgeoning the Australian economy into submission, by giving Australia 1 1/2 million unemployed and under-employed persons. When the economy starts to pick up—and it will at some stage—the old inflation surge will start again because none of the fundamentals that are necessary to sustain low inflation have been put in place.

I have mentioned some of the things that the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have said. The incident that grabs me more than any other was when the Treasurer, Mr Keating, had the gall to say on the AM program on 28 February 1990, just prior to the 1990 election:

SPEECH.PARA: We won't have a scorched-earth policy, we won't destroy business activity, we won't destroy employment, we will do all this gradually.

I do not know what he meant by doing it all gradually, but what he did was to scorch the earth of Australia in a way that has never been done deliberately by an Australian government in the history of our nation.

PARA.TAB: They were some of the things that were said before the 1990 election—absolutely monstrous lies. But the statement that, more than any other, will stick in the minds of all Australians was the one made before the 1987 election, when the Prime Minister said: `By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty'. That is the most cruel, monstrous lie that has ever been perpetrated on the Australian electorate. Last Friday, the Prime Minister shot the messenger, Mr Kerin; he did not have the guts to have a go at shooting the person who wrote the messages, namely, himself. The Prime Minister said that the overriding goal of the Hawke Government now is to destroy the coalition's Fightback package. How is that for a way of giving Australians a feeling of vision, leadership, initiative and encouragement?

I say to Senator Gareth Evans and the Government that Australians are desperately looking for leadership. They are looking for vision. They are looking for hope in a sea of despair that the Government has created. There is an alternative. We need not have a nation as recessed and despairing as that which we have today. We need not have a situation where one in three of our young people are out of work, with little prospect in the foreseeable future of getting a job, and with the prospect of the number of unemployed rising inexorably. There is nothing in the Australian economy to indicate that we have to have that situation.

There is an alternative for Australia and for Australians. There is hope for Australia. There is opportunity for Australia. That opportunity lies in leadership and in the promotion of visionary, positive policies. That is what the coalition's Fightback package is all about. It is about vision, hope and opportunity. It is about rewarding Australians. It is about rebuilding Australia. All the Government can do is whine and carp and attempt to pick away for holes that it hopes it might find in that package. I have news for the Government. I think that it is having a desperate problem with that package and it will continue to have a desperate problem because it has no answer to the vision that the package provides.

Let us look at some of the measures that the package puts forward to provide hope and vision. Outlined in the package are the largest personal income tax cuts in Australia's history, a 30 per cent reduction in income tax and a slashing of tax rates across the board. Ninety-five per cent of all taxpayers will face a marginal rate of tax of 30c or less. The targeting of income tax reductions has been geared and directed towards lower and middle income earners—those whose earnings are in the range of $20,000 to $50,000, those whom this Government has crippled through progressive income tax increases, in effective terms, over the last eight years.

We will give business a chance to grow and develop once again. We will abolish almost $20 billion of indirect taxes, which are one of the essential reasons for the uncompetitiveness of this country and which fall on the cost of business. We will introduce a goods and services tax. We will do what the Prime Minister, the former Treasurer and the great bulk of those opposite wanted to do in 1985: introduce a broadly based goods and services tax. Those opposite did not have the guts to introduce it.

The one reason why the Government did not do it is that it got to the tax summit and, on day one, Bill Kelty got up and said, `The union movement will not have a bar of the goods and services tax'. At the end of day one, the Prime Minister, without even consulting Treasurer Keating, pulled the rug out from under the whole deal. He announced in a press conference, `Bill Kelty says that we cannot have a goods and services tax, so it is off the agenda'. That is why we did not have a goods and services tax in Australia five or six years ago, and those opposite know that as well as I do. Those opposite know it as well as all Australians do.

Those opposite support a goods and services tax just as much as the coalition does. They support it because they know that it is an essential part of getting this country growing again, of getting this country more productive and more competitive. That is the only way that this country will get out of the crisis in which it is now. It is the only way in which we will be able to provide jobs, employment, growth, quality of life and improved living standards for our people.

I was amazed to hear Senator Evans as Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate perpetrate today the same monstrous lie that the Prime Minister continues to peddle, namely, that our reform package benefits only the rich and disadvantages the poor. It is a barefaced lie—the Prime Minister knows it and those opposite know it. The Prime Minister, and Senator Evans again today, take selective parts of the package, concentrate solely on tax reductions for different individuals and ignore completely the other benefits that flow from these proposals.

Most important of all, low and middle income earners will benefit from the increased job opportunities that will flow from the labour market and structural reforms, and from the removal of all anti-business taxes that those opposite have jacked up progressively throughout their period in office which have made business in this country uncompetitive. Those opposite completely ignore such matters. Let me raise them, and I hope they do not embarrass Government senators too much.

They completely ignore the doubling of the family allowance for families with combined incomes below $30,000, and the 50 per cent increase for families with incomes from $30,000 to $50,000.They ignore the $300 increase in the annual dependent spouse rebate for families with children. They ignore the tax concessions for health insurance, specifically directed to low income families. They ignore the $90m set aside for increased child-care support. They ignore the first home owner's scheme for families earning below $40,000. They ignore the very large increase in education funding, a large proportion of which will flow to low income non-government schools and to TAFE colleges.

They ignore the zero rating for GST purposes of health and education expenses, and that that zero rating will reduce the cost of those services. They ignore the exemption of rent from tax, which is there to help protect the poor and the low income earners. They ignore the fact that the aged will be offered very generous pension increases; part pensioners will get access to the GST tax credit arrangements; and, for the first time, there will be access to pharmaceutical benefits for non-pension retirees—a very major social equity decision.

Those opposite ignore the deferred pension plan. They ignore tax credits and re-insurance subsidies to encourage people to take up private health insurance and compensate for the impact of the GST on their financial wealth—something that this Government was never able or prepared to do. They ignore the $50m that the coalition has committed to increased funding of voluntary/non-government agencies to assist family crisis care—a very necessary and equitable commitment. They ignore all of those matters. They ignore sole parents' pensions and other pensions being increased by 8 per cent. These are some of the matters that the Australian people want to hear about.

What are the Government's policies? All Government members can do is carp, whine and fight amongst themselves. This is a question of leadership and vision for the future. Those opposite are absolutely bereft of either, and are seen to be bereft of either by the Australian people. As a government, they ought to resign or, at the very least, call the earliest possible election. We will take the fight to them the day they call an election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the early sanctimonious things said by Senator Hill was that we should have a constructive and rational debate. As soon as Senator Evans started speaking, and for the whole of his 15 minutes, the henchmen on the other side simply tried to drown him out. So much for a rational and logical debate on these issues that Senator Hill wants to raise.

PARA.TAB: The performance of the Opposition reminds me of British politics. What I once said of a British leader would apply to Senator Hill: he performed like a rag doll pumped full of benzedrine, because he read his speech with great passion today. On Senator Short's speech, I am reminded of another description from British politics: it was like being savaged by a dead sheep. It was a very thin performance. Senator Hill feels so strongly on these issues that he had to come in and read his impassioned speech. That shows how loathe he was to try to cover the subject matter.

One would have thought that Australia was the only country in a recession, and that the Labor Government in Australia was the only government trying to grapple with these difficulties. The fact is that many countries are going through recessionary periods.
Senator Herron interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have great differences in ideological approach. Great Britain, under a Conservative government, is probably in a far worse recessionary situation than us—especially in regard to interest rates, inflation rates and unemployment. Those opposite—up until the last two years—would get down on their kneeling mats and point in that direction every time six o'clock in the morning came around to worship Thatcherism. It is no longer very popular to worship Thatcherism. In France, under a socialist government led by Mitterand and Mrs Cresson, the figure of three million unemployed was reached in the last month. So it has had difficulty in tackling these recessionary problems.

PARA.TAB: Also, we will shortly have a visit by President Bush to this country, and he will no doubt discuss with us the economic circumstances in the United States—which, again, are recessionary. Again, it is repeated in New Zealand. I mention New Zealand because it has been through a consumption tax. All the sorts of things the Opposition is saying and all the predictions it is making about a consumption tax have been tried in New Zealand, yet New Zealand has high unemployment, relatively high interest rates, a low investment rate, et cetera. We will not get a tax led recovery; we will only ever get an investment led recovery. That is the only way out of this recession.

Senator Hill went on to passionately attack the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke). We know how much it hurts members of the Opposition that he beat them in 1983, 1984 and 1987, and again in 1990. I was on the other side of that equation with Malcolm Fraser, and it hurt me too. I understand the invective that they want to use.

We had Senator Hill say, `Describe the circumstances in which Mr Hawke had Mr Kerin replaced'. Senator Lewis laughed; he thought it was funny. It was only 20 months ago that in the middle of an election campaign his Leader had to sack him—right in the middle of an election campaign! Why? Because he had been loose-lipped and had attacked the leadership, not realising someone had a tape-recorder on him.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon starts interjecting. He used to be on the front bench—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister should be addressing his comments through you, Mr President, not to the chamber. I ask you to ask him to do that.

—Let me repeat the point for your benefit, Mr President, because I really should address my remarks through you. I was explaining that when people come in here and have the gall to interject on leadership and replacement questions, they should look to their own careers. I just pointed out, because Senator Lewis was giggling through Senator Hill's contribution, that he himself, unfortunately—and I felt sorry for him—suffered the indignity of being replaced.I went on to point out to you, Mr President, that the person seated in front of him started interjecting, and he has been replaced on the front bench. Indeed, when one looks around there are quite a few. Senator Archer used to be a frontbencher—he is no longer there; Senator Vanstone used to be on the front bench—she is no longer there. These decisions are made from time to time, for a variety of reasons. Senator Bishop, trying to slide back into her seat, used to be on the front bench.

PARA.TAB: Old Smiley over there has been put on the front bench but has not been given a portfolio; that is how much the Opposition believes in the ability of its front bench—it puts someone there but cannot trust that person. I am sorry to tell Senator Boswell that the Opposition will tolerate him there until the day it wins, and then it will be straight back to the back bench without any question.

Those opposite are the great gonnas: they produced a package that they said is gonna do this, that and the other. It is important to look at the track record of the great gonnas on the other side. Of course, they have collective amnesia about the Fraser years: 1982-83 did not exist.

At the moment we have high unemployment, but we do not have double digit inflation or double digit interest rates, which were characteristic of that time. Those opposite have expunged that from their memory; Malcolm Fraser no longer exists. Those that have served under him have denied him thrice; they have pushed him to the outer recesses of their minds.

When those opposite had the opportunity to do things, how many tariffs did they reduce—ever? How much micro-economic reform did they undertake? None. Every time the airline pilots put up their hands for a pay rise, what did those opposite do? They handed it straight to them. What happened when the BLF held everyone up at every building site? Those opposite laid over; they did nothing.

This Government has been willing to face up to the tough decisions, and do what was necessary. The gonnas over there—the people that are always gonna do something—do nothing. All they can do is shout from the back bench, forget their history and produce a package that will not work.

Let us look at the package that those opposite have today put on the table for debate. It will be seriously inflationary, as Syntec and others have pointed out. The real question is: how quickly will those inflationary pressures be washed out of the system?

The fact is that those opposite have no wages policy; they have no method of washing that inflation out of the system. Automatically, with the inflation rate predicted by Syntec, home mortgage rates will go up 4 per cent and disposable income will go down the drain. Those opposite should not talk about their compensatory package; that is meant for other things. In the short term, disposable income will be destroyed by this.

The only reason I would not like to be here now is to see the new Treasurer (Mr Willis) detail the savings package that those opposite have produced, because it is illusory. The savings are not there.

When we came into government, those opposite had left us with government expenditure, as a percentage of gross domestic product, at 29 per cent. And we have reduced it to 23 per cent. Those opposite—arguing for smaller government and everything else—were never able to reduce it by a percentage point in the Fraser years. We have reduced it by 6 per cent, with the hard work of Finance Ministers Dawkins, Walsh, Willis and Co. They have been able to reduce the figure, cut the fat out of government and allow much more for investment.

I will go to only a couple of other points. For the first time today I saw a shell shocked shadow Minister. Senator Short looked totally unconvincing when somebody said he would try to prove that there were holes in the package. For the first time Senator Short looked as though he was worried. He knows, from his Treasury experience, that the expenditure side of his package is a nonsense.

Those opposite cannot provide the tax cuts and the compensatory package. And if that is the case, those opposite have two choices: either to renege, as they did in 1977 on their tax cuts; or blow the deficit out. Either one would be a disaster, but blowing the deficit out further would be the greatest disaster.

I know about my area only but, having read 1 1/2 pages on defence, I see that what those opposite propose to do is a total betrayal of the history of defence administration in this country. They cannot make up or achieve—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't fix it.

—Senator MacGibbon has been going around and saying that defence expenditure should be 3 per cent of gross domestic product. That is an extra $2 1/2 billion that those opposite have to find. Meanwhile, the shadow Minister for defence, Senator Durack, and others will dump another $200m back into Consolidated Revenue. We have kept defence expenditure at real growth for years and we have put up with Opposition members going around the bases and everywhere else and saying we cannot be trusted on defence. The only people who like the Opposition's defence policy are the Democrats. They at least have a logical policy. Senator Bell agrees that these days the Liberal and Democrat policies are the same.

PARA.TAB: We have before us today a motion read by Senator Hill. He read his speech—his prepared text. He wants a rational debate, yet people get shouted down every time they try to have a say. Every time there is any analysis at Question Time, we have all sorts of points of order to cut the answer off. To use a sporting analogy, Senator Hill likes kicking downhill with a breeze all the time. He does not like the hard work. He does not like the hard debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get a new Whip. They have all gone away while you've been talking.

—Our lawyer mate from Queensland is starting to express his views again. He is the master of the inane interjection. The apprentice, Senator Walters, is sitting there babbling away. When we are talking about the unfortunate replacement of a Minister, Senator Macdonald might like to stand up and explain why the Liberal Party in Queensland has just replaced Mr Beanland; why Senator Macdonald's other ally, Mr Cooper, has just stood aside; why Mr Metherell left the New South Wales ministry and Liberal Party; or why two frontbenchers were sacked in Adelaide on Friday last week.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald may jump up and argue that the replacement of a Minister or other member of parliament is bad, but in the last few weeks there have been examples littered right across the coalition parties. I tell Senator Walters, through you, Mr President, that Robin Gray is next, if ever there is a carcass hanging up waiting to get cut down. All the Opposition members have walked away from him. He was their greatest mate in 1982. Now they have walked away from him. They have left him there to die politically. Having brought the Liberal Party back to government for the second time in 50-odd years, those opposite are now getting rid of him.

This motion deserves to be defeated. It is inappropriate to bring it up at 2 o'clock by way of ambush, but that sort of mechanism is the only way Senator Hill can operate—kicking downhill with the breeze, not giving others a chance to prepare their speeches. Even poor old Senator Short, I suspect, could not have prepared that amount of nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion, particularly the last line:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . its failure to offer Australians any alternative to the Coalition's Fightback program as it desperately and selfishly clings to power.

That is the part of the motion that I want to address today. This country deserves better than the situation we are in today. This nation, which once had the third highest standard of living in the world, has now been reduced to a situation where a million people are unemployed, our farmers are being thrown off their properties due to the Government policy of 23 per cent interest rates, our youth cannot get jobs and unemployment is going over the one million mark.

PARA.TAB: What does the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say when we bring these matters up? He says that we are un-Australian. The coalition package was launched on 21 November and no-one in the Government has laid a glove on it yet. Government members have not laid a glove on it because they cannot lay a glove on it. Mr Howe, the Deputy Prime Minister, went down at the first hurdle. He made a monumental mess of it. He retired hurt to the dressing room. Then we saw Mr Kerin go up; he was sacrificed at the altar when he could not dent the package. He was thrown out of the boat. Then yesterday, at the New South Wales conference, the Prime Minister took the ball; he absolutely bored the delegates. According to what the journalists said, it was a pathetic, even an embarrassing, attempt to dent the goods and services package. No-one has been able to take it on. No-one on the Government side, except sometimes Senator Walsh, has tried to give an intelligent explanation of what is wrong with the package. Senator Walsh, from his position as a journalist with the Australian Financial Review—a very privileged position—has a crack at the package from time to time, but even that has failed.

When the Government could not put any dent in the coalition package, could not attack it, could not do anything to it, the Prime Minister fell back on calling us un-Australian because we provide a vision and a hope for the future through laying down a package that has some sort of vision, some sort of blueprint for prosperity, some sort of hope for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pathetic.

—It is a pathetic attempt. The Prime Minister deserves the censure of the Senate, and so does the Government for putting up with the Government's attempt. It has been a pathetic attempt by the Government. What is more un-Australian than having a million people unemployed? What is more un-Australian than that? What is more un-Australian than having people thrown off farms that their families have had for four or five generations? What is more un-Australian than having our youth unable to get jobs? What is more un-Australian than having 50 per cent and 60 per cent increases in bankruptcies? That is un-Australian.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has betrayed the confidence of the people of Australia. He has gone to them and said, `I am a good Australian. I will have a drink with you. I can tell a joke with you. I can say a few words which you would identify with'. For eight years he has bought their confidence with that sort of message. But it does not matter now. The people have woken up and they have said, `No longer can we put our confidence in this man'.

When Australians knock off for their three-week holiday at Christmas they will be thinking of their future and their children's future and they will be thinking of the fellow on the next machine who lost his job, the empty desk or the farm notice that will go up in their district. All of those will be monuments to this Government's inability to govern this country.

After nine years the people of Australia have lost confidence; all they want is to have an election now. They want to be able to cast their votes and they want some type of change in Government policy. Today Mrs Kirner said that Mr Kerin is not to blame. He cannot sell something, he cannot sell a policy, if it is not there.

Let us look at what the Government has done to Australia. Let us look at some of its policies. It has introduced a training levy of 3 per cent when small business is just going out the door backwards. It introduced a superannuation levy of 9 per cent—another cost on business when bankruptcies are up by 50 per cent every three months. It introduced a fringe benefits tax that is loading tax onto business. No wonder businesses are having to shed labour all the time and no wonder we are finding that there are one million unemployed!

We should look at the contrast between the policies of this Government and those of the Opposition. One is loading business imposts—cost on cost on cost to businesses—while the other one is taking costs off. The coalition is removing payroll tax, removing excise and reducing seven taxes. It is doing all these things, and that is the contrast between the Government and the coalition. One is putting costs on and the other one is taking them off. No wonder the people in rural Australia have grabbed the coalition package like a man grasps something when he is drowning. They have grasped it because it gives them some hope.

In my experience in the National Party I have never seen people grab a package with more desperation and more hope than they have this package, because it gives them something. They can see that the removal of the payroll tax will remove costs from their inputs, costs from putting beasts through abattoirs and costs on the Wheat Board. They know that the removal of the excise duty on fuel will cut transport costs by 10 per cent. They know the removal of the sales tax on transport will cut their costs by another 6 per cent. They know that they will be better off by 16 per cent on transport costs plus payroll tax. They know that they will get increased family benefits. Not one person that I have met in rural Australia has not grasped this package with some hope.

This Government offers Australians absolutely no hope. They know that through the Opposition's package they will have $6 billion removed from their diesel and petrol prices, reduced freight costs, a rebate on input costs and no assets tests for isolated children. What has this Government ever given them? Nothing at all. After nine years, everyone who supports the coalition, and many people who do not, have said that it is time for a change.

It does not matter how hard the Government tries, how many Ministers it sacks, or whatever else it does, the tide is out. The situation will only worsen and the Government will fall further and further behind in the polls. The option that faces this Government now is whether to go to an early election and lose less or wait until the time is up and lose more. All the marginal seats will topple. The decision this Government faces is whether it should go to an election now and salvage a number of its seats or continue until its time is up and be relieved of even more seats.

This censure motion deserves to be carried. If the Democrats do not support the censure motion, they are condoning the Government's approach and its policy direction that have left this country in a terrible hole. They are condoning the fact that while this Government has been in power the gross foreign debt has risen from $36 billion to $166 billion, an increase of 500 per cent. The current account has risen from $7 billion to $15.5 billion—another legacy of this Government's discredited policies. The Democrats, by not supporting the censure motion, will be condoning the fact that bankruptcies are up 72 per cent on last year and that there are 867,000 people unemployed and many more underemployed—and some of those men whose wives are working are not entitled to benefits. The Democrats can no longer sit on the fence—they must either support the Opposition and its package or support the Government—or they will be wiped out at the next election because they will have become completely irrelevant to the debate that is facing the Australian people.
At the conference last Sunday, the Prime Minister, in the uninspiring speech he gave when he desperately needed to rally the troops, said:

SPEECH.PARA: So it is a message of confidence I bring today—confidence in our capacity for renewal and revitalisation, confidence in our program for a better, fairer, stronger Australia, and, above all, confidence in the people of Australia.

He has betrayed that confidence; he has betrayed the people of Australia; and he has betrayed this nation. He can no longer rely on the goodwill of the people of this nation. Mr Hawke is finished. It does not matter what the Government puts into place, because the people have made their decision.

PARA.TAB: During the Christmas break, people all over Australia will be talking to their families, friends and relatives, and the discussion will be: `We have trusted this man for eight years, but it is time for a change. Australia deserves a change. Our children deserve a job. Our families deserve a future. This Government has not given us that future and so it will have to go'. The sooner the election is announced, the better it will be for Australia. The Government is wounded; it cannot make any policy decisions; it is totally tied up in leadership challenges—and which Minister will be next off the sleigh to feed the baying wolves?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook.

—It could be Senator Cook or anyone else. It looks like Senator Button is ready for the high jump, because the unions and the organisational wing of the Party are demanding his resignation. If he does not jump, he will certainly be pushed. It does not matter now what actions this Government takes. It is on the ropes; it is finished; it has been discredited; it has had its chance; and it failed the people of Australia badly. It is time it went.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the Leader of the National Party in the Senate (Senator Boswell) support a consumption tax. Apart from low income earners in this country, no other sector will be worse affected by a consumption tax than the primary industry sector, the rural sector. When the realisation hits that there will be a 15 per cent tax on all services and all products from the rural sector, there will be a massive vote of no confidence in the National Party of Australia.

PARA.TAB: This motion invites the Government to vote on a lack of confidence in itself. There is no lack of confidence in this Government and this Government is not intending in any way, shape or form to cast a vote of no confidence in itself. The ghost of 1975 hangs over this debate. In 1975, with one positive poll, in this chamber Supply was blocked and a Government was sacked. To look at the demeanour of the Opposition in its steps of setting aside Question Time, shouting down speakers from the Government who have entered this debate at the Opposition's request and hogging the television coverage of Question Time to make a rehearsed and written speech in this chamber is to see the ghost of 1975 hanging over this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you're right.

—Senator Panizza hopes I am right. I think that is a disgusting admission from him, because one of the most disreputable events in Australian history was the blocking of Supply in this chamber, and we will not succumb to it again. Moreover, there ought to be a fundamental recognition in this country, irrespective of what party people come from, that governments deserve to fulfil their term. If there is not that recognition, no change is possible, because all change involves some period of unpopularity in order that the rewards are reached further down the track. We will insist on fulfilling our term and prove that our economic settings are the right and proper ones for this country. One of the most foundational claims of this consumption tax package—
—Goods and services.

—It is a consumption tax, raw and simple—a 15 per cent tax on everything—and the Opposition had better put that idea in its mind. It can gloss over it with allegedly PR tested fancy titles such as Fightback, but it is a 15 per cent tax on goods and services in this country, and that is what the Australian community will understand. One of the proud claims made by the Opposition about this tax is that it will create employment. On 22 November on radio 2GB, John Hewson said:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe it is possible to aim to create, between now and the end of the decade, something like two million jobs . . .

And he went on to argue that that is part of the 20-point plan of this package. On 23 November, the very next day, in an address to the Eastern Suburbs Leagues Club, as reported by the Canberra Times, John Hewson said:
I am not making any promises about the level of unemployment. There will be transition effects.

Of course there will be transition effects, because there can be no guarantee about unemployment. If one goes through this whole package, one can see no accurate basis upon which one can extrapolate a $2 million job creation program over nine years; one has to look at the transition problems. Even if one accepted the raison d'etre of the whole package, the transition problems in it are enough to bring it tumbling down—to create high inflation and high interest rates, increase the exchange rate, create further unemployment and wash cyclically through the economy of an uncompetitive Australia. That is the impact of this package.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased that this package is now before the Australian community. There is now a clear contrast between what the Labor Party and the Opposition stand for. The Opposition has proposed that it will fix employment with a new tax and generate growth and investment with a new tax; and that a new tax will, somehow, create a more productive Australia. Now, for the first time in the democratic world anywhere on the face of this earth, there is the invention of a tax-led recovery. If people are taxed more, magical things can happen. That is, of course, black magic. That is, of course, not true and when one looks at this package, it is clear that it is not true.

A new tax of 15 per cent will not fix the Australian economy: a new tax of 15 per cent will drive this economy into the ground and push it down the New Zealand road where, just across the Tasman, exactly that has occurred. There is a laboratory, if you like, sitting there and anyone who wants to see the impact that the Hewson package would have should just go there to have a look.Moreover, this tax is totally inequitable. It is a tax that is regressive. It is a tax that benefits the wealthy, hurts the poor and damages the middle class in this country. That is the sort of tax it is.

Let me go to the figures. Let me demonstrate my proposition. Let me do something that has never been done on this side of the argument before: prove a point. People earning $20,000 a year would gain 4.8 per cent in income from this tax. At the level of $30,000—around the level of average weekly earnings—the gain would be 6.8 per cent. But at $50,000—for those in a higher income bracket—the gain would be 12.4 per cent. Comparing $30,000 with $50,000—these are percentages, not just flat money amounts—the increases go from 6.8 per cent to 12.4 per cent.
