If one is in that group of Australians—less than 2 per cent overall—who earn more than $75,000 a year, which is two and a half times the weekly average earnings, the gain peaks at 14.7 per cent. A low income earner on $20,000 would get a 4.8 per cent tax cut but someone earning more than $75,000 would get 14.7 per cent, and 14.7 per cent of $75,000 is worth a damned sight more than 4.8 per cent of $20,000. And the Opposition says this tax is not inequitable!

It is a tax that provably serves the rich and wealthy in this country, looks after the Liberal Party and National Party mates, does not help low income earners, penalises the middle classes in this country and is totally regressive. On top of that, this whole consumption tax package is a package that reduces real wages. At the same time that taxes would go up, wages would come down under this package. That is not the wages of the executives or the wages of the captains of Australian industry—there is no plan here to curb excessive executive salaries; none whatsoever—but the wages of ordinary working Australians, and they would come down quite dramatically. This package is deceitful. Up front it says that real wages have fallen in Australia but, in its fine print, it forces a scenario on this country that would push real wages down further.

It is a high inflation package. At the moment inflation in Australia is running at 3.3 per cent. On Budget forecasts that will drop to 3 per cent. What does this package do? According to the reputable and independent economic research unit, Syntec, this package will push up inflation from 3.3 per cent, targeted at 3 per cent, to 9.5 per cent. As it does that, interest rates will rise—Syntec testifies to that in its own independent analysis—and the exchange rate will firm, meaning that for exporters of rural products and mineral commodities out of this country the prices will get higher, the returns will be fewer and we will suffer as a consequence.

There are three basic myths that the Opposition has tried to peddle about this package. I will deal with each of these myths and expose the paucity of reasoning and the deceitful nature of the allegation. The first myth is that living standards in Australia have fallen. Since 1983, real household disposable income per capita has risen by over 10 per cent.

The second myth is that our international competitiveness is deteriorating. Under Hewson, foreign debt would increase by over 50 per cent of GDP compared to around 30 per cent now. An increase to 50 per cent from 30 per cent would be a direct by-product of the Hewson package—a direct causal link established—and the Opposition cannot get out of that argument.

The third myth is that Australia has a relatively big government and high taxes. Of course, everyone knows that that is not true, yet the Opposition propounds that theory. Australia is the second lowest taxing country in the OECD with only Turkey being lower. The wholesale sales tax is not distortionary—it comprises less than 2 per cent of business costs and less than 1 1/4 per cent of our exports.

These are examples of deceit. I use the word `deceit', and there is no single greater deceit in this package than the deceit about industrial relations, wages and working conditions in this country. It has been said by Dr Hewson and Mr Howard that the centrepiece of this whole package is industrial relations reform, as they call it. That is what they say. That is the centrepiece. In over 700 pages of written material, there is one-plus page on what they mean by industrial relations. All they say in that one-plus page in more than 700 is that they will rip the guts out of the Department of Industrial Relations and destroy its program estimates. That is all they say.

Is there a clue as to what they will do? No, there is not. Is there a clear policy statement on so-called reform? No, there is not. Is there a series of press statements by Mr Howard? Yes, there is, but he never gets pinned down, he always evades the point and he never comes clean. What we do know from Mr Howard is that the New Zealand road beckons him. The New Zealand road is the road he wants to travel. The New Zealand road is the road which scorched the earth in New Zealand, drove that economy into the ground, created unemployment of the sort that we have not seen in this country since the Great Depression and totally destroyed the living standards of New Zealanders.

It is clear, therefore, that the industrial relations policy—the so-called centrepiece—is the mystical ambush that we expect to get near to an election. Why do not honourable senators opposite ever tell the truth? If it is the centrepiece, tell us what the policy is rather than us having to divine it from a series of press releases, leaks and, shall I say, Delphic views put by their shadow spokesman.

We do know a couple of things, and on those couple of things we should concentrate. We do know, for example, that it is the intention of the Opposition to destroy the Industrial Relations Commission. We do know that it is the intention of the Opposition to undermine the award system in Australia that protects minimum wage and condition entitlements for ordinary Australian workers.

We do know, courtesy of page 2 of the Financial Review last Thursday, that it is Dr Hewson's clear intention, to use his own words, `to destroy the Australian union movement'. He argues that for his package to be realisable the Australian union movement `must be and shall be destroyed'. This is one of those transitional difficulties to which he refers—the fact that an organisation to which 42 per cent of the Australian work force belong will be ignored. In any democratic society the checks and balances that hold fair play in place require a free, open and democratic trade union movement. But, no. None of these issues are issues with which Dr Hewson is concerned. I ask honourable senators to see for themselves, if they have not already done so, page 2 of last Thursday's Financial Review. Dr Hewson's commitment is to destroy the union movement, and that is a transitional change.

We heard from Mr Greiner. He had to leave Australia and go to Japan to tell foreigners how good Australia's industrial relations were and, I might say, he did a very objective and fair job. Mr Greiner, the Premier of New South Wales, a man with a very poor industrial relations record in his own State—disputes in New South Wales run, at 51 per cent, above the average for the rest of the country—described Australian industrial relations in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: But the perception of a country—
referring to Australia—
with labour problems is the most erroneous image of all.
In the past decade strikes have declined by 70 per cent and three-quarters of Australian firms have had no strikes at all.
He went on to say:
Workplace reform and wage restraint have become routine. Cooperation has overtaken confrontation.

Thank you, Mr Greiner, for that unsolicited testimonial about success and achievement in the field of industrial relations by this Government. Is not that a basis for continuing economic improvement? Of course it is. Is not this an example of getting Australians to work together to remove the old barriers of them and us, employer and employee, and worker and boss? Is not this a basis for setting team goals for an enterprise, aiming at achievement of those goals and then trying to improve by sharing the benefits in profits and better wages? Of course it is. This is the basis that we have created in this Government.

PARA.TAB: What does Dr Hewson want to do? He wants to destroy it and break it down. He wants to renew the confrontation of the Fraser years and replace cooperation with conflict. He wants to pit Australian against Australian; he wants to divide Australians into boss and worker, employer and employee. That is what he wants to do. That is the commitment he makes in his policy.

We have seen no better an example than in the so-called Austrain package, whereby if a person is working in a company he or she can be easily sacked and replaced by someone receiving 80 per cent of the award rate. That is what Dr Hewson's package proposes—80 per cent of the award rate. He will say, `You are all out, sacked and finished; we will replace you with people earning 80 per cent of your wage'. When those people finish and, 12 months later, their replacements go up to the full rate, they will be sacked and replaced. The Opposition is promising recyclable unemployment.

I am running out of time and I have not had the opportunity to turn to the issue of health. Through the accord, this Government introduced Medicare and removed health costs from the Australian household budget. The Hewson consumption tax package, apart from adding 15 per cent costs and lowering wages, will add to costs in the Australian household $2 billion extra per year in health costs. Who will meet the extra $2 billion? It will be ordinary Australians. It will be a cost which they do not have to pay now: a $2 billion levy. Is that costed into the so-called compensation? Of course it is not, because the Fightback program is basically a deceitful package. The document goes for over 700 pages all up. It tries to hide the nasties somewhere in the fine print, while beckoning up front and saying, `This is a good package for you'. It is deceitful. It will be unmasked, it will be seen for what it is and it will be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested to hear the emotional response from the ACTU advocate, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. It was very long on passion but pretty short on facts. In his last bit of passion—which was as inaccurate as everything else he said—he talked about the money which is to be spent on health. Would the honourable senator rather have queues for public hospitals? Would he rather have the rich in the public hospitals? That is the way he would like a health care system to run. But the people of Australia know it is in a mess and it is no good him trying to say otherwise.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Am I in order to reply to that question now, or should I wait until later?
—I think there will be an appropriate time later, Senator Cook.

—We are here today, believe it or not, to censure this Government for the misery and hardship delivered to hundreds of thousands of Australians—one would never know that from the Minister's speech—as a result of the Government's economic incompetence. We are here, too, to censure the Government for its failure to offer any alternatives to the coalition's Fightback program, as the Government selfishly and desperately clings to power.
—Are you reading this?

—No, I am not reading, but I will now read something to answer what Senator Cook has just said. Senator Cook made some comments about rich mates. He reminded me that the Government has been governing for rich mates for the best part of nine years. I will list for the honourable senator some of the rich mates that he has been governing for: Warren Anderson, donation of $150,000 to the Labor Party; Kevin Parry, $200,000; Sir James McCusker, $200,000; Lang Hancock, $1m over three years; John Roberts, $300,000; Yosse Goldberg, $300,000; Laurie Connell, $1.5m; Dallas Dempster, $400,000; and Alan Bond, $300,000. The list could go on and on. We know who the rich mates are; let us not forget who this Government has been desperately governing for throughout the last nine years.

PARA.TAB: But we are not talking about rich mates here today; we are talking about Australians throughout this country who are battling and who are worried sick. They are not the rich mates of the Government; they are the people for whom this Government really should have been governing. I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that earlier this year the Australian Institute of Family Studies reported that 24 per cent of families where the wife was not in the work force were having difficulty financially, and another 49 per cent were just coping. Even where the wife was working part time, 55 per cent of the families were having financial problems.

That is the reality; that is what this Government's policies and lack of leadership have brought upon us. These Australian families are suffering misery and hardship. An item which appeared in the Institute of Family Studies journal stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The recession is having a considerable effect on young Australian families, particularly those with children or with one breadwinner. When respondents were asked what were the greatest pressures on them, financial and business pressures loomed large in their minds. Money was also a main cause of disagreement between partners.

We know that it is not just money; it is marriages, too, which are at stake because of this Government's failure. We know that people in the bush have been committing suicide as a direct result of this Government's economic policies and their impact on these people. But the Government will not debate the Fightback package. We will get an emotional diatribe like we have just had from Senator Cook. The reason the Government will not debate the package is that the Government is dead afraid of the proposals which are contained in nearly 700 pages and in three volumes.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans has said here today that the Government does not need an alternative policy. He said it by way of interjection. I do not know whether Hansard picked it up, but several of my colleagues and I on the front bench heard Senator Evans say that the Government did not need an alternative policy. Let that be on the record if that is what the Government thinks. Australia does need alternative policies, and it needs and deserves an alternative government.

The policies engineered by this Government have brought us massive interest rates which have sent businesses, big and small, to the wall. They have sent nearly one million Australians out of work, into misery and hardship. Yet this is the Government which believes money should be spent on such things as research into women and sustainable development, grants for the development of surfboards shaped for women or investigations into the portrayal of women in the media. At the same time, the Government is disregarding totally the degradation of women in pornography in this country. The Government has also spent 12 months or more living off the immoral earnings of Telecom Australia and its 0055 telephone numbers, without taking any action until recently, despite the fact that women throughout this country hate it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the big issue in Australia—the 0055 telephone issue?

—The Minister does not understand because he is not in touch with what is going on in grassroots Australia. Senator Richardson clearly thinks that is a trivial issue. Many Australian women—15,000 or more people have already petitioned the Parliament—find it offensive that the Government will not take action and that it has lived off those immoral earnings. The Minister should not try to tell me that he knows what is going on in the country.

PARA.TAB: This Government does not listen to mainstream Australia; it listens to fringe groups. It listens to the ones who make a loud noise. Senator Richardson is the past master of this —manipulating fringe groups for political preferences at election time. We all know how Senator Richardson aims at the group which makes a lot of noise and then oils its wheels.

The Government's attention to Australian women is evinced by a mass of consultants, a bevy of bureaucrats and glossy publications. The Government does not worry too much about actually doing something practical or mainstream for Australian women. That is because it is all talk and no action and it is out of touch anyway.

Senator Evans told us that he does not need any alternative policies. The Government will allow young women in battling families to struggle and to suffer—the women, their husbands and their children—because the breadwinners are out of work and are unable to find replacement work. This Government will sit by and wring its hands while women in the country are living in desperate fear for their future and that of their families. The Government just sits by while older women worry about income security in their old age and health care when they need health care. The elderly are already very heavy consumers of health insurance because they know that they will end up in queues for so-called elective surgery for hip replacements and so on. They are very frightened about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are they going to afford private health insurance?
—They will be compensated entirely for their private insurance, and the honourable senator knows it. Why will the Government not debate these Fightback proposals?
—They don't know because they have not read the package.

—I think it would be very good if I told the Government some of the things that I think are pretty important to Australian women. Let us see whether the Government thinks they are too. There has been the doubling of family allowances for families with an income of under $30,000 and the increase in family allowances by 50 per cent for those on incomes of up to $40,000 and the dependent spouse rebate has substantially increased for one-income families, with children, with an income of up to $70,000. There is also additional child-care assistance of $90m.

PARA.TAB: Assistance to isolated children has been particularly difficult recently. Families have been unable to send their children away to get an education, yet the cost of transporting them to local schools or over great distances and poor roads has been immense. The measures we are proposing for isolated children will go a long way towards remedying the effects the Government has caused.

Despite Senator Colston's report into gifted and talented children, this Government has not lifted a finger to help those who are most able to get our country out of the economic trough—the gifted and the talented. The Opposition is prepared to spend money on programs to assist gifted children. That is an Australian first. We are spending money to help voluntary agencies provide emergency relief, crisis care and counselling to pick up those families that this Government has put in a position of needing that help.

Women too will benefit from the extra two million job opportunities. They are real jobs—not make work jobs that this Government thinks of—provided by the private sector because of the encouragement given to business, which will generate jobs. Personal income tax cuts are particularly targeted to middle income families, which are having such trouble. The major changes to the capital gains tax are particularly important for older people going into retirement, especially women who are substantial owners of small businesses. The great changes in the capital gains tax will be important to them.

We never hear the Government say, `This is terrific; you will get $500 per annum income tax free on any shares held by employees through an employee share scheme'. Oh no, the Government would not like the workers to hear about that! What about the workers in the western suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne that the Government purports to care about and the two-parent families trying to get to two jobs, sometimes part time work, in jalopies that can barely keep going on the roads? They consume petrol, but they have to get there because there is no public transport.

TALK.START.PARA: —You'll put a 15 per cent tax on car repairs.

—We will take the money off and hand it back to them at every petrol pump, and they will remember that. The tax free savings scheme will help Australians save money for the first time. They will not feel that the Government is ripping it back off them the moment they have saved by taxing it twice. Australians will be pretty pleased about that.

PARA.TAB: Older women who have been out of the work force and get back in but are behind the eight ball with their superannuation will have a means of making a catch-up payment when they have any savings at all to put into their superannuation. That will be meaningful to those women. That will be important to the people who will not have to pay a lump sum tax on their superannuation payouts.

Housewives and their spouses who have never been able to have any kind of retirement income security will, at last, be able to get tax deductions on any money put into retirement savings accounts, which will be very important. Tax free savings for families will be very important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry's workers would have loved it, and Senator Sherry knows it. So it is no good shouting now. Wives who are going to outlive their husbands want to know that they will have some decent income in their old age. We live a lot longer than men, and we are poor a lot longer as a result. Anything that can be done by way of superannuation or income security for women in their old age is a marvellous step forward. The present Government has been in office for nine years and has not lifted a finger to try to do anything about it. Senator Sherry should know about casual employees in the hospitality industry. They have little or no—
—What did you do for them? They had no superannuation until we got into government.
—They will now have meaningful opportunities for superannuation instead of the Government's 3 per cent nonsense—
—We are going to give them 9 per cent.

—Rubbish. The Government will not. I have not seen the legislation; Government members are all talk. The deferred pension plan will enable people who want to work longer to take 8 per cent more each year that they are not on the pension

SPEECH.PARA: while they are in the work force earning a living wage. That will mean a lot to many people. What about abolishing the compulsory retirement age? A lot of people do not want to be forced to retire. That is important to people.

PARA.TAB: Young Australians will be able to borrow against their superannuation entitlements and young Australians who want to acquire a home can get a $2,000 cheque from the Commonwealth Government. I think they are pretty important things for average Australians, but this Government does not want those matters debated.

At the last election a $64m promise was given to women in rural areas who have little or no access to good quality health care that there would be mammography services, including mobile units, for Australian women. Eighteen months later, after we had the flourish of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the election, $1m of that $64m has been spent over three years. That is yet another massively broken promise of the Prime Minister.

Why can older women not get a Medicare rebate on densitometry, the measurement of bones for osteoporosis—an important preventative mechanism which will allow women to be treated ahead of time for osteoporosis? Why will the Government not do that? Why will the Government not debate our proposal to do it?

We have other measures which will improve the quality of health care to people in rural areas. Why will the Government not discuss them? Why will the Government not discuss the pharmaceutical benefits concession card for people over the age of 65? Why will the Government not discuss the way we want to free up the opportunities for new drugs? We have not had a new contraceptive pill available in this country for 10 years. We are a Third World country when it comes to contraception nowadays. Why do we have such bureaucratic measures? The Government is so lacking in concern that we cannot get any attention given to that.

An extra $10m will be spent to give women, and those caring for people with dementia, respite care. These are important matters for individual Australians right around this country, but the Government does not want people to know about it. That is why it will not debate this. The Government does not have any policies itself.

There will be a massive injection of new funding into education—particularly $520m over 10 years—into the TAFE system. Very importantly, women enter the education system in maturity so that they can acquire skills to get back into the work force when they need to support themselves. The Government has dragged its feet on the TAFE system. We are showing it the way.

There will be an extra $154m to encourage parent choice of school in the government sector, to lift literacy and language skills, and to expand professional development for teachers. There is an exciting series of proposals on education, as well as on health. These proposals deserve proper recognition and debate, not destruction. Australians like the sound of these proposals when they hear about them, and they wonder why the Government should see it as a priority to try to destroy the package.

Dr Hewson, on a number of occasions publicly, has offered to support the Government in the implementation of our measures. If the Government does not have policies of its own, why does it not take up Dr Hewson's offer, for Australia's sake? It is genuinely made. But it will not be accepted because this Government is obsessed with its leadership. Neither of the men who engineered this recession—the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating)—regardless of which job they have currently or will have in the future, will have the gall to pick up the remedies for the recession that they caused.

The Government stands condemned for the hurt it has engineered and for the lack of leadership and policy failure it has imposed on Australia. The censure motion deserves to be supported. It will certainly be supported outside this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened intently to Senator Hill when he moved this motion. I know that some of my colleagues do not take him seriously, but I do. I heard his plea—
—Look behind you and see how much support you have.
—I have only to look in front of me. As long as I know Senator Walters is on the other side, I know I am on the right side.
—You have quality behind you too.
—I am well aware of that, as Senator Faulkner says, especially in his good self.
—All the knives are out behind you.

—It happens all the time these days. I listened to Senator Hill's plea when he was talking about this package. He said that it was bringing in a new basis of hope and opportunity for the future and that the Opposition wanted it debated on rational grounds. I have been sitting in my office thinking about that. In order to assist that along, on behalf of the Government, I move the following amendment:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after "censures", substitute:
"the Opposition for advocating an economic package which:
(a)is based on an inequitable tax policy, including the taxation of the basic necessities of life;
(b)will do nothing to improve the living standards of ordinary Australians; and
(c)is environmentally irresponsible.".

SPEECH.PARA: We have to debate this package on rational grounds, and I think I have given this Senate the appropriate opportunity for just such a debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us a debate on the environment.

—We will certainly be talking about the environment. I agree that this consumption tax package must be debated. Nowhere in its 600 pages can we see any detail at all on where two million jobs will come from. The only detail is that under the third option—they do not exist. That is the only detail. It is an illusion. There is no detail whatsoever as to where the proposed savings come from. While this debate has been progressing, in another part of the building the Treasurer, Mr Willis, has been punching a $2 1/2 billion per year hole in this package. This package has been hit below the Plimsoll line so many times this afternoon that it is already starting to sink. During the next 15 months that is exactly what it will do.

PARA.TAB: In the early part of his speech Senator Hill concentrated on savings. I was interested in that. I try to listen carefully to what Senator Hill says. I do not want to deride it. However, I am a little amazed when I hear him say that the package is all about savings. Basically there is nothing in the package whatsoever about savings; not a thing.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is true; it cannot be debated. The Opposition is not serious. In Budget considerations this year—only three or four months ago—the Government decided to introduce 12 per cent superannuation for every Australian worker by the end of the decade. There has not been a more visionary announcement by a government in this country in 40 years. It is a great announcement and a great decision, and one that is long overdue. What happened on the Opposition benches? If those opposite have any concern about savings, it was not expressed in relation to the Budget in August. All we heard then was Mr Howard—we all remember him, he used to be an Opposition Leader—claiming that it was an expropriation of employers' profits. Those opposite did not even have the wit, the capacity, to recognise that Australia could do nothing less.

PARA.TAB: I do not understand where this concern for savings came from when there is no question that during the next 30 years the number of pensioners, as against the number of taxpayers, will become a huge problem for us. At the moment for every six taxpayers, we have one pensioner. By the year 2030, the number of taxpayers for every one pensioner drops to three—the number for taxpayers halves. We have a choice, and I suppose this is what the Opposition has been looking at. We can halve the pension, and I assume that the Opposition accepts that because it rejects the alternative. There is only one alternative: to introduce decent superannuation provisions for all Australians to provide for their later lives. The nation cannot afford it with the ageing of the population. Apparently, that is completely missed in this so-called package.

At the end of the day those opposite are prepared to say that pensioners can have their earnings halved, have their meagre incomes cut to shreds, because they do not want to expropriate—as they put it—employers' profits. Let us look at this so-called expropriation of employers' profits. If we went to any of the capital cities in Europe—or the United States—and asked an employer just how radical, how unusual, how different, how extraordinary is it to expect employers to contribute to employees' superannuation funds, it would not be unusual to find that it is the norm right across Europe. In all the countries that Australia likes to compare itself with, this is considered normal—nothing unusual; just the normal, everyday, routine occurrence. No matter where we go or who we ask in Europe, no-one disagrees with what is a matter of routine.

Those opposite, jumping as always to the tune of the employer organisations, terrified that the big boys with the big quids might suddenly turn against them, just say, `Whatever you want. If you want us to consign Australian pensioners to misery, if you want us to tell them that you want to halve their income, we will do so because you have asked us'. That is what this package provides for Australia's future.

What is even worse is that those opposite have had the gall to complain about foreign debt. The only way to get a savings pool of hundreds of billions is via the announcement in August. That is the only way. But this lot opposite were just not prepared to do that, could not accept the last hurdle; they had to turn back and run away. This Government will not be doing that. We will not be prepared to accept the halving of pensioner incomes because of some sacred agenda for a tax that hits the poor but benefits the rich.

In looking at any package, whether it is this consumption tax package or any other, I think all Australians have to ask themselves some questions about our future. It seems to me that Australia's future obviously lies in moving away from agriculture and raw mineral exports and getting into some value adding and into manufacturing. The real question for Australians is twofold: first, how do we achieve that; and secondly, who can implement that program? The answer to the first lies in the creation of a climate where investment can flourish, a climate which would have as its first requirement low inflation and low interest rates. If we do not have those two, we cannot have investment or jobs. So what happens?

We are presented with a package which gets rid of both, which destroys any hope, which dashes all hope of low inflation and low interest rates. Later during the week the Treasurer will have something to say about just what that inflation figure ought to be. Just as today he punched a hole in the costings of this consumption tax package, during the week he will do the rest of the job. He will show that it is not just a matter of grossly, fraudulently, underestimating the savings nominated in the package; it is also a case of underestimating the inflationary effect.

Every Australian, even every pensioner, who has any dollars in the bank will have to understand that this package brings about an automatic, immediate, overnight reduction in all that person has saved through his or her life. The other problem is that no-one in the Opposition is prepared to consider whether those savings ought to be compensated. Those opposite just do not care. That is their problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. That is a totally inaccurate statement, and the Minister well knows it. I ask you to ask him to withdraw.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr President, I do not think I will bother to answer what you have correctly said was not a point of order. As those pensioners contemplate their loss of savings, they also have to contemplate the extraordinary attack that the Opposition is prepared to make on their everyday lives. Every time they walk into a supermarket to buy the butter, the bread—
—You haven't even read the document.

—I know that those opposite do not want to hear any of this. When pensioners go to buy the milk or to buy anything else, the Opposition will just keep on crushing them. Today's noise and today's buoyancy will not be evident in six months time. This package will disappear and those opposite will disappear with it.

PARA.TAB: When we are looking at the climate that needs to be created for investment, we need to look at some sort of program for micro-economic reform. I can recall my colleague Senator Ray pointing out just how much the Opposition has been prepared to forget the Fraser years. It is worth reminding those opposite that in those Fraser years not one step on the road to micro-economic reform was ever taken. During this Government's period of office, we have already had a huge overhaul of the telecommunications industry. The consortium Optus, which was successful only a couple of weeks ago, has already committed itself to a $4 billion investment in Australia over the next five years, and 5,000 direct jobs are to be created. We will see an additional 26,000 direct and indirect jobs over the next 20 years from the third runway, which we approved in 1989. Demand at Australia's premier airport will be met and will be met for the next couple of decades.

Furthermore, airline deregulation has only been in place for a very short time, but already, with the new entrant, Compass, in the field, we have seen fare discounts of extraordinary proportions. This has not been heard of in Australia for decades. We have seen a 38 per cent increase in passenger numbers over one year.

Most importantly, I refer to waterfront reform. I have noticed over the last few weeks that the Opposition has not been asking Senator Collins any questions about it. I can understand why when we look at the figures. Enterprise agreements covering facilities in all capital cities and a number of regional ports have already been approved by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority over the last few months. So far, 2,362 waterfront employees have left the industry under the Government's reform program. That is 500 more than the announced two-year target of 1,800 redundancies to be achieved by this November.

In all of those areas there have been tremendous advances through economic reform. In the area of trade, exports of manufactured goods have increased by 112 per cent in real terms since 1983-84. The opportunity for the change away from reliance on commodities is already there and we are delivering the goods.

We have only to look over the Tasman to New Zealand to get an idea of what the Opposition really has in store for Australia. The New Zealand Government, with all the so-called benefits of its consumption tax, has cut the standard rates of unemployment benefits and sickness benefits by 9.7 per cent and 16.6 per cent respectively. This year there will be no indexation of benefits rates. The family benefit as a universal payment has been abolished. Honourable senators should remember that it is to New Zealand that Dr Hewson went to get his inspiration. The young are specifically targeted. The unemployed in the 20-24 age group in New Zealand have had their income slashed by 24.7 per cent this year. More than one million adults—one-third of the population—are badly affected, directly or indirectly, by the New Zealand consumption tax.

We do not have to look just at New Zealand. We should look at the UK, from which the Opposition used to say we would get some real inspiration. About one in five of the European Community poor live in Britain. That is what conservative government brings over time. One-fifth of the population in that one country is poor. In 1980 there were 49 million EC residents living in poverty; by 1985 it had increased to 50 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many children are in poverty in Australia?

—I will get to the children in poverty argument in a moment. I am very glad Senator Kemp raised that; as usual, I am grateful to him. In London these days the homeless are described as the roofless. The rooflessness in London has been growing at an extraordinary rate. There are approximately 300,000 people in the city of London alone who have no roof over their heads. That is the kind of world that the Opposition would have us face in the future.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the area of taxation. Over the last eight years we have seen some extraordinary reforms in taxation. This Government has done more than any other. We have made the largest personal income tax cuts in the nation's history. We came to Government in 1983. The Opposition never wants to talk about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fraser did nothing.

—That is right, Mr Fraser did nothing. The top marginal tax rate was 60c when we got into government. The lowest marginal rate, even if one was a battler, was 30 per cent. That has changed. The Government has cut those rates to 47 per cent and 20 per cent respectively. The dependent spouse rebates have been increased; they are indexed for inflation. All the things the Opposition could not do in all of those years, this Government has done already—and it will keep it up.

PARA.TAB: What is more, we have announced that by 1995 there will be no pensioner in the tax system. That will be one of the great reforms that this nation has ever had. It is long overdue. The Opposition could not even contemplate it in its seven or eight years in government. All it did was put taxes up. That is the real rub of the GST package. The Opposition is asking Australia to trust it. That would be a pretty difficult job for any sane person.

TALK.START.PARA: —A big ask!

—It will be a big ask, as Senator Collins says. Australians will be asked to trust the Opposition. The Opposition is not only asking that; it is asking Australians to believe that no future government can be trusted either. It is asking them to believe that the goods and services tax will never go up. We have been helped by Mr Downer in this. He is always a big help. I had a look at his document. It proves that taxes have gone up all through Europe—in France, Italy, Germany, the UK, Denmark and Israel. It does not matter where we look; taxes have gone up. But Mr Downer has us all reassured. His document says that tax has gone down in Chile, Peru and even Costa Rica. According to the Opposition's documents, taxes have gone down in those three places. Everywhere else—in every country with which we like to compare ourselves—taxes have gone up.

PARA.TAB: Every Australian knows that once the coalition's system is put in place taxes will keep going up, because it is easy to put taxes up. Honourable senators have to understand that it is very easy. Once we get a goods and services tax in place, it is simple to ratchet it up. It just takes a stroke of the pen and it is done; the money just rolls in. The Opposition could never resist it, mainly because, as the money rolls in, the Opposition knows it rolls in from the poor and not from the rich. It is the right kind of money for the Opposition because there is no problem at all for those who support the Opposition and every problem for ordinary decent Australians. That is what the Opposition is always like when it comes to money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wholesale sales tax up by $6 billion.

—When we get to wholesale sales taxes, we only have to compare bread and milk with Mercedes. Our priority is the bread and the milk and the Opposition's priority is the Mercedes. That is the essential difference.

PARA.TAB: In this debate, Senator Kemp, who is always very helpful in these matters, had the gall to ask me about child poverty. I think that ought to be addressed. I do not think it ought to be forgotten that it is only four years since my predecessor in this job, the Deputy Prime Minister, Brian Howe, introduced the family allowance supplement, which is obviously, unarguably, one of the great social reforms of this century. It ranks with the child endowment introduced by Mr Lang in the 1930s. This is one of the great reforms of the century.

In setting and reaching benchmarks, the supplement ensured that working class families in this country had available to them cash that they had never thought of before. The only problem in the early years of the scheme was getting it out to families. But hundreds of thousands of families now benefit from what has been a tremendous reform specifically directed to low income people and their children. Nowhere in the Opposition's package can any low income person in this nation find comfort. For example, in the much trumpeted tax cuts that is not even on the agenda. If one has a quid in this country one will get a much bigger cut out of the Opposition and this package but, if one has not, the battle continues and it gets harder and harder.

I would like to refer to the words `environmentally irresponsible' in the amendment I have moved. Let us look at the environmental irresponsibility of what this package is about. The Opposition says straight away that it will reverse the Coronation Hill decision. The Opposition will go in to Kakadu and the headwaters of the Alligator River that give Kakadu its real meaning and that make Kakadu the special place it is in the hearts and minds of Australians.

What hope will national parks right around Australia have when the Opposition gets in? Absolutely none. The Opposition has made it very clear that the sandminers will get a free go. Right along the coast of New South Wales sandminers are gearing up and saying, `We hope this gets up. As soon as it does we will have a free go again. We will be back into the national parks, back into the beach fronts, back where we always wanted to be but where Labor stopped us from being. No more will Labor—be it State or Federal right around the nation—stop this from being. We are out of the national parks and we would love to be back into them'.

Fortunately, during the next 16 months this package will come apart line by line, even though it is already below the Plimsoll line, as we were told a few times today by the Treasurer, Ralph Willis. That will go on and on. After six months the Opposition will not be trumpeting the package any more; it will be terrified of it. I do not think anyone over here should worry unduly. This tax package will fail. It makes the Opposition ineluctable. It returns Labor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion put forward by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill, which calls for the Senate to censure the Government for:

PARA.TAB: (a)the misery and heartache caused to hundreds of thousands of Australians as a result of its economic incompetence;
(b)its failure to offer Australians any alternative to the Coalition's Fightback program as it desperately and selfishly clings to power.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion does come at a time when the Government is exposed as being leaderless and rudderless. The public is sick and tired—actually, sick to death—of the public brawling within the Government which is diverting its attention from concentrating on the real issues and overcoming the ills that many people in our society suffer.

PARA.TAB: These ills are visited upon them by a combination of factors but the Government appears not to be concentrating on the solutions. The problems are manifest and widespread. One tragedy facing this country is 30 per cent youth unemployment. Also, 100,000 low income earners in Australia are spending half their incomes just keeping a roof over their heads. In the past 10 years the net tax payable by a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children has gone up 40 per cent more than the increase in disposable income. Family allowances are now only two-thirds the value they were when introduced in 1976.

It is upon the family that the burden of this Government's economic policies falls far too heavily. As mentioned by Senator Richardson, the Minister for Social Security, the Government has introduced the family allowance supplement, but that family allowance supplement goes to about only 8 per cent of all families. Most families, including some of those on FAS, are far worse off now than they were in 1976.

Why do I say 1976? What has happened to family allowance assistance since 1976 has to be repeated time and time again. As the Senate will recall, in 1976 the tax rebate for children was abolished and the money saved was transferred into a family allowance. In other words, it was a payment out of the hip-pocket of the taxpayer into the purse of the mother. It did not cost the Government a cent. It was the family's money and the Government took it out of the back pocket and put it into the purse. I supported that but at the time I warned that, if the family allowance was not indexed from that moment onwards, there would be a travesty of justice visited upon all families in Australia. That is precisely what has happened.

Since that time, successive governments have purloined from the purses of mothers something like $8 billion. Each fortnight this Government takes $49.60 out of the purse of every mother in a family with four children; that is, to the tune of almost $50 a fortnight this Government is putting its hand into the purse and taking out that money. No wonder families feel that there is something amiss. There is 50 bucks amiss for a start, and then we add to that the problems of unemployment.

The Government has boasted that these days families can have two and three jobs. It boasts about the number of jobs that have been created. But let us look at what these jobs are; let us see whether they are full time or part time jobs. Here is the Government boasting that families are now able to have two and three jobs but, of course, the family needs two or three jobs just to make ends meet. Let it not be forgotten, either by the Government or by the Opposition, that, so far as those families which rely on one income and particularly a lower income are concerned, the weighted average minimum award rate of pay for full time adult employees has fallen in real money terms by about $60 per week in six years.

I believe that there is a disastrous situation in the community. I have urged the Government to look at the participation rates in the work force and see who for perhaps more socially desirable reasons wants to stay in the paid work force and who wants to come out of the paid work force. It is not a question of compulsion or otherwise; it is a question of giving people free choice. Many people do not have that freedom of choice because they are forced, by economic pressures, to enter the paid work force. I am talking about those hundreds of thousands of mothers who would prefer to do the job which they consider is the most important in the world for them, that is, the nurturing of their children, yet they are forced into the paid work force just to make ends meet.

We will have a new unemployment figure out this week. Is it going to be another disaster? I fear that it is, with unemployment at between 800,000 to 900,000. That is a disgrace. The attention of the Government is being diverted from its real mission, because it seems to see the demolition of the Fightback package as its mission. That is not the Government's real mission; its real mission is to get on with the government of this country.

I would like to congratulate the Opposition for its political strategy because, sitting where I do, day by day I can see the Government falling for it. Might I say that it is a magnificent political strategy, and we can see the Government falling for it all the time. The Opposition has made the Government fight on its ground. The Opposition has made the rules. It is extraordinary, but members of the Government are following the Opposition's rules. The Government is nitpicking on the rules, saying, `We will punch holes in the Fightback package'. Well, the Government is just punching into the air. It is a disgrace, and my heart bleeds for this country to see it happen.

That is not to say that the Fightback package is all about the Opposition trying to set the Government into confusion. Clearly, there is a philosophical backdrop to the Opposition's Fightback package. It capitalises on the fears and very real concerns that are widespread within the community. It appeals to those who rightly believe that human initiative has been stifled.

In some areas the Fightback package has a somewhat warped view of the principle of near democracy. Near democracy is a principle—an ideal—which is very dear to the hearts of Australians, who love to be known as wanting a fair go and who love to be seen to be having a say. I am talking about the principle of subsidiarity. People want to have closer control over those who exercise power over them. I agree that the principle of subsidiarity is an important principle in government—that power should reside with the smallest group capable of efficiently performing the functions for which that power is required. In that way, those over whom the power is exercised have closer, nearer and more effective control over those who exercise the power.

That is a good thing, but I believe that that principle is warped in some parts of the Fightback package. In my view, the Fightback package places far more confidence in market forces overcoming economic and social ills than is warranted from experience in a number of other parts of the world.

The Government is all at sea. It reminds me of a story that was going around last week. The ship of government was at sea and a report was made to Captain Kerin during the night. He was told, `There is a light—a vessel —ahead, and we are heading on collision course'. Captain Kerin got on the two-way radio and said, `This is Captain Kerin. You are heading towards us on collision course. I order you to change course'. The reply came back, `This is Able Seaman Smith. No, you change course'. Captain Kerin got Admiral Hawke up and Admiral Hawke said, `This is Admiral Hawke. I order you—indeed, instruct you—to change course. We are on collision course'. The reply was, `This is Able Seaman Smith. No, you change course'.

Captain Kerin and Admiral Hawke huddled together and said, `What will we do? We will appeal to his good nature'. Admiral Hawke said, `This is Admiral Hawke. Will you please change course; I am a battleship'. The reply was, `This is Able Seaman Smith. No, will you please change course; this is a lighthouse'. The Government is at sea; it is not heeding the warnings that have been given to it—the clear light that has been shown to it. I believe that the Government should concentrate on avoiding those rocky outcrops and go full steam ahead to overcome the ills that are besetting this country.

The problem is that good government is not being exercised and there is not the imaginative leadership which would give a lead to the community and encompass the aspirations of the ordinary people. For good government there needs to be values as well as organisation. Within the community there must be a cohesive set of values, a clearly understood set of values, by any good government.

In this context, good government means the establishment of an economic and social order in which persons can live with freedom and dignity and pursue both their spiritual development and material well-being in conditions of equal opportunity and economic security. I believe that the Government fails that test.

It is unfortunate that the Government's attention is being diverted from getting back to basic principles by its attempts to follow the rules that are being set by the Opposition in its Fightback package. The Government should go back to basics. It should look at the beacons. There are plenty of beacons in the past which are clearly there for Labor to see, but because Labor is so blinkered it cannot see them. If the Government took the high ground and argued the matters from first principles, it may well be that we would see a very important debate in this community—not about the minutiae of some parts of the package, but an overall debate about where good government should lead this country and about whether the aspirations of the community are, in fact, captured and enunciated by the Government or by the Opposition.
I feel that I could support this censure motion. The first part of the motion states:
That the Senate censures the Government:
(a)for the misery and heartache caused to hundreds of thousands of Australians as a result of its economic incompetence. . .

SPEECH.PARA: I am not too sure about the latter part, but I could go along with that. It states:

PARA.TAB: (b)its failure to offer Australians any alternative to the coalition's Fightback program as it desperately and selfishly clings to power.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the other thing that concerns me. We appear to be debating things as though there will be an election next week. As I understand it, there will not be an election until 1993 yet, listening to members of the House of Representatives, one would imagine that there will be an election next week. This censure motion, even were it passed, would not affect the course of this Government. Clearly, if this censure motion were passed in the House of Representatives, we would have an election next week or within the foreseeable future. At this point, it is not my intention to vote either for or against this motion. The Government has moved an amendment to it which has just landed on my desk, and about which Senator Graham Richardson made some comments.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am concerned, what I have said is very clear—people can take it the way they want to. I believe that there are many hundreds of thousands who are hurting in the community. In that sense, I think the Opposition in this chamber today has done a service to the community, but I believe that this motion is more appropriate for the House of Representatives than the Senate. I understand that the House of Representatives is not sitting now, of course. We should hold our fire. We in this place should be regarded with some degree of respect for our ability to be a check on the House of Representatives, which is the place of government. We should do that judiciously in every way we can, as we attempted to do last week. I appeal to the Government to look at the signs, to see the problems and to heed the warnings, because if it does not it will be sunk, together with its leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said some time ago, we have taken this unusual step because Australia is in crisis. We have asked for the Government to recognise that crisis and to recognise the misery and heartache that have been caused to so many Australians—the million unemployed, the other half million who are underemployed or who have given up, and the 30 per cent of the youth of this country who cannot find jobs. The Government should, first, recognise these tragic issues. Secondly, in recognising them, it should face up to the cause: the Government's own economic incompetence.

PARA.TAB: Occasionally in this place Senator Button has sort of admitted that the Government has made mistakes. What the Government now needs to admit is the degree to which it has been in error and it needs to recognise that it has made tragic errors, the consequences of which many Australians are now suffering.

The Government, instead of sacking the previous Treasurer because he failed to adequately communicate, should address its policies and address where it has gone wrong. It should get away from the argument that was put in the shallow job statement a few weeks ago in this place that the Budget and the Government strategy are on track. They cannot be on track when every few weeks the unemployment figures are higher. We suspect that later this week the figures will be higher again. The Government cannot be on track. It needs to change policy.

The Opposition has put down a comprehensive and integrated package, as has been said today, of nearly 700 pages, to provide for this country a new direction that can give hope to Australians, that can give job opportunities and that can restore people's confidence in themselves. We have put that package on the table for debate. We want to debate it. We want it debated from now until the next election. But we want a rational debate, not a debate based on fear. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) should understand that. Like any Prime Minister, he should be willing to take the debate on principle, to attempt to take the economic argument, and to let the Australian people, in the end, make their choice.

We have raised this issue today because the Government has failed to recognise the misery and heartache that have been caused to hundreds of thousands of Australians as a result of its economic incompetence and because it has failed to offer Australians any alternative to the Fightback package that we have put before the Australian people. Regrettably, the reason for the Government doing so is that it is desperately and selfishly clinging to power. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We will be voting against the amendment because, as I indicated in my speech, we oppose the policies of the Government and the Opposition. For that reason, we will be voting against the amendment and the motion.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask the Minister whether he agrees with his Victorian colleague Premier Joan Kirner that it was unreasonable to sack the former Treasurer, Mr Kerin, for lack of communication because `. . . you can't blame lack of communication when there isn't an effective policy to communicate'.

—No, I do not agree with that. We do have substantive policies, as is well known. We are very proud of those policies because they have delivered effective micro-economic reform to the Australian community and have developed a very effective set of longer term economic settings which will be crucial to this country's long term economic future. We have policy settings in place that have beaten inflation and brought it down to levels that are unquestionably in line with our major trading partners. We have policies in place that have created a situation where interest rates are now at manageable levels—9.5 percentage points—compared with what they were 18 months ago.

PARA.TAB: We have policies where wages growth has been kept in check by the accord. We have a fiscal policy which is delivering structural integrity so far as the Budget is concerned. We have a policy in place which has reduced the current account deficit and which is stabilising the external debt in association with that. We have policies in place which are keeping demand growth below production growth, ensuring that inflation will be locked in at its present low levels and ensuring that the current account deficit reduction will be locked in at its low levels. We have an industry policy in place which is delivering genuine structural change.

We have a micro-economic strategy over a whole variety of sectors which is ensuring competitiveness and flexibility and productivity gains in the Australian economy. At the same time, we do have a policy strategy in place which is operating as an effective safety net, both in the social welfare area generally and so far as labour programs are concerned. These policies are delivering skills and training to people who will need them as the economy picks up. We are delivering all of that in an environment where, although there has been recession, as we are all acutely aware, the economy—at least so far as the non-farm economy is concerned—is unquestionably emerging from recession.

The evidence is there, with a 0.4 per cent net increase in the September quarter national account so far as the non-farm product is concerned. The evidence is there, with demand recovering in the September quarter, with profits and investment in equipment rising, with private final consumption expenditure remaining strong, with exports remaining strong and net exports in particular contributing 3.1 percentage points of real growth. We have a situation where, as a result of that, there has been more than a 20 per cent improvement in the current account deficit, despite a strong deterioration in the terms of trade.

We have positive signs continuing with dwelling approvals trending upwards and housing starts being set to rise strongly throughout the course of 1991-92. We have a number of business surveys indicating that although orders are currently at a low level, business activity is beginning to pick up. So we do have policies in place. We do have a strategy for the longer term sustainable growth in employment and in the economy, which is utterly at odds with the piecemeal scramble for the affections of the electorate that the Opposition has been demonstrating with its particular package.

The contrast, as we saw during the censure debate, is immense. The kind of strategy the Opposition is talking about—its alternative strategy—is one that will produce job reductions in the short run and not guarantee anything like the longer term job creation it is talking about. We are talking about a strategy which will deliver inflation, on the Opposition's own documentation, at over 12 per cent. We are talking about interest rates which, on its own documentation, will increase, and which all objective observers are saying will be of the order of 13 to 16 per cent. If that follows through into mortgage rates, just a two percentage point increase in mortgage rates will completely destroy the benefit for the average household of the tax cuts which the Opposition is talking about for such a household. It is committed to reducing real wages significantly and, by its own admission, it has destined productivity to go backwards. It does not have a package; it has a slipshod, piecemeal collection of bright ideas by yuppie undergraduates who do not know what they are doing, put in place by a leadership that does not know what it is doing, except capitulating to its perceived political needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, after that, I am forced to ask a supplementary question: why was Mr Kerin sacked?
—For reasons well and fairly articulated by the Prime Minister in his press conference last Friday.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs been drawn to the public lecture by Mr Justice Kirby calling for a review of Australia's drug laws? Mr Justice Kirby stated that Australian drug laws and policies had developed more as a response to international pressure than as a well targeted response to the dimension and character of the real problems of drug abuse in this country. He further suggests that the drug problem is more fitting for the attention of public health authorities than a court of law. Does the Minister agree with calls for a change to the way in which Australian authorities handle the drug problem in this country? Has the Minister examined the comments of Mr Justice Kirby? If so, what action is planned on these proposals? Further, are there any plans to change the Government's policy on drugs from prohibition to health care or alternative regulatory policies?

—I have seen press reports of a speech given by Mr Justice Kirby in which he spoke of what he claimed to be `Australia's fixation on prohibition to solve its drug problems'. He went on to detail that he thought that was imposing too high a cost on the community in regard to its police, court resources, and so on. That is a very unfair characterisation of Australia's strategy to deal with the problem of drug addiction in our society, whether we are speaking about the drugs that are labelled illegal or the drugs, alcohol and tobacco which cause such devastation to the health of so many people in our community. In fact, it is quite untrue to say that any one policy is dominant, whether it be prohibition of the illegal drugs, public health programs, or education rehabilitation programs. There is a partnership between all these areas which places us in a unique position in dealing with the problem of a drug-ridden Australia.

PARA.TAB: This morning Senator Baume and, I think, Senator Brownhill were present at a function in the Great Hall where some 2,000 young volleyball players from 100 schools from around Australia—190 teams—were gathered for the launch of the Commonwealth Bank Cup by the Prime Minister. The Drug Offensive was a co-sponsor of this Cup.

We got the message across to those 2,000 very fit, young Australians not only that their sport should be drug free—and they are committed to that—but also that they, as peer group members, should be putting pressure on their own age group, the higher teenage group, to take issue with the phenomenon of binge drinking. Unfortunately, binge drinking is a very important part of the culture in Australia, particularly at the end of the school year. Binge drinking by young people is a very serious and important part of the aberrant drug behaviour in which they can indulge. This, of course, can lead to violence which has its own problems in our society.

An example of the cooperation between law enforcement authorities and health programs lies in the needle exchange program. Particularly as a result of the evident difficulty confronting our society from the HIV virus, major cooperative efforts have been made between health and law enforcement authorities to allow that needle exchange program to be implemented in various jurisdictions.

Australian society does not set an impossible goal of ridding society of drugs, or of requiring drug abuse to be totally eliminated from our society, but we believe that the harm created by drug taking in our society can be minimised. On the law enforcement side, that requires vigorous action, in my belief, to stop trafficking in drugs. To that end, this chamber has been particularly supportive of measures to increase funding for the Australian Federal Police and the Customs services to prevent the importing of certain drugs into Australia and, of course, to confiscate the profits of crime of those who do engage in that drug trafficking, making profits out of our vulnerable, young Australians.

That has to go hand in hand with major educational and health efforts. That is being done. There is no one dominant strand to our policy, but I believe there is a comprehensive policy which will enable Australia over the next several years to diminish the reliance on drugs—indeed, the drug addiction—that is a characteristic of parts of the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Treasurer. I refer to the national accounts published last Thursday. Do these mean that the former Treasurer, Mr Kerin, was right when he said recently that Australia was in the worst recession for 60 years?

—No, it does not mean that. The recession is continuing as far as the aggregate figures are concerned. The overall GDP result in the September national accounts quarter is disappointing, but it is important to realise that gross non-farm product rose by 0.4 per cent. Obviously, that was not enough to ensure an overall net positive result in an environment where, in the farm sector, there was a full 16 per cent reduction in output as a result of the massive problems that that sector is experiencing from a combination of lost production through drought, and low prices as a result of overseas development. It is a phenomenally difficult environment to be coping with, as far as that particular sector is concerned. As far as the rest of the economy is concerned, the reality is that we are, as I have said, and for the reasons I have given, emerging from the recession.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the answer that has just been given by Senator Evans, what forecast does the Treasurer make in relation to farm product growth in this current quarter?

—I am not sure what current forecast there is. It is obviously contingent on the drought. If those opposite know more than I do about when it is going to start raining and when production and output will increase, then they ought to be sitting in a higher place of authority than this Senate. They must have a direct line to the Almighty. They should be sitting in a chair in a cathedral somewhere because, under those circumstances, they must know something that we do not.

PARA.TAB: Obviously it is very difficult, because of the nature of the forces at work on that farm sector output side, to make confident predictions. Nobody could possibly have assumed that the combination of factors would produce the devastating slump that has occurred. Certainly not the heroes of the National Party. Senator Boswell—as Senator Ray said, not trusted to occupy any position other than No. 2 on the obituary speakers' list—at the time of the last Budget was not heard to say anything about what the situation might be in the farm sector. Certainly we have not heard anything from Mr Fischer, who constantly has to be hidden from exposure because of his blundering around in this particular policy area. He has not had any brave predictions to make —or at the time of the Budget—about the inaccuracy of our forecast.

The point is that the rural sector decline has been deeper, stronger and longer than anyone could possibly have conceded, acknowledged or predicted. Under those circumstances, it is difficult to limp out of the environment we are in. But we are getting there, very obviously on the figures, as far as the things that are more within our control are concerned, and that is in the non-farm sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has he seen last week's `Corporate Brief' from the respected and long established economic consultancy, Syntec? Does it argue that the Hewson consumption tax package would result in higher interest rates, higher inflation rates and a higher exchange rate because of the Opposition policy on wages and industrial relations? Does the Government intend to implement the consumption tax package as it relates to wages and industrial relations? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have actually read the Syntec report, `Corporate Brief', dated 2 December 1991. It is not fair to describe Syntec as a pro-Government agency—it is not. It is a genuinely independent and, I believe, respected economic consultancy aimed at making economic forecasts for the benefit of the business community. Syntec did forecast that the consumption tax package of Dr Hewson would increase inflation and interest rates in Australia, and would increase the exchange rate. Perhaps the best thing to do is to quote exactly what was said. The introductory paragraph states:

ANSWER.PARA: If you think Hewson will win the election in 1993, prepare for a roller-coaster ride in interest rates—and, to a lesser extent, the exchange rate. A weakening international economy will bring 1992 interest rate falls. From a Hewson victory in 1993, rises must be expected as the new Government beds down a radical new labour market policy in a hostile union setting. The interest upswing must then re-commence as GST-adjusted inflation reaches a minimum of 9 1/2% in 1994.

One of the key elements of the Budget this year for the Government was to lock in a low inflation rate. It is a key element of our wages policy. The inflation rate is now at 3.3 per cent. According to the Syntec forecast, the Hewson inflation rate would be 9.5 per cent—a jump in inflation of 6.2 per cent during that period. That is a 6.2 per cent turbo-charged inflation rate to 9.5 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is either ignorant or misleading the Senate because Syntec put out a disclaimer at the end of the week on this statement. It was appalled at the way the Labor Party was misrepresenting its original statement.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Not only is there no point of order, but also the interjection was wrong. Syntec did not say that. I have a copy of its press release here and I am prepared to table it now to prove that what Senator MacGibbon has just said is not true at all.

PARA.TAB: In its press release, Syntec referred to allegations about movements in interest rates. So far, I am debating its forecast—obviously uncomfortable for those opposite—of turbo-charged inflation rates in Australia from the level of 3.3 per cent that is now enjoyed because of this Government's policies, to 9.5 per cent minimum. That is what Syntec said. As I have said, Syntec is an independent body. This is not the Government, this is an independent economic forecast.

Why does Syntec say that inflation will blow out so dramatically? Because of the labour market policies which are embedded in the consumption tax package. It observes that those labour market policies will blow this country apart with industrial disputation.

Last week Premier Greiner was quoted in this chamber as boasting about how Australia's industrial relations performance had improved. Premier Greiner was right—the Hawke Government has improved industrial relations performance in this country quite dramatically—and he was right to tell the Japanese about it, but if a Hewson Government ever gets into power we can forget about that improved industrial relations performance.

Dr Hewson himself has said that Syntec is wrong and that it will be professionally embarrassed. He has said that it is wrong. If one looks at page 2 of the Australian Financial Review last Thursday, one sees that, according to Dr Hewson, it is wrong because he plans, as a transitional thing, to destroy unions in Australia; that is to say, the consumption tax package cannot work unless the Australian trade union movement is destroyed. He has made, in his own words, a declaration of war upon the 41 per cent of the Australian working population who have chosen to join trade unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Chosen!

—That is a major institution in this country, an institution with which we have worked cooperatively. He now wishes to invoke the Fraser Government era of confrontation and division—Australian versus Australian.

PARA.TAB: One knows from any casual perusal of the economic record that the Australian union movement has cooperated with this Government in keeping wages at a moderate level. It has ensured that there has been a low inflation rate, and that is now its commitment. The reason we will not adopt the labour market policies of the Hewson Opposition is that we want to harness the cooperation of the Australian community, bring about the change in workplace culture of which Greiner spoke so approvingly, ensure that Australians work together and not against each other, protect the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, protect the award system and provide legitimate rights to employer organisations and trade unions. We will not turn Australian against Australian, turn this into conflict and division, and bring back the Fraser years when we had high unemployment, high inflation and high industrial disputation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In view of the stage reached in the ESD process and in view of the conservatism—some might say absolute rejection—of ESD by most senior bureaucrats in important portfolios, what ongoing structures and processes will the Government put in place to ensure that this important initiative does not die with the reports of the committees and that the recommendations for change contained in these reports are carried through?

—I think Senator Coulter is exaggerating the reaction of those to whom he refers as senior bureaucrats. I think he inferred—I forget his exact words—that they have almost unanimously rejected the concept. I am not aware of that occurring. Obviously, there are different points of view, as there need to be, and bureaucrats across the board will put views to government, but the Government remains committed to a process of ecologically sustainable development: it always has and remains so.

PARA.TAB: The real crux of the question will be decided in what can be negotiated with the States, and we are probably still some time away from being able to give a result. But I can assure Senator Coulter on behalf of the Minister, Mrs Kelly, that her commitment remains as firm as it ever was and so does that of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister's reply mean that the further progress in the ESD debate is dependent upon an agreement with the States? Can the Minister also indicate whether, for instance, as suggested by Dr Hamilton, the head of the RAC, there will not be a Government department or organisation committed to ESD?

—I am referring to the States as a very important element, but it is certainly not the only one. The working group reports make over 400 recommendations. That affects a lot of players in this game. It affects a number of industries and conservation groups in the way they see things as well as the public at large. The Prime Minister and the Premiers, though, have agreed to a process of a Commonwealth and a State working group to consider the outcomes of the reports. That is what I was referring to, and that is the right thing to do.
