PARA.TAB: Further, because there is such an enormous scope covered by these recommendations, such a wide diversity of issues that have been confronted in the course of those deliberations, it may well be that at a meeting of the major players in this game, which will be chaired by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet—I think the meeting occurs in February—there needs to be some process developed for an even wider public consultation process during the next few months or even the next year. So I am not by any means saying it is restricted to the States—it must be broader than that—although I do regard the process to be undertaken with the States as vitally important to the success of any ecologically sustainable development program.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Industrial Relations Legislation: New South Wales

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industrial Relations seen reports of criticisms by a former judge of the New South Wales Industrial Commission of provisions in the New South Wales industrial relations legislation restricting entry to workplaces by unions? Do these criticisms allege that these provisions are designed to buy time for employers `to cook the books or get the complaining employee'? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Federal Government intends to consider these New South Wales type provisions in any reforms it proposes to make to the Industrial Relations Act?

—Former judge James Macken—he has now resigned—of the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission is respected on all sides of the industrial relations fence in New South Wales and nationally as having an encyclopaedic knowledge of industrial relations. He commands wide respect and has the necessary experience to make commentary in a public way about the direction of industrial relations. The fact that he should come out and so openly attack the New South Wales Industrial Relations Act is in itself quite significant.

PARA.TAB: However, what he said ought to be listened to perhaps with a closer ear because of the significance of his words. He did say that the New South Wales Act will buy time for employers to enable them to cook the books or get rid of a complaining employee because of the statutory provision before a workplace can be inspected. He did say, `Voluntary unionism in this day and age is equivalent to compulsory non-unionism'. He also said that many employers would be hard hit if the Bill—that is now the New South Wales Act—succeeded in seriously diminishing union power because workers no longer represented by a single bargaining agent would split into warring groups. He also said that the legislation provided management with a work force in statutory chains and was unlikely to be able to challenge its status as a mere resource for managerial use.

The fact that such a sombre and serious criticism should be made by such a distinguished industrial relations figure cannot be dismissed, despite the fact that we have heard from Premier Greiner in just the last week the praise he has heaped on the Australian industrial relations system—praise that is related to the Hawke Government period of responsibility for overall outcomes in this country.

If one looks at the New South Wales record, one sees perhaps why someone as distinguished as James Macken would be concerned. The figures on industrial relations disputes, measured by working days lost per thousand employees, for the year to August 1991 show that New South Wales has more disputatious to the extent of being 51 per cent above the national average. If we compare the New South Wales performance to that of another manufacturing State, Victoria, we find that it is 24 per cent below the national average. The fact that there is that level of disputation in Australia is at the door of the conservative Liberal Government in New South Wales for mismanagement of industrial relations in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: quite clearly the answer which the Minister is now giving does not relate to his own portfolio; he is commenting on State legislation. Further, he has now come to the point where he is debating the point, because he could have answered the dorothy dixer posed by Senator Childs with a simple yes or no. You yourself have ruled that he may not develop arguments; he must simply give an answer which is relevant to his portfolio and not debate the question. I ask you to rule him out of order.

—In reply to Senator Bishop's point of order, I point out to Senator Cook that the last part of the question asked whether the Federal Government would implement the provisions, and I think he should make his remarks on that part of the question.
—Thank you, Mr President. I will take your suggestion and do that. One of the reasons why we will not go down the New South Wales or New Zealand road in industrial relations in this country—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Cook has just said that he will not debate the point, but he is doing so when he starts to make an argument to sustain his answer. The Standing Orders say very clearly that honourable senators shall not debate the question. I ask you, Mr President, to follow your precedents and rule him out of order.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I listened very carefully to this question, and the Minister was talking about his responsibilities as a Federal Minister within a Federal industrial relations system in which a significant number of the work force in Australia are under Federal awards and in which there is a general accord which applies to all workers in this country. The fact that at one stage the Minister criticised the appalling industrial relations record of the New South Wales Government compared with others is still in order. Under the Standing Orders he is entitled to do so. I put it to you, Mr President, that the second point of order raised by Senator Bishop ought to be thrown out in the way that the first one was.
—Order! I do not believe that the Minister was debating.

—Thank you, Mr President. I was, as you invited me to do, making some comments as to why the Commonwealth Government will not accept the New South Wales or New Zealand style of industrial relations. One of the clear and obvious reasons is that that style generates a level of industrial division, in this case 51 per cent above the national average. The other reason is that the basis of that industrial legislation is to promote division and conflict and to set Australians against Australians in the workplace. As acknowledged by Premier Greiner in his speech overseas, we have endeavoured to engender a sense of teamwork in the Australian workplace so that workers and employers can work together around a set of enterprise goals, which guarantees fair reward to profits and wages and generation of higher productivity on that basis.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We seem to have a difficulty, in that you upheld my first point of order, the Minister got up and flouted that point of order, and then you allowed Senator Aulich to debate it further. If you fail to uphold the point of order I called earlier, I suggest you look at standing order 196 on tedious repetition.
—Order! Senator Cook's answer has been a very long one, and the reason it has been extended is that there have been three long points of order. I think Senator Cook is concluding his answer.

—One of the ways in which New South Wales employees can escape the poor industrial relations record of the New South Wales Government is to obtain Federal award coverage. That is an option for them. To answer the last part of the question: no, we will not introduce a New South Wales or New Zealand form of industrial relations. We do not want to plunge this country into conflict and we do not want to set Australian against Australian. We want to work positively for the economic development of the community.

—I was somewhat perplexed by the long, rambling answer given by Senator Cook to the question about interest rates, exchange rates and inflation. Therefore, I ask the Minister representing the latest Treasurer a question on those matters. I refer the Minister to the blow-out in the Budget deficit to $6,863m in the four months to the end of October. I remind him that this is already 50 per cent greater than the forecast deficit for the whole year. Obviously, that has to be funded. How is that increased deficit to be funded? If the deficit is to be funded by increased sales of government bonds, what is the impact of that demand for funds on domestic interest rates and inflation? If it is to be funded by overseas borrowings, what will the impact be on the exchange rate and our foreign debt?

—The question is based on a false premise. The deficit outcome for the year to October simply cannot be extrapolated to estimate the outcome for the year as a whole. It is common for very considerable within-year variability in Commonwealth Government outlays and revenue to occur. The cumulative deficit of $6,863m for the year to October is higher than the expected deficit for the year as a whole, $4,732m, but that is due to variations in the pattern of outlays and revenue collections. The point that Senator Macdonald is making, or seeking to make, simply does not arise.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I hear what Senator Evans says, but the deficit has already grossly blown out. If the figure is something like that for the end of the year, could Senator Evans tell me how that increase will be funded? If it is to come from increased sales of bonds, what effect will it have on the domestic interest rate and inflation? If it is to be funded from overseas, what effect will it have on the exchange rate and foreign debt? It is an enormous blow-out, and I am asking Senator Evans what action the Government will take to fund that blow-out—if it is not that blow-out, the blow-out that is anticipated?
—The lights are out and nobody is home.

—I just pick up what Senator Ray so admirably said—`The lights are out and nobody is home' so far as Senator Macdonald is concerned. Senator Macdonald simply was not listening to the answer I gave. The answer is, as I described it, that there is no basis on which to extrapolate a deficit at this stage. Therefore, the points he asks me about simply do not arise.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In the light of continuing Australian and international concern to ensure greater transparency and restraint with regard to conventional arms transfers, can the Minister advise what progress has been made towards establishing a United Nations register of arms transfers? What practical steps will be taken to ensure the implementation of such a register?

—As I have indicated on several previous occasions, Australia has consistently called for the establishment of a universal and non-discriminatory register of conventional arms transfers under the auspices of the UN. I am pleased to inform the Senate that a resolution which establishes such a register was adopted in the First Committee of the United Nations on 15 November. Australia was a co-sponsor of that resolution, which was adopted by an overwhelming majority of 106 to one, with eight abstentions and only Cuba voting against. The eight countries abstaining were Burma, China, DPRK, Iraq, Oman, Pakistan, Singapore and Sudan. This resolution reflects the clear view of the world community that there is a need for greater transparency and, consequently, greater restraint with respect to arms transfers.

PARA.TAB: The resolution calls for member states to exercise due restraint in exports and imports of conventional arms; the establishment of a register to include data on international arms transfers; and the establishment of two groups of technical experts, one to report to next year's General Assembly on the procedures and input requirements of the register and one to be established in 1994 to prepare a report on the continuing operation of the register and its further developments, taking into account the interim work of the Conference on Disarmament. In this context, the resolution also requests the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva, of which Australia is one of 39 members, to address as soon as possible the question of excessive and destabilising accumulation of arms, including military holdings and procurement.

Australia does intend to contribute to and participate in this ongoing process, which, if implemented, will certainly assist in minimising the possibilities of excessive and destabilising arms transfers. This is not to suggest that arms should not be transferred to meet legitimate self-defence requirements, a point that Senator Robert Ray and I have often made. In terms of future action, Australia will, of course, contribute to the register. We will work actively in the Conference on Disarmament in support of its consideration of this issue, and we will make available Foreign Affairs and Defence personnel to participate, as appropriate, in the two expert studies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: following the sacking of Treasurer John Kerin and his replacement by Ralph Willis, why are the Government's top five Ministers and the majority—that is, 53 per cent—of members of the Hawke Cabinet all from the Victorian branch of the ALP, which makes up only 17 per cent of the Caucus, and which has crippled the Victorian economy and is now doing the same to Australia's economy? Why does the Keating dominated New South Wales Labor Party have only two seats in Cabinet and Queensland none at all, although together they make up half the Caucus in a Government described by Max Walsh in the Sydney Morning Herald today as being `tribalised in an unprecedented fashion'? When will this Government stop running this nation through backdoor deals that are aimed at propping up the Prime Minister's leadership instead of doing what is in the best interests of Australia?
—I hope my colleagues from New South Wales and elsewhere will forgive me if I offer the hesitant and halting explanation that in politics, as elsewhere, cream does rise to the top.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. A lot of things rise to the top—sour cream, slag and scum. I ask the Minister once again: why is it in Australia's best interests to have 53 per cent of the Cabinet from Victoria? If it is not in Australia's best interests, whose best interests are being served by this extraordinary situation where New South Wales and Queensland, which provide half the Caucus, provide only 12 per cent of the Cabinet?

—I am obliged to concede there are alternative explanations of how people get to the top—and Senator Baume has offered some that appeal to a number of my colleagues. But as to the alleged disproportion might I say that it is not just a matter of quantity, it is a matter of quality. I am sure Senator Richardson, among others, would willingly acknowledge the point that the nature of the contribution, the quality, the extent, the dynamism, the effectiveness and all round brilliance, in fact, of the contribution made by people from other States amply compensates for the quantitative shortfall which may be temporarily evident.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Can the Minister advise whether the three scenarios—A, B and C—in the Opposition's goods and services tax package, or value-added tax package, rely on the Hawke Government's micro-economic reform program in forecasting the creation of 1.6 million new jobs? If this is the case, can the Minister further advise whether the use of the micro-economic reform program is sufficient in itself to support the employment growth projections contained in the Opposition's document?
—This morning in the censure debate we had a repetition—
—What does it have to do with you?

—In response to that interjection, with the portfolios that I am personally responsible for plus the portfolios of the two Ministers I represent in this chamber, I am responsible for about 80 per cent of the micro-economic reform agenda. The Government will not be relying on the analysis that has been given by the Opposition in its Fightback document. The Opposition again this morning—and it is fraudulent and deceitful of the Opposition to do this—referred to the two million new jobs that are supposedly being created by its Fightback policy. I have here a copy of table A3 from the Opposition's document on employment and unemployment.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Unfortunately, Senator Collins did not get on the batting list earlier in the day, but there are appropriate times to debate and appropriate times to answer questions. He is now seeking—
—When you ambush us; that's the only time.

—If you want another debate at the end of Question Time, you can have one. The Standing Orders specifically prohibit debate during Question Time, Mr President, and I ask you to keep the Minister to the Standing Orders.
—Briefly on the point of order, Mr President, I am responsible for a micro-economic reform portfolio. I was asked whether the Government can rely on these figures and I am answering why we cannot.
—I think the question was in order. I must say I was worried about it to start with, but it did mention the micro-economic policies of the Government and I would ask the Minister to comment on that.

—I am doing so directly. The three scenarios that are offered, A, B and C, rely entirely—and this is where the deceit comes in—on micro-economic reform and on the projections that are drawn from micro-economic reform. They rely not on the Opposition's policy, which this document does not analyse, but on reports from the Industry Commission as to productivity that is going to be delivered by micro-economic reform only. Let me correct one thing: even the Opposition's document scenario C, which is the high road maximum figure scenario, points to the creation of only 1.527 million jobs—I guess it is just as easy to tack on another 500,000; it is as substantial as everything else contained in this document. But the important thing to point out is this: this is not an analysis of the Opposition's policy. It is an analysis by Access Economics of reports from the Industry Commission which does not contain the factor of the impact of a goods and services tax on employment—and it is about time this was corrected.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I would like to quote you on 19 February 1987 when you said with regard to a point of order that clearly `the majority of the question did refer to Opposition policies' and that you would `allow it on the basis that the Minister answers only that part of the question that dealt with her portfolio and the Government's policy'—not Opposition policy, but Government policy. We know the Government has a void, but the Minister can try.

—Order! The Minister is answering the question he was asked and micro-economic policies are within his portfolio. Can I say, Senator Bishop, that I have taken out a review of the points of order that have been made over the last two or three months, and in practically every case the rulings I have given have been correct.

—The reason the Government cannot rely on this analysis in terms of the impact of a GST is that Access Economics has simply lifted the labour productivity estimates from Industry Commission reports and put those Industry Commission report estimates into the Murphy econometric model it has used for this analysis. I say again: it is a pretty substantial piece of deceit for the Opposition to peddle this analysis as an analysis of the Opposition's GST package when it is nothing of the sort. It does not contain any analysis whatever that factors in the imposition of a consumption tax on employment. The extent of this deceit cannot be overstated.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You ruled that the question was in order because it made mention of micro-economic reform. That is irrelevant—

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just listen for a minute. Why don't you shut them up?
—Order!

—Mr President, you said the question was in order because it made mention of micro-economic reforms. That is not relevant to whether or not the answer is within the Standing Orders. He is not permitted under the Standing Orders to be debating Opposition policy under any guise. I draw that standing order to your attention again, Mr President, and ask that you enforce it.

—Order! As I have said many times, it is difficult to work out when an answer is becoming a debate. This has been a long answer, but again it has been interrupted consistently with points of order. But, Senator Collins, I think you should reasonably conclude the answer.

—Mr President, I will conclude the answer, but I have only been able to get about two sentences out without being interrupted. The question needs to be asked—and I hope someone will ask it—why did Access Economics not factor in the impact of a consumption tax on these very important projections on employment growth on which this package rests? The organisation consists of professional economists—very good ones, and I concede that. I can only assume the reason Access Economics did not factor it in is that it was not asked to do so by the Opposition. If that is the case—and someone should ask Access Economics—why was it not asked?

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, everybody knows that a consumption tax is a tax on employment. Everyone knows that every time Australians put their hands in their pockets under a coalition Government, they will find Dr Hewson's hand already there. I would like Opposition senators, if no-one else can answer the question, to answer: why are they portraying this document as an analysis of their policy, which it is not, when in fact it is an analysis of Industry Commission reports?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to Terry Shanahan, the President of the New South Wales Labor Party, and his statement that `the Party can ill-afford to go to the next election with the dual folly of having one of our most potent batsmen sitting in the grandstand, but also some of the middle order merely serving out their pre-retirement notice'. Does he agree Mr Keating should be returned to the Cabinet? As Senator Button has now announced that he will not be contesting the next election, does the Prime Minister intend to push Senator Button off the ministerial sleigh to appease the hungry organisation and the union wing of the party who are baying for more ministerial blood; or does the Prime Minister intend to allow Senator Button to drift into an easy retirement because he was instrumental in providing Mr Hawke with the numbers in his elevation to the prime ministership?
—The question was about a Mr Shanahan who does not exist, and the answer is: none of Senator Boswell's business.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, and it is about his possible contribution to preventative medicine—something I have not seen emphasised in the `Flightback' package. I ask Senator Collins: are airport terminals considered to be public buildings? If so, when will the policy of not permitting smoking in public buildings be implemented; and, if not, will the Minister encourage airlines to recognise their obligation to provide travellers and workers with a safe and healthy travel and working environment?
—Your guess is as good as mine.

—No, my guess would be a lot better than Senator Walters's. The answer is that the FAC is not in a position, legally, to implement a policy such as that which Senator Bell suggests—although the FAC and I will acknowledge that the public pressure on it to do so is growing in leaps and bounds with every passing day. The terminals are in fact legally operated by the lessees of the FAC—that is, the airlines. I have to say, with respect, that, as an asthmatic, as far as I am concerned one of the best things that this Government has done in recent times—and every flight attendant in Australia would agree with me—has been to ban smoking on flights. A great many smokers that I know also agree with that. But I do think there is a difference between pumping air around inside the very confined space of a small cylinder of aluminium at 35,000 feet and in an airport terminal where, unlike on an aircraft, people do have the opportunity of getting away from the smoke if it annoys them.

PARA.TAB: The policy that has been adopted by the FAC—I think sensibly—is to encourage the use of designated non-smoking and smoking areas. It will continue to respond to the most effective pressure of all in this respect: pressure from the paying customers as to what they want. I think it is fair to say—and I am sure the FAC would confirm this—that the pressure, in terms of emphasis, has now shifted from designated non-smoking areas to designated smoking areas which will become increasingly smaller as time goes by.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer him to a speech by the Prime Minister, wherein he said:

QUESTION.PARA: One in 10 Australians out of work—a figure no Australian would have believed possible a few years ago and which no Australian government should ever be forgiven for creating.
Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister's sentiments, and when will the Prime Minister resign?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all deeply conscious of the unacceptability of the present levels of unemployment and the Prime Minister is the first to acknowledge that, the first to make that point and the first to concede that it is something which we must continue to work desperately hard to ensure does not become an entrenched and permanent feature of the Australian landscape. We believe our policies are such as to ensure that that will not happen. We do believe that when any improvement in the employment situation does occur it has to be sustainable and durable. There is no point whatsoever in creating an artificial bubble which will burst and make the situation worse. That is the problem with most of the pump priming solutions that are urged upon us.

PARA.TAB: There is no surprise, in one sense, about the current level of unemployment exceeding the 10 per cent mark because it will be recalled that in the Budget in August it was stated that a peak of up to 10.75 per cent might well be achieved this financial year. We all hope very much that that will not be the case, but we have to work on the basis that it just conceivably might be. It needs to be appreciated, of course, that this is occurring still against a background of participation rates which are higher than has ever been the case historically. As such, a 10 per cent unemployment figure in the present environment—with a participation rate of around 63 per cent—is not having quite the draconian impact that the Opposition's own recession had in 1982-83, with a 10.3 per cent unemployment rate in a situation where the participation rate was only 60.3 per cent.

These are things which do matter in terms of the degree, extent, nature and duration of the hardship that is being suffered. The Prime Minister, and all of us in the Government, are acutely conscious—there is no higher priority on our policy agenda—of trying to do something to get over this particular problem but to do it in a way which will produce durable and sustainable results, not artificial and short term ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the question again, in part. The Prime Minister said, `One in 10 unemployed in Australia —a figure no government should be forgiven for creating'. Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister's sentiment?
—The honourable senator can ask the question again, but he will get exactly the same answer.
—I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: what is the Government's policy towards recognition of the Ukraine?

—As the Prime Minister's publicly released message on the weekend made clear, Australia is `sympathetically examining Ukraine's request for recognition'. There is no question but that the 1 December referendum did constitute a decisive and unequivocal expression of the will for independence on the part of the Ukrainian people, and that Ukraine is now entering a new era in its history.

PARA.TAB: In a great many ways, the course of that history has now been set. The recognition of Ukraine by the great bulk of the international community does seem inevitable. We in the Australian Government certainly see our own recognition of Ukraine, within a comparatively short time, as inevitable. Our only concern at the moment is with the timing of that act of recognition, which will depend on how a number of presently unresolved issues are addressed.

I indicated in my own statement of 3 December that a number of issues do remain relevant to our, and the international community's, consideration of the recognition issue and the associated one of the establishment of diplomatic relations—namely: the issue of security and central control of nuclear weapons, given Ukraine's stated commitment to become a non-nuclear state; the issue of acceptance and compliance with existing Soviet arms control commitments; the issue of commitment to internationally accepted human rights arrangements governing the standards for observance of human rights and to protect, in particular, minority rights; and the issue of arrangements for meeting the Soviet Union's international obligations, particularly Ukraine's share of the Soviet Union's debt. These are all issues that are being discussed right now by Ukraine's Government with its neighbouring republics and with what remains of the central Soviet Union Government.

We ourselves are engaged in consultation with the Ukraine Government on how it proposes to address these issues. It is quite likely that these issues will be resolved satisfactorily within quite a short space of time—whether by retaining the present centre as a confederal state in its own right, or perhaps by its translation into a looser form of coordinating machinery like the EC, or by some other means, remains to be seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. —To conclude, might I just say this: Australia fully acknowledges the process of transformation which is at work, and the reality of the independence aspirations, and achievements, of the Ukraine people. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

Two weeks ago, in Tokyo, Mr Greiner, the New South Wales Liberal Premier, said:

ANSWER.PARA: We have a regime of change in Australia that is streamlining the market place through deregulation, tax and tariff reforms and fundamental reforms to our air, shipping, road, rail and communication industries. Nick Greiner said that a productivity revolution is occurring as a result. Moreover, he went on to say:
When it comes to wages, strikes, inflation and economic growth, Australia suffers from miscast perceptions and unfair stereotyping.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROCEEDINGS ON POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES LEGISLATION

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the undertakings I gave during debate on 5 December 1991, I considered various matters raised during the proceedings on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill and I have had a statement prepared in relation to these matters. The statement deals with the various matters raised in some detail. I suggest that senators should take time to consider this statement before seeking to respond to it. I have also reiterated the undertaking which I gave on 5 December to refer the various questions to the Procedure Committee. I therefore suggest that the statement be incorporated in Hansard so that senators may have the opportunity of further considering it. I did contact the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Australian Democrats about that procedure.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: On Thursday, 5 December 1991 I undertook to consider matters which were raised by Senators during the proceedings on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. The Deputy-President and Chairman of Committees, Senator Colston, also undertook to consider one of those questions. I have considered those matters and now make a statement to the Senate. This statement covers the question raised with Senator Colston, and he concurs with the statement.
There were three major matters which were raised during the discussion on the bill:

.the ruling of the Chairman of Committees, which I upheld as being in accordance with a ruling which I made on 3 December 1991, to the effect that a contingent notice of motion to seek to overcome the limitations imposed on debate on an urgent bill may be used only once

.my ruling that, when the Chairman of Committees has reported to the President that a ruling by the Chairman has been objected to, the President is then required to rule on the correctness of the Chairman's ruling
.the raising of points of order by Senators during the proceedings.
Before proceeding to discuss these matters, I should make some observations on the significance of the limitation of debate on urgent bills under standing order 142.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Limitation of Debate on Urgent Bills

INTERJECT.PARA: Standing order 142 provides for the Senate to declare that a bill is an urgent bill, that debate on the bill should be limited, and that the Senate's decision on the bill should be taken within a limited time. When orders under this standing order have been made, the Senate has decided that a bill must be dealt with by a particular time, whether a specified time or after the expiration of a quantum of time. The standing order is expressed to operate "notwithstanding anything contained in any other standing or other order". It requires the Chair, at the expiration of the prescribed time, to bring the proceedings on the urgent bill to a conclusion by putting the questions requisite to dispose of the bill. While orders under the standing order are in operation, therefore, the Chair is under an obligation to ensure that the order of the Senate is complied with, and that the decision of the Senate is not defeated and the proceedings on the bill delayed. Any rulings by the Chair must be consistent as far as possible with the Senate's determination that the urgent bill must be dealt with within the prescribed time.
In that context I will now proceed to consider the matters which were raised.

Senator Hill and other Senators have on the Notice Paper 4 types of contingent notices of motion to allow them to move for the suspension of standing orders to seek to overcome the limitations imposed by the operation of standing order 142. The contingent notices provide for motions to be moved:
.to allow debate to take place on a declaration of urgency
.to avoid the limitation of debate on a motion for the allotment of time
.to extend the time available to consider the urgent bill
.to allow amendments circulated other than by the government to be put at the expiration of the time allowed.

Since these contingent notices were first employed in 1986, when a motion has been moved pursuant to a contingent notice, debate has been allowed on the motion to suspend standing orders for the time allowed for such motions, even where, under standing order 142, no debate is allowed or the time for debate has expired. This interpretation was followed on this occasion; for example, Senator Hill was allowed to move a suspension motion pursuant to a contingent notice when the time for proceedings on the bill had expired, and debate was allowed on that motion. This interpretation is very liberal as regards the rights of Senators. It would be open to the Chair to adopt an alternative and stricter interpretation, namely, that when the time for debate has expired no further motions may be moved and no further debate may take place, and the question before the Chair must be put forthwith. The interpretation which has been followed is in accordance with the traditional liberality of the Senate and represents a significant right on the part of individual Senators to seek to have the Senate change its mind and allow more time for debate.

Leaving aside the question of whether such a motion should be allowed to be moved, and regardless of whether debate should be allowed on such a motion, it is clear that the Chair can allow only one such motion to be moved at the stage of the proceedings referred to in the notice. If this were not so, Senators could, by moving successive motions to suspend standing orders, defeat the limitation of time and frustrate the order of the Senate that a bill must be dealt with. The Chair could not allow such a procedure to defeat the express determination of the Senate.

The ruling which I made on 3 December 1991 may be summarised as follows. Senator Hill had a contingent notice of motion to move suspension of standing orders to remove the time limit on debate on the motion for the allotment of time. It had been assumed in the past that the time allowed for debate on the suspension motion would not be part of the time allowed for debate on the motion for the allotment of time. That assumption had been followed on this occasion. This raised the possibility, however, of an endless series of motions for the suspension of standing orders endlessly extending the time for debate on the motion for the allotment of time. The proper construction of the contingent motion is that it allows only one motion to be moved to suspend standing orders to extend the time allowed for debate on the motion for the allotment of time. Any further motion for suspension of standing orders is moved without notice and the time allowed for it must be part of the time allowed for the motion to allot time. At the expiration of the time allowed for that motion, therefore, I was obliged to put the question on all motions and amendments then before the Senate.

In the ruling as recorded in Hansard, I stated that once Senator Hill had moved for the suspension of standing orders he could not move a similar motion again. As I made clear on 5 December, however, a similar motion may not be moved again by any Senator.

When the suspension motion was moved for the second time on 3 December, I allowed the motion to be moved and to be put to a vote, on the basis that the time for debate on the allotment of time had not then expired, but did not allow debate on it when the time for debate had expired. When, on 5 December, Senator Hill sought to move a suspension motion for a second time, the time for debate had already expired, and the Chairman of Committees ruled that the motion was not in order in that the relevant contingent notice allowed the motion to be moved only once. The two rulings were based on the same principle: that the relevant contingent notice allows only one such motion to be moved, and any further motion is not pursuant to the contingent notice. I treated the second suspension motion moved on 3 December as being moved without notice and put it without debate; the Chairman ruled that the second suspension motion moved on 5 December was out of order because it was not in accordance with the contingent notice pursuant to which it was purportedly moved.

The fundamental point underlying the rulings is that it must be the case that only one attempt can be made to seek the agreement of the Senate to extend the time available, and once the Senate has rejected such a request, the attempt cannot be made again. Each contingent notice, and any notice essentially the same, may therefore be used only once for each occurrence of the contingency for which it is intended. To rule otherwise would be to allow the proceedings to defeat the determination of the Senate that the urgent bill must be dealt with within the limited time.
This approach is supported by the "same question rule", which is contained in standing order 86:

.A question shall not be proposed if it is the same in substance as any question which has been determined during the same session, unless the order, resolution, or vote on such question was determined more than six months previously or has been rescinded.

This rule is seldom invoked and is interpreted very liberally in relation to the normal proceedings of the Senate. Where the Senate is considering a bill declared to be urgent, however, the rule should be applied more strictly to prevent successive attempts to try to get the Senate to change its mind in relation to the limitation of time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Ruling by the President on the Chairman's Ruling

INTERJECT.PARA: Standing order 145 provides:

.If objection is taken to a decision of the Chairman of Committees, such objection must be stated at once in writing. The Chairman shall then leave the Chair, and the Senate resume. The matter having been laid before the President, and Senators having addressed themselves to it, shall be disposed of, and the proceedings in committee shall be resumed where they were interrupted.

The reference in the standing order to the matter being disposed of means disposed of by a ruling of the President, which can then be objected to under standing order 198. In other words, the President rules on the correctness of the Chairman's ruling. This interpretation has always been followed since the standing orders were adopted in 1903. The procedure is described in Odgers' Australian Senate Practice as follows:
.When the President has taken the Chair of the Senate, the Chairman reports the dissent. . . . .

.It is the practice of the Senate, when a decision of the Chairman of Committees is objected to, to permit Senators to address themselves to the Question before the President gives a decision. The debate on an objection to a decision of the Chairman cannot be adjourned.

.After hearing the views of Senators, the President must give his decision. Unless objection is taken to that decision, it is binding, and the Committee resumes its work. But if objection is taken to the decision of the President, the debate upon his ruling is automatically adjourned till the next day of sitting, unless the Senate decides that the matter is one requiring immediate determination. In the meantime, the ruling of the President has to be accepted.

This procedure has been followed with every objection to a Chairman's ruling. In recent years objections to rulings of the Chair have been extremely rare, but they were much more frequent in former years.

The standing order and the description of the practice in Odgers refer to the President hearing argument before ruling on the Chairman's decision. It is always open to the President, however, to determine the matter at once without hearing any debate. It may be argued that the President is under an obligation to do so when there is an order of the Senate that a bill must be dealt with within a limited time.
The question was raised whether the Chair is obliged to hear points of order raised by Senators when the time for proceedings on an urgent bill has expired.

The same consideration applies to points of order as to suspension motions. It must be within the discretion of the Chair to decline to hear any further points of order and to put the questions for determining the proceedings on the urgent bill. If this were not so, it would be open to individual Senators to raise successive points of order and by that means to defeat the determination by the Senate that an urgent bill must be dealt with.

The Chair has an obligation at all times to preserve the rights of Senators and to ensure that the procedures of the Senate are properly applied, if necessary with the assistance of Senators by way of points of order. But the Chair also has an obligation to ensure that the decisions of the majority of the Senate are carried out and are not frustrated. As I have indicated, when the Senate has made a determination that an urgent bill must be dealt with within a limited time, the Chair has a particular obligation to ensure that that determination is not subverted.

In this connection it should be pointed out that proceedings in the bill in question were extended for almost 3 hours beyond the time specified by the Senate, due to the suspension motions, the motion of dissent and points of order.

At Question Time on 5 December Senator McKiernan asked me a question about the numbers of points of order raised, and I promised to get out some figures. I table statistics relating to points of order raised during the last four periods of sittings.
During the discussion on 5 December I indicated that I would refer these matters to the Procedure Committee for consideration, and I again indicate that I will do so.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Addendum to the Statement by Mr President

INTERJECT.PARA: I also undertook during the debate on 5 December 1991 to respond to an objection by Senator Teague to words used by Senator Evans, who referred to the Senate as a "relatively useless institution".

I did not hear this expression at the time. It may be regarded as contrary to standing order 193(3), which provides that a Senator "shall not use offensive words against either House of Parliament". I think, however, that I would require something rather stronger than that to invoke the standing order and require a withdrawal. Offensive language must be judged by the sensitivities of the time. I do not think that we are now so sensitive that we would regard Senator Evans' words as requiring action by the Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I did anticipate this matter would come on earlier in the day and I therefore thought it was reasonable that colleagues should have an opportunity to read it and consider it. That is still my view, and I am happy to debate it in detail after the suspension of the sitting for dinner tonight.

PARA.TAB: Briefly, whilst there is much in the statement with which I agree, with respect, I think it is in error in at least two parts. We have to address that because, on reading Odgers' Australian Senate Practice I see that one of your predecessors once ruled that, if the President makes a ruling and it is not then disputed, it achieves the status of a standing order. I find somewhat incredible Presidents giving themselves that stature; nevertheless it means that if we disagree with it we have no alternative but to dissent, otherwise it attracts this particular stature.

I give you notice that the two areas I disagree with at the moment are: firstly, the ruling by the President on the Chairman's ruling. Paraphrasing what you say: because there was a guillotine, you argued that part of standing order 145 which says that senators shall be heard on the issue—to quote the standing order correctly `Senators having addressed themselves to it'—is overridden by the guillotine.

The problem is that it seems to me that the guillotine had concluded and that the Senate was proceeding under the standing order which then provides for a voting procedure. There is nothing that I can find in the Standing Orders that indicates the voting procedure should be dealt with in any other way than any other business under the terms of the standing order. It therefore seems to me that the ruling you have made on that issue is incorrect.

Mr President, the other issue which seems to me to be incorrect is your ruling in relation to points of order. You argue in that instance similarly that, notwithstanding standing order 197(2), which specifically states that a senator has a right to raise a point of order at any time, that may also have been overridden by the guillotine. Again I put to you that, at the time these votes were being taken, the guillotine was not in application.

There may be an interesting argument as to how something under the guillotine stands in relation to other provisions of the Standing Orders, but it does not seem to be the issue that you were asked specifically to direct your attention to; in other words, the issue that particularly arose during the debate the other day.

The issue, as it arose the other day, concerned disputes when the Chairman of Committees and you refused to take points of order. It now seems, according to this considered set of reasons, that that was because the matter was under a guillotine and, therefore, inappropriate. We argue that that is wrong. Firstly, the matter was not under a guillotine and, secondly, you were obliged under the Standing Orders to take the points of order as raised and, therefore, with respect, in our opinion the determination that you have made is incorrect.

Mr President, I give you notice that later in this debate I will be moving dissent on both of those two issues. I do not know whether any of my colleagues want to contribute anything to the consideration before the Senate at the moment. But, at the end of whatever they wish to contribute, I will ask that the matter be adjourned until later tonight in order that all of my colleagues have an opportunity to consider the opinion that you have put before the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words about this matter. —Order! In reply to one of the points raised by Senator Michael Baume, Senator Teague has just brought to my notice the fact that an addendum to my statement has been circulated and you should have a copy of it by now.

—You will receive it.

—Mr President, there are two distinct elements to your statement. PARA.TAB: I say in passing that Senator McMullan might have got some cooperation from this side of the chamber had he not so despicably doublecrossed us with half-smart tactics last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I understand what the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) is saying when he talks about the program for the day. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I do agree with the point that Senator Hill accepted—that we will be able to address this matter when we have looked very thoroughly at the statement you have made and the addendum that has been circulated only in the last few minutes. I received this addendum directly from you—and I thank you—about a quarter of an hour ago. I just want to put on the record immediately that I am disappointed that you have found:

SPEECH.PARA: I did not hear this expression at the time. It may be regarded as contrary to standing order 193(3), which provides that a Senator "shall not use offensive words against either House of Parliament". I think, however, that I would require something rather stronger than that to invoke the standing order and require a withdrawal. Offensive language must be judged by the sensitivities of the time. I do not think that we are now so sensitive that we would regard Senator Evans' words as requiring action by the Chair.

I, for one, believe that it is offensive. I acknowledge your power to give a ruling. I do not question the conscientiousness of your statement, but I am still offended by the reflection of Senator Gareth Evans, in particular in these two contexts: one was the vehemence and emotional immaturity with which Senator Evans made the remark at the time and how it was received. I noticed that Senator Vanstone immediately sought the call to take a point of order and was told by you to sit down. Later, Senator O'Chee brought this matter to the attention of the Chair. Only when you had eventually returned to the chair was I able to make a point of order, which you heard and took on notice, as it were, to give this response.

PARA.TAB: The second reason I think it is still offensive is the track record of Senator Evans in particular, more than any other senator, on derogatory descriptions of this chamber. I just want the Senate to note that I am disappointed in your statement. I believe that the statement is still offensive. You have ruled that it is not to be taken as a precedent for being contrary to standing order 193(3), but I give notice that if any other honourable senator were to use this phrase, or if Senator Evans were to repeat the phrase, I will be one senator who will again immediately take a point of order under standing order 193(3).

—Perhaps another reason why people should go away and discuss the matter—all I have done is explain what happened and explain earlier rulings—is that I do not think there is anything before the Chair to dissent from at the moment. That is something else we could probably discuss during the suspension of the sitting.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:
Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

TAB.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Campbell (from 38 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Fee Relief Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the two-tiered child care fee relief scheme to be introduced by the Federal Government from 1 January 1992 will discriminate against families needing child care for "non-work related" reasons.
That fees for these families will rise to such an extent that thousands of parents will not be able to afford access to child care services.

That as a result the viability of many child care centres and services will be significantly affected causing increases in fees for families who need access to child care services for "work related" reasons.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Senate should disallow the Federal Government's new two tiered child care fee relief scheme.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2)The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3)These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petitioning letter which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders from six petitioners requesting that the National Measurements (Standard Time) Amendment Bill 1991 be rejected:

PARA.TAB: 109 Leamington Street
Nth. Rockhampton, 4701
6th August, 1991

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Flo. Bjelke-Petersen
House of Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA
Dear Senator,

As a representative of the undersigned, we do request and urge you, as our representative in the Senate, to do all in your power, to ensure that the proposed Bill, giving the Federal Parliament jurisdiction in determining the date and times of operation together with the ending of a period known as "Daylight Saving" be rejected and not permitted to become Law.
The grounds on which we base this request are:

PARA.TAB: 1.We submit that the determining of this matter, is a concern of the State and has no place in it for the interference of the Commonwealth Parliament.
2.The conditions that apply in Queensland, especially in the Tropical Zone, cause undue hardship and discomfort to the people residing here in the following respects:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)The early rising times cause discomfort by reason of lack of sufficient sleep, since the retiring time does not alter effectively, because of the continuing heat presence at the evening delays the ability to sleep.
(b)The setting of the sun, in the evening during mid-summer is 7 p.m. E.S.T. (8 p.m. D/S time) which means that, for the dwelling, cooling does not take effect until late in the night.

PARA.TAB: (c)The late time of the sun's setting, means that the evening meal is taken during a hot period of the day and, further that, should advantage of the daylight hours be taken (as said in the "for" case), the news broadcasts on radio and TV are missed, because it is impossible to do work and hear or see the programme.

(d)With the early rising, this constitutes a long day since, if one is to take advantage(?) of this bonus time, it means that one has to work longer hours to fill in the time; the alternative is to boil while sitting at the table supposedly enjoying a meal.

(e)For work to be done inside the home without air-conditioning, means that the perspiration saturates any paperwork; in the tropics, the humidity is such that fans do not have an effective result and often, when the day is hot, the air is likewise very still, so a breeze is not available, to help with the cooling of the body or the home.

(f)If study is to be undertaken under the above conditions, it is not only difficult to carry out the work, but it is difficult to concentrate while the body is uncomfortable, so that the work suffers.
(g)To overcome this problem, it is necessary to study into the night, which reduces the hours left for sleep, particularly so with the early hour of rising.

(h)The ability of the body to resist infection or disease is reduced, because the denial of normal rest time and, since the coolest hours of the night are in that period when the sun is about to rise; that important period is denied, because of the requirement to wake up from the period of soundest sleep, to comply with the requirement of a Law, which is brought about to appease some vested interests.

(i)In the tropics, the medical profession, backed by the Government, is urging people to stay out of the sun during the heat of the day, but the proposed Law will mean that that urging on the part of the Government is wasted and with that waste, comes the added risk of persons being afflicted with sun spots and cancers.

(j)The disruption of the normal daily routine of the whole State, is unnecessary, because the travel times for trains, `planes, coaches etc. can be easily adjusted to accommodate that set by interstate requirements; with the availability of recording technology, it should not be insurmountable to carry out the broadcasts to Qld. people to suit their times; it is done frequently, when it suits the broadcaster, to record programmes and play them later, because the times clash with established routine programming, or for some other reason, as it suits them.

(k)With a Government sited in Canberra, the greater part of the population of the country being near to that City's latitude, the lesser populated areas are going to be given Cavalier treatment, when it means their comfort and health compared to the populations near the seat of Government—another reason why we want the decision to remain with the State Government, who will stand or fall, on the wishes of the people affected, in this matter; if Canberra is saturated with politicians, who have no sympathy for the people in Queensland, this State will suffer for its inclusion in the Commonwealth—one of the reasons that the Senate was created being, that lesser populated States would have equal voice with the more populated States.

SPEECH.PARA: We respectfully submit this petition, confident that you will do your utmost to represent these wishes to the House of Senate and to which we append our signatures.
