TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a statement in response to the question asked by Senator Hill just before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. I understand that Dr Hewson and Mr Fife, the Manager of Opposition Business in the House of Representatives, and any members who have inquired, have been advised that the days of 18, 19 and 20 December have been set aside for possible House of Representatives sittings and to keep those days aside. The final determination has not been made by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). It will be made very shortly and a letter will be sent out. Attempts have been made to advise members that those are the days which they should keep available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: The arrangements seem to be very different from what we were told last week, upon which certain arrangements were made for this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was too late to change them.

—It was all too late to change. We were talking about finishing business at the end of this week. The Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan) will remember that the message he brought to us was that Mr Beazley, who is in charge of Government business in the House of Representatives, said it was too late to meet that requirement; the days of 18 and 19 December were required for the House of Representatives to return and we would therefore be required to sit the same days. It seems today that no decision has been made at the House of Representatives end of the building at all, simply that members have been told to mark the days in case they are required to return.
—That is not what I said.
—That's what you said a minute ago.
—I do not know how I could have misunderstood the statement that was made only a minute ago. That is exactly what the Manager of Government Business said.
—Would you like me to say it again?

—Perhaps the Manager should. When he clarifies that, I would like to know the plans in relation to this chamber. If the House of Representatives is not recalled, whenever that decision is made, are we expected to return for those two days at the end of next week and what business does the Government intend us to be transacting?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There is no question but that the House of Representatives will sit next week. There is doubt as to which of those days—18, 19 and 20 December—it will sit, or whether it will sit on all of those days.
—The 20th is a new day.
—I am not the slightest bit happy about the possibility of sitting on the 20th.
—You have just mentioned it for the first time.

—If Senator Walters would keep quiet for a second and stop interrupting so that I can speak and tell her something, she might actually learn something. One never learns by speaking; one only sometimes learns by listening.
—You have made your statement.

—I thought the statement I made was quite clear. In my view it is entirely unnecessary to contemplate sitting on 20 December for any procedural requirement that I can see. The Leader of the House, Mr Beazley, advises me that he has given that advice to Dr Hewson and Mr Fife, so I am telling honourable senators that. If he asks me whether I think it is necessary, I will say no. Honourable senators would not want me to not tell them that he had given that piece of advice. That is something of which I am now aware and I am telling the Senate. It is not a secret.

PARA.TAB: In my view, it is not necessary for the House of Representatives or the Senate to sit on 20 December. If we work in a reasonably orderly manner, the agreement which we reached last week is quite easily achievable—that is, we can finish the required work in the sitting days that we indicated last week, being four days this week and two days next week. I am in no doubt that with reasonable cooperation that remains achievable. But if that cooperation is not forthcoming, more days may be required.

So I cannot give a categoric indication of what the sitting of the Senate will be. As long as cooperation continues, I will implement what I thought was an agreement with the Opposition to pass the Government's legislative program in the six sitting days set down. In my view, this is perfectly easily achievable. It would include passing some legislation on the 18th and 19th and also dealing with some matters returned to us from the House of Representatives on those days. Obviously, there will be some Bills returned but, of course, it is impossible to predict at this stage what that legislation will be.

It is always the case at the end of sittings that legislation that has been amended in the Senate passes between the two Houses and requires consideration by each House. Therefore, both Houses need to sit on the same days. So it is perfectly easily achievable, with the bare modicum of cooperation, that we can pass the necessary legislation and deal with any disagreements between the Houses in six sitting days, including today.

That is my current intention and it is consistent with the indication given by the Leader of the House. He is being understandably abundantly cautious in saying, `Well, we may need the 20th'. In my view, it will not be required. I believe that the Senate can, with the bare minimum of cooperation, maintain that legislative program. I am happy to talk again to the Opposition about that matter at any time it wants to have a discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that there is no prospect of the House of Representatives coming back this week. Do I also take it that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) is indicating that it will be necessary for the House of Representatives to sit for at least two days and possibly a third?
—Not necessarily.
—Has it been decided that the House of Representatives will sit next week? Is it only a matter of how many days it will sit?
—Yes, it has. I have said that twice.
—No. I think the honourable senator just talked about three possible dates.
—If there is any doubt, it would have to be an explicit yes, it is certain the House of Representatives will sit next week, and it will be one or more of those days.

—Could Senator McMullan also give us an indication of the extent to which legislation is required to be passed by both Houses in order to take effect prior to the resumption of the Parliament in late February next year, and the extent to which the Government believes it is likely to be necessary for legislation to be further amended by the House of Representatives and brought back to the Senate?

—The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) has concentrated tonight on the mere modicum of cooperation that has come from the Opposition. We have done nothing but cooperate with the Government. Indeed, we were promised that we could get up on 13 December as long as we passed certain legislation. A short time after we agreed to that and were bending over backwards and cooperating fully with the Government, the Government and the Manager of Government Business in the Senate in particular, broke their promise and included the ad bans legislation in the list, although it had never been part of the original agreement.
—That is not true.

—I can only take the Whip's word for this and she assures us that agreements were broken. The Manager of Government Business agreed that our Whip was always very fair and he said that at the time she must have misunderstood.
—That makes two of us.

— Senator Knowles says that makes two of them. They both must have misunderstood. The very clear fact is that as soon as the Opposition is prepared to cooperate with the Government, the Government breaks its promise and lets us down.

PARA.TAB: Last week a gag was put on a Bill that was of vital importance. We had declared from the very beginning that it was the most important Bill ever to come before the Senate. It was a Bill that banned freedom of speech and freedom of the media, the like of which we have never seen in this country before. The Government, breaking its promise, gagged the Bill and then complained bitterly when we chose to take all those hours that we needed to debate it by sitting through the night.

The Government had to withdraw the gag, because of its dreadful drafting, so that amendments could be made to the Bill. The Government was incapable of putting forward a Bill that did not ignore the various situations in various States. The Government had to drop the gag of its own volition and take away the Bill to amend it, not once, but twice. The Government's behaviour was utterly disgraceful.

The Manager of Government Business in the Senate says, `We can get through on the 18th, 19th and 20th so long as we cooperate'. Well, I am telling the Manager of Government Business that there will be no cooperation by the Opposition from now on because we cannot rely on his word. We cannot rely on his promises and we cannot rely on any of his offers. He stood in this place during the debate on procedural motions and agreed with Senator Ray and the Opposition that the Chairman had not made the correct decision, and said that he agreed with us and would vote with us.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I didn't.

—He said that section 145 of the Standing Orders could be agreed to. He agreed that the Senate should debate the procedural motion but, before anyone on this side of the chamber had a chance to say a word, he gagged it. That is how much faith we can place in his promises and his indications to us, and he will get no cooperation at all from us. If those opposite want to sit through until President Bush comes then, okay, let us do it. We do not care. We would like to have Bob Hawke up here. We would like a few Caucus meetings. I do not think Bob wants them. We would like a few Caucus meetings held because then those opposite might come to their senses and decide that getting rid of him is the best of all evils.

PARA.TAB: The Government is in crisis. It is an appalling situation when the country is being run by a group of so-called Ministers fighting over how long they can keep their Prime Minister and, meanwhile, more than one million people are unemployed and in the dole queues. All those opposite can argue about is whether Mr Keating might be better able to use vitriolic phrases against our GST package than the Prime Minister.

The Prime Minister sacked his Treasurer because the Prime Minister could not find any holes in the package. Because there is nothing to attack, he shoots the messenger. It is not the Minister's fault he cannot find holes in it; it is not the Treasurer's fault that it is watertight. Now we have another Treasurer, the second string. The cartoon in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald showing the Prime Minister poking his head out of a Treasury office and saying `Next!' is a delight because it shows up better than any words could the shambles the Government is in. Senator McMullan should not come in here and ask us for cooperation. When he decides that he will behave decently in this place there might be some cooperation from the Opposition. Until he decides to behave decently he should not ask us to cooperate because we do not trust his word.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to make a few comments on this matter. I would hate to wake Senator McMullan up through this debate but I think it is probably worth while his stirring from his slumber—which he is obviously not going to do. I do not know whether to throw something at him or what.
—You got a reaction then.

—Senator McMullan talks with his eyes closed; I do not know whether he sleeps with his eyes closed. I want to get something straight here: there has been an agreement. Senator McMullan knows that, I know that, and the chamber knows that. Right from the word go in this session the Whips had a communication that, if the necessary legislation that was set down was actually passed in an orderly fashion without necessarily truncating proper debate, there was a possibility that we could finish by 13 December and actually spend some time in the electorates we are meant to be servicing.

PARA.TAB: I can well understand that those opposite do not necessarily want us out and about in our electorates, because they are struggling against the Fightback package. But surely that is not a good enough reason to back off on an agreement that was quite clearly made. I think there was some confusion by my colleague, Senator Walters, about the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. While we recognised that that was always on the list right from the word go, there was never a hint that that debate was going to be cut short in the way in which it was, and that we were not going to be allowed sufficient time to properly debate it, let alone have sufficient time to look at the 37-plus amendments that the Government would move to that Bill.

The stunt pulled last week—one of many—to have the debate curtailed was just a real smart alec effort. It is something that the Opposition has not appreciated in any way, shape or form. It is just a further matter in which the agreement that was made back in August has now come asunder. If those opposite think that things are going to be smooth sailing from here on in, I would suggest respectfully that they think again because by 20 December—the date that those opposite are now talking about—we will have been here six out of seven weeks. I am not saying that we will not sit whenever those opposite want to sit—we will. As Senator Walters quite rightly said, if those opposite want to sit until President Bush arrives, so be it, but at least tell us.

It was only Thursday of last week, the last sitting day before today, that Senator McMullan came around here and said to us that he was going to make a statement to the Senate saying that we would be sitting the six days—Monday to Thursday of this week, and Wednesday and Thursday of the following week. Now, tonight, we find that that is all very different. But the one question that I have not been able to find an answer to, and I would be appreciative of an answer—it is a question that Senator Alston has also asked—is this: what legislation that we have left is necessary? What bits of legislation are necessary?

From what I can ascertain there is absolutely nothing that it is crucial to pass now. What we face year in, year out, at the beginning of every session, is a situation where the Senate sits around like a collection of pot-plants waiting for legislation to come from the House of Representatives. Yet before we leave this place it appears that the Government is requesting us to pass legislation that is not necessary now so that we can come back next year and sit around like pot-plants for a week or two.

In the last few sessions—this session; the previous session, the autumn session; and the last Budget session—we have almost had to shut shop here because the Government has run out of business. We are now faced with a situation where the Government has gone that extra step of sneaking legislation into the Senate to bypass the cut-off date for introduction of new legislation into the House of Representatives.

Once again, the intent of the decision of the Senate to have a cut-off date has been bypassed by Senator McMullan and the Government to make sure, once again—smart alecs—that the Government has other pieces of legislation coming in here. Where do we stand on all of this? Why is it necessary to go through the motions of what Senator McMullan is now suggesting? Why, since the last day of sitting, have we had a change in sitting dates from 18 and 19 December to 18, 19 and 20 December?

It is rather decent for some people to be able to plan what they will do. If it is the Government's wish that we sit through until 31 December or 2 January, when President Bush arrives, how about doing the decent thing and telling us? Mr Deputy President, I would certainly like Senator McMullan to tell the Senate whether the agreement that was set down by all parties in August is still in existence and, if not, why not? I would like him to tell us what legislation is necessary, because I cannot see any that is, and I would like him to tell us whether it will be a Government requirement—and whether it has done a deal with the Democrats yet again—that the adjournment be negated night in, night out, in order to get through the legislation that the Government is now saying is so essential, though nobody else can see why.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to clarify in my own mind and for the benefit of the Senate what Senator McMullan has said. I was watching my television when he rose to make a statement tonight. He said something. By the time I got down here in the chamber he was apparently saying something different. I was walking down the steps so I may be mistreating Senator McMullan by suggesting that. Certainly what he said at 8 o'clock, which I heard on the television, was that—and I think these were the words—people who had cared to check, including Dr Hewson, had been told that they should make themselves available for 18 and 19 December. He did not say that the House of Representatives would be sitting but that people should be on guard, on stand-by, in case it was sitting.

PARA.TAB: What Senator McMullan has said since I walked down the steps seems to have changed. I would like Senator McMullan, by leave if necessary, again to give us a guarantee that the House of Representatives will be sitting on 18 and 19 December—and, if necessary, 20 December. I suspect that the last thing this Government wants to do is to bring Caucus back together before Christmas, because, as the newspapers are full of today—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or to put Hawke in front of Hewson.

—Or to put Mr Hawke in front of Dr Hewson. The last thing that Mr Hawke will want is a gathering of his opponents within the Labor Party, the Keating supporters, who could get together, have a Caucus meeting and do the deed before President Bush comes. I am quite sure that it will happen after President Bush is here. I am sure that is part of the deal with the Left. The Left will let Mr Hawke stay to see President Bush and then he will find some excuse and walk away. My feeling is that the Government is desperate not to have Caucus meet in case things happen before then.

PARA.TAB: I would like Senator McMullan to assure us that there will be a meeting. He may well say that if the Government wants to have a Caucus meeting, overthrow Mr Hawke and install Mr Keating, it is none of my business—and that is probably right. What is my business is that we went through this farce of one of the most important pieces of legislation in the history of this Parliament—the proposal to ban free speech in this country—having to be guillotined because it had to be dealt with, for some reason, before the end of this year.

The Democrats, with the very noticeable and courageous exception of Senator Sowada, went along with that furphy. As I understand it, the Labor Party was trying to pretend that this legislation had to be dealt with so that the House of Representatives could deal with it and it could become law before the Parliament met again in February. That was the reason why we had to deal with it in that way and the Democrats were sold that argument. If the House of Representatives does not come back and does not agree with the amendments, that would be an enormous breach of faith.

That is the reason why I have an interest in the matter, and that is the reason why the Senate has an interest in the matter. I want a double assurance from Senator McMullan that the House of Representatives will meet some time between now and Christmas. Whilst I believe Senator McMullan—and it would be improper for me not to believe him—I do suspect that forces are moving over which Senator McMullan has no control. I think those forces may determine that the last thing the Government wants is for the other chamber to come back before Christmas. I ask Senator McMullan for that assurance. As I have said, what he said changed from what I saw him say on the television at 8 p.m. and what he said when I arrived in the chamber, but no doubt Senator McMullan will give a categorical statement that the House will meet between now and Christmas.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave a very cryptic report at 8 o'clock because I felt there was only one matter in any doubt which was what advice had been given to members of the House of Representatives about which days they should be available to return. I did not give a fulsome report because I thought there was only one matter—
—Not fulsome—full.

—Senator Alston is correct. I did not give a very full description because I did not realise it was required. I have been happy to expand in response to the queries and, for some reason that I am not quite sure of, I am happy to reiterate that the House of Representatives will sit next week. The only doubt—and it is very slight—is as to which days that will be. My view is that it will sit on the 18th and 19th, but, of course, I do not determine that.

PARA.TAB: The one thing that Senator Macdonald said that I do agree with is that there are forces afoot over which I have no control. There are thousands of them and they may do something of which I am not aware. The House of Representatives intends to and will sit next week, and my view is that it will sit on the 18th and 19th.

There has been much ill-informed passion about alleged breaches. Nothing has been added to the legislative program which we are seeking to pass now, and one thing has been subtracted, but apart from that it is exactly the same as that which I distributed to all honourable senators on 29 July.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you didn't get it introduced in time into the House of Reps.
—I will come back to the introduction in the Senate in a moment. It is not exactly germane to this discussion; nevertheless, I am happy to discuss it.
—It is.

—I am not trying to avoid it; I am saying that it is at a bit of a tangent, but I am happy to discuss it. I thank Senator Knowles for acknowledging that there has never been any doubt that included in the legislative program which we were seeking to pass—preferably by 12 or 13 December because that is when everybody wanted to go home, but whatever date—was the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. It was listed in week one on the program distributed on 29 July and has always been there.
—I accept that, but it kept being put back, as you know.
—But it was always in the program as `not been added'.
—I thought it had been withdrawn. I apologise.

—There was never any indication of that. The first definitive indication I received that there would be no guarantee of its being passed by the 13th was in a discussion with Senators Hill and Reid. They gave me the advice that they could not guarantee its passage by the 13th, so I indicated then—because we all felt that we needed to advise our House of Representatives' colleagues of which days they needed to come back—that we would therefore have to come back on the 18th and 19th. That was the change.

PARA.TAB: I am not alleging that that is a breach of agreement by the Opposition. Opposition senators said that they would try. They never gave me a guarantee that we would succeed. We all simply set out to try to pass that package of legislation distributed on 29 July by the 13th. Opposition senators said that they would use their best endeavours. I acknowledge that there was a substantial amount of cooperation for a lengthy period, which broke down at the point when it was said, `No, we cannot guarantee to pass that legislation by that date'. That is a legitimate decision about the significance of that legislation. I am not attacking anyone for making that point. But that is the point at which the cooperative arrangement collapsed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you do? You gagged it.

—That has never been and is not in any way a matter of controversy between us. Of course it is true that that happened. Such guillotines have been used in the past and I imagine will be in the future, no matter who is in government. So, in my view, there is no breach of any agreement. Senator Knowles asked me to indicate the legislation we are seeking to pass this session: it is unchanged. Other than the dropping of one matter off the program, it is unchanged from that which we provided on 29 July. It remains the same. That is what we are seeking to pass by that date. Cabinet has indicated that this is the legislation which it regards as essential for passage and that is, therefore, the legislation I believe we need to try to pass.
—But don't you look at it more closely than that? There is no need for it.
—Those opposite may wish to make that judgment. Cabinet has given its judgment, which I endorse, that this is the legislation that is essential for passage. Those opposite understand the process.
—Does that affect your start-up date, for instance?
—There are a variety of reasons. I am not responsible for any legislation but, wearing my lesser hat, there is much legislation about which I know almost nothing.
—But are you aware of any start-up date, for instance?

—The Cabinet has made a decision that this is the legislative program, and I do not intend to get into a debate on behalf of all the Ministers in the Parliament about the priority of all the legislation before us.
—Are you aware of any start-up dates prior to the resumption?
—Start-up dates are not the only thing in question. Let me talk about one.
—Just rule that out, though.

—Let me talk about the insurance package, which has a lower priority than some legislation. I am sure the Opposition, just as we are, is getting a substantial amount of lobbying from the industry that it would like that passed. If we do not pass that legislation, from the point of view of implementation, that is not a crisis—and I have indicated that. We very much want it and the industry has asked us—and I am sure it has asked the Opposition—to pass it. From the Government's perspective—I have indicated this to Senator Reid—we seek to pass the legislation. But if the Senate made a judgment not to deal with the legislation, that is probably about the only thing left that would not cause a problem to the Minister in question. That does not mean we do not want to pass it. I once again urge the Opposition to pass it. I am sure the industry is lobbying the Opposition, as it is us. But the Cabinet did not list that as essential for passage, although the Government wants to pass it. It has always been on the program, but I have advised on half a dozen occasions during discussions that it is listed at a slightly lower priority.

PARA.TAB: So that is the basis of the legislative passage. If shadow Ministers, Whips or whoever is involved with that want to talk to individual Ministers about whether they can be persuaded that individual pieces of legislation are not as important as the Cabinet decided they are, well and good. I certainly do not intend to enter into that debate. It is not one to which I can usefully contribute, other than in the couple of areas with which I am dealing. I do not think there is any doubt about their desirability or need to deal with them.

I think that deals with Senator Alston's two questions. I think I have dealt with Senator Macdonald's questions and the matters raised by Senator Walters which relate to this particular point. I indicated to the Opposition informally, and then to the Senate in a statement, that we wish—and I believe it is a reasonable program—to sit for six days and that will enable us to pass that body of legislation. In my view, we could pass it easily without negating adjournments, late sittings and all of those things.

We have exchanged schedules of what legislation we thought would be reasonable to pass on particular days. Without any pressure to negate the adjournment or to do anything extraordinary in that regard, by sitting only the six days and concluding on the 19th we would be finished comfortably. Of course, today we have not dealt with any of the legislation which is on that program, and that is not a wonderful sign about where we might be going. But there is plenty of time to talk about that subsequently.

I am surprised that there is any doubt about it: the House of Representatives will sit. I was only indicating a margin of possible doubt about which days it would sit. That has always been the case, and it remains the case.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Advance to the Minister for Finance involves some considerable additional expenditure which I am certain the Senate will find quite interesting. Particularly interesting is the Department of Employment, Education and Training. An extra $22m is to be allocated specifically in relation to Austudy—in other words, age-related student allowances—but another $5m is also to be allocated for Abstudy and $6.3m for labour market program assistance to job seekers in industry. Altogether it is something like $32m. This is extra money which was not in the Budget and which the Parliament is now being asked to agree to as part of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. It is interesting to note that the reason given for the increase in the Austudy payment is:
Payments under Austudy are income support and are often the only means of income for recipients, it is therefore urgent that these payments are made.
That is self-evidently true. But the reasons continue:
The supply estimate calculation in March 1991 did not anticipate the increases in beneficiary numbers that have taken place.

Interestingly, not only did the Budget wrongly estimate by a very considerable amount the demand for Austudy, but it also reinforced what we have been saying here for some time, that is, that Austudy payments are being used by this Government as an alternative to unemployment benefit. The reason there is this huge increase—

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely right.
—I see my colleagues nodding their heads, and I acknowledge that interjection that what I am saying is right.
—And disability support pensions and sickness benefits are also proxies.

—That is absolutely correct. Disability pensions and sickness benefits are also being used as proxies, or substitutes, for unemployment benefits. In this way the Government hides the real impact of unemployment. What we see here with this $22m underfunding of Austudy so far is a clear indication that the Government underestimated Austudy needs because many young Australians could not find jobs and have gone back to schools, universities or to other institutions of learning as it is their second choice. Basically, they may as well increase their skills because they cannot get a job. For many young people, that course of action is a very useful procedure, and may well increase their options if and when further jobs become available. We know that under the present Government's policies there is no prospect of jobs for them. This Government and some of its advisers are now conceding that there will be a 10 per cent unemployment rate in general for at least three years, and that the 30 per cent unemployment rate amongst young Australians under the age of 20 unsuccessfully seeking full time employment will persist as well.

PARA.TAB: So here we have clear evidence in these figures that this Government not only massively understated the extent of the recession it said we `had to have', and massively understated the amount of unemployment it would create, but also exposed the fact that it uses Austudy as an alternative for unemployment benefit.

When we look at what the real level of unemployment is under this Government, there is no doubt now that we should look very closely at some of these huge increases for Austudy and the other benefits that Senator Alston indicated. It is certainly far higher than the official statistics, and this Advance to the Minister for Finance simply confirms what we have been saying for quite some time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Advance to the Minister for Finance has become an important indicator as to how well or how badly individual departments are run. At the risk of again putting down something which other people may have become aware of, but which I suspect most people are not aware of, during the last Estimates hearings I obtained an undertaking from the Department of Finance that it would not only maintain a register of those departments which made applications for an Advance to the Minister for Finance and were unsuccessful or successful, but also publish that list.

PARA.TAB: I am particularly interested in the manner in which preparation is done, how well or how badly overall calculations for estimates are made, and how well or how badly a department is administered. I believe that the number of applications which fail to gain acceptance against the Advance to the Minister for Finance, as well as those that ultimately are accepted—I understand that some of them have two or three goes—will be a good indicator as to who is doing an adequate job and who is not doing an adequate job.

I am particularly interested in the item under the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, `Australian Customs Service—Other services. Compensation and legal expenses $389,000'. When we go to the supporting documentation, we read that the explanation for the requirement from the AMF is this:

SPEECH.PARA: Due to an unforeseen compensation payment of $589,000—
a pretty substantial sum—

resulting from a court ruling against the Commonwealth in October 1991 after the Supply bills were prepared. The funds available for payment now total $10,411. As we have on hand payments in the vicinity of $400,000 to be made before 22 November 1991 the additional amount of $389,000 is requested to cover payments which must be made.

People who are used to dealing in litigation—and surely Customs must be—would know that when they are looking at the sorts of pay-outs they may have to deal with, they are obliged to do estimates of what work in progress may result in. It is a common practice in ordinary legal practice and I do not see why Customs cannot do it more effectively.

PARA.TAB: We have yet to debate the annual report because it came in late, but the draft annual report was made available to the Estimates Committee. If my memory serves me correctly, in that report there were an enormous number—in excess of 300—of cases down for investigation. They were supposed to yield—again if my memory serves me correctly—$54m worth of duty which was to be recovered. In fact, there were only 45 commercial actions and the amount recovered was in the vicinity of $3m.

The long and the short of it is that the Advance to the Minister for Finance is being used to advance what amounts to verdict moneys, without the particulars of the case even being included in the documentation. Dare I suggest that if I go through the annual report I will find very little, if any, provision for decisions which may go against the Commonwealth. I can only say again that the inquiry that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is holding into the Customs Service is probably way overdue.

I might say that the amount of correspondence that has come in from all over the community saying just that—that this inquiry into and shake-up of the Australian Customs Service is way overdue—is borne out by the fact that Customs is requiring money from the Advance to the Minister for Finance the validity of which, quite frankly, I would query.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the 1990-91 annual report of the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council, known as EXANDIS. This is the first annual report of EXANDIS and it covers the 15 months to 30 June 1991. On previous occasions when I have spoken on documents in this place, I have spoken about how Australia must keep its product clean and pure if we are to compete in the world. That is one special feature of Australia, compared with all other countries in the world, being an island continent. If an exotic disease came into Australia, we could suffer catastrophic problems in our animal industries. The establishment of EXANDIS, which is a consultative council, is:
to raise the level of Australia's disease preparedness and improve the range and timeliness of advice to the Government on exotic animal disease issues.
The composition of EXANDIS is aimed to represent the interests of all those concerned with the livestock industries potentially vulnerable to exotic disease.
If diseases such as foot and mouth disease got into Australia and among our wild pigs and other wild animals, they would cause untold damage.

PARA.TAB: The eight-member Council includes an independent chairman; one member representing the Australian Agricultural Council; one member representing the Department of Primary Industries and Energy; two members who are nominees from the National Farmers Federation to ensure that the views of the livestock industries are effectively represented; and three members with special qualifications and expertise in such areas as disaster emergency management, communications and public relations, agricultural marketing, the veterinary profession, et cetera. The secretariat services are provided by DPIE in Canberra. The Council's objects and functions are to inquire into, assess and report to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on the adequacy of the strategies and procedures provided in any approved veterinary emergency plan.

The Council has had a very heavy workload over the past 15 months or more. I would like to commend the Council on the AUSVETPLAN. The AUSVETPLAN documents have been completed and represent a set of uniform strategic and operational plans for the technical aspects of exotic animal disease emergency response.

The importance of EXANDIS cannot be overemphasised when it is realised that, as I said earlier, an outbreak of foot and mouth disease would do untold damage. It was estimated that the cost in the first year of such an outbreak would be about $8 billion. Obviously, we would have to deal with such an outbreak very quickly and that is what this group of dedicated people in EXANDIS would do. They have a plan to handle such an outbreak, if it ever eventuated. But, of course, the most important thing is to make sure that it does not happen to Australia and that we do not lose beef markets or any other export markets. I commend the annual report of EXANDIS to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Supporting Applications of Issues from Advances to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: A section of this document explains quite clearly why supporting applications are an important and useful part of government financing. Supporting applications show the reasons behind advances made to the Minister for Finance during the month. Many of these advances are, of course, soundly based. That is why when we criticise some that are not soundly based or that arise from incompetence, we are pointing out real errors by the Government.

PARA.TAB: One item in these supporting applications demonstrates the quite proper use of this Advance. I refer to the item that relates to the tragic accident in which RAAF aircrew were killed in a 707 plane crash on 29 October 1991. The payment of compensation for the families of the RAAF personnel killed would clearly not have been provided for in the Budget. Therefore, the allocation of $744,670 by way of compensation is quite proper. It would be totally improper to complain about this sort of additional expenditure because clearly it should be made and clearly there was no capacity for it to be known at Budget time.

These papers also contain an explanation of why the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services needs another $6.7m. This is exactly the sort of request that is disgraceful and represents real incompetence by a government.
The Government decided in the Budget that it would need co-payments for medical payments. We now find that the costs of doing this were not included in the Budget. The supporting material states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Supply allocation did not provide for additional staffing and administrative expenses resulting from Budget new policy initiatives agreed after the preparation of Supply Estimates.

This happens to total $6.7m. The Government is quite prepared to introduce measures of substance in the Budget, but it is not prepared to outline in the Budget the costs of implementing those new measures. It seems incredible that this can be taken for granted. The supporting material continues:

Costs associated with the Medical Benefits co-payment Budget initiative are being incurred under this sub-division until 1 December 1991 . . . these costs need to be incurred in order to achieve implementation of the Medicare co-payment arrangements by the specified date. The shortfall in Administrative Expenses relates directly to these costs. . . The AMF —
that is, the Advance to the Minister for Finance—

requirement is urgent as there are insufficient funds in Salaries to cover Pay 10 . . . and claims for payment must be paid by the due date. The AMF requirement was unforeseen as the higher level of funding required . . . was unknown at the time of the preparation of Supply estimates.

That is simply unsatisfactory. If the Government is so competent when it introduces the Medicare co-payment, a significant measure, and is prepared to put the proceeds of it in its Budget, why does it not have the honesty to also include in the Budget the costs involved with the project? The answer is simple: it is either incompetence or deception. We are having to put up with it.

PARA.TAB: In December we are at last being told that $6.7m extra is needed to implement this Budget decision. What chicanery! What an absolute fraud this Government is. The Government's Budget was wrong by an amount of $6.7m. One simply has to ask: was this deliberate or was it due to incompetence? On the Government's track record, particularly the way it has been dealing with the coalition's rescue package for Australia, it is probably fraud. This Government did not want a Budget that showed the reality of its costs; it wanted to bamboozle the people of Australia with figures—figures which have now clearly been shown to be wrong. How can the Australian people be sucked in once again by a Government which cannot add up the figures in its own documents yet tries to attack the coalition's document? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to the Supporting Applications of Issues from the Advances to the Minister for Finance during the Month of November 1991, I refer to the document from the Department of Administrative Services relating to an advance of over half a million dollars which falls into the category of `urgent and erroneously understated'. The advance relates to errors made with regard to superannuation dealt with by the Department during the last financial year. The most significant part of the accompanying documentation is the fourth paragraph of a document called `Part 1'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Late last financial year, the Senate Estimates committee requested details of overtime payments made to staff of members of Parliament. An examination of the overtime component of the salary ledgers for 1990/91 established that there were integrity problems with the ledgers caused by coding errors. It needs to be kept in mind that the faults and shortcomings, the rectification of which has now led to this approach for funds, would most likely not have been detected but for the action of the Branch.
I think we could re-write that to say, `It would not have been detected if not for action by the Senate Estimates committees'.

PARA.TAB: The Government likes to deride the effectiveness and importance of the Estimates committees, largely because they result in embarrassment for the Government. It is not surprising that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) is embarrassed—he frequently is. Here is yet another example of the Department not getting it right. Yet the documentation tries to say, `It is really okay, because we nearly got it right'. Quite clearly, that attitude will not do in departments or in Australia as a whole. We have to aspire to, and achieve, better than that.

Another important point to make concerning this particular application against the Advance is that even the language that is used—ADP payments and so on—is rather dated. The point I make is the importance of the Senate Estimates committees and the importance of the members of those committees resisting the Minister responsible for this particular Committee, Senator Bolkus. He is one such Minister who chooses to fight any sure investigation. There are other Ministers who find the investigations of Estimates committees more useful. That is usually the mark of a good Minister. The documentation goes on to outline how the Government will improve the situation.

The final point I want to make is that this document is yet another example of the way that government departments, particularly those under Ministers who are less than well equipped, make gross errors. It is particularly pertinent to the model that has been established within Treasury under the guidance or otherwise of Senator McMullan and whichever Treasurer we happen to have at the time—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer we had to have.

—Senator Alston has it right. When the Government set up this model and started to test the costings of the goods and services tax and the overall Fightback package—which we have on admission in the Estimates committees has been set up within Treasury at the instigation and instruction of the former Treasurer (Mr Kerin) to spend taxpayers' money on party political work—the question that we will always be able to ask ourselves is: how worth while or how reliable is the sort of work that they do? It should be borne in mind that the figuring for the last Budget was out by $7.7 billion and that we see errors in the Department of Administrative Services, which means therefore that other budgeted figures have been blown out. In other words, it is the work as overseen by the Ministers.

PARA.TAB: My criticism is of the Ministers who have the responsibility for oversighting the work of those public servants. Public servants are answerable to the Ministers and to the Executive. The reliability and the scrutiny of the Ministers is certainly lacking. It is borne out only through the Estimates committees where we finally get accountability to the Parliament that we see how defective this Executive Government, as personified by the Ministers, really is.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The foreword on the first page of the annual report of the Freedom of Information Act shows that the overall cost of the administration of the Act in the year in which it reported was almost $10m. A total of $351,000 was collected in fees and charges, an increase of some 13.5 per cent. The average amount collected per request was $14.10 compared with $13.21 last year. The average cost per request to each agency was $398, a similar amount to the cost incurred last year.

PARA.TAB: In view of these figures, one wonders why the Government saw fit to introduce earlier this year the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill which introduced further restrictions preventing citizens from obtaining information under the legislation. At the time, the Australian Democrats voiced concern about various amendments that the Government proposed to introduce. One amendment that I drew attention to proposed to force people, if they wished to obtain personal information in an agency, to use internal proceedings first, even if that could have affected their careers or was personally embarrassing.

The next area we expressed concern about was that an agency could actually refuse to supply information if a substantial diversion of resources were to occur within the agency; and that decision is to be made at the agency's discretion and in its judgment. The definition of `commercial activities' was widened further, but it was not clearly stated exactly what commercial activities were to come under that particular heading. Finally, an agency is able now to delete what it considers to be irrelevant material from the material that is provided upon an FOI request.

All of these amendments were foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats. However, we could not at the time get any support from either the Government or the Opposition for these amendments. Consequently, the Bill was passed as introduced by the Government, imposing all these restrictions. In view of the report that we are dealing with today, I wonder whether it was really necessary, if we had a total cost of $10m for the necessary provision of freedom of information for our citizens, to try to save an additional few thousand dollars at the expense of citizens' rights to obtain information under the legislation.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Letter from Speaker of ACT Legislative Assembly

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present a letter from the Speaker of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly concerning the ACT electoral system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a background paper prepared by the Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Super System Survey: A Background paper on retirement income arrangements and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate established the Select Committee on Superannuation on 5 June 1991 to inquire into and report upon a wide range of matters relating to superannuation. The Committee has already received and published over 130 submissions from a wide range of persons and organisations interested in superannuation. Reflecting the importance of the issues under consideration, the financial and general press have commented on the submissions from some of the more important players in the field. The Committee welcomes the analysis of issues occurring in the press, because it is only through public airing and discussion of the complexities and problems with superannuation that the Committee can produce a meaningful report.

PARA.TAB: Superannuation arrangements existing in other countries is one of the matters included in the Committee's terms of reference. The purpose of the paper I am tabling is to provide a general overview of the retirement income arrangements from a selected number of OECD countries and two other nations which have unusual retirement income systems. It is worth noting the trends which the survey reveals.

Firstly, of the 21 countries that were surveyed, only three have mandatory employer contributions lower than Australia's current 3 per cent. Chile, the Netherlands and New Zealand do not require any employer contributions towards superannuation retirement income. Secondly, if the full phasing in of the current Government's 9 per cent target for superannuation is achieved, there would still be 13 countries with mandatory contributions from employers greater than Australia. So even if a 9 per cent target is reached we will be only mid-way through the pack. Thirdly, from the employee's contribution aspect, Australia again also appears to be close to the bottom of the table. Ireland, Sweden and New Zealand alone are the only countries not requiring mandatory employee contributions towards some sort of superannuation pension retirement fund. Fourthly, of the 21 countries surveyed, only two allow pension funds to be drawn on for housing purposes—Singapore and Belgium.

There are only three countries out of the 21 where the Government requires direction of the investment of private superannuation funds. Those three countries are Belgium, Denmark and Switzerland. Nine of the 21 countries have a lower retirement age for females than for males. Three of those nine countries are increasing the female retirement age to the same as the male retirement age. In particular, the United States is increasing the retirement age to 67 for both sexes.

A further point that comes out of the report is that very few countries allow the use of retirement or pension funds for other purposes. However, both Singapore and Spain are notable exceptions. They both have very high contribution rates. Singapore has a combined employer-employee contribution rate of 40 per cent and Spain has a combined employer-employee contribution rate of 45.8 per cent. In Spain the superannuation payments also cover sickness and family allowance payments. I have already mentioned that in Singapore, superannuation payments go towards housing and, interestingly, contributions also go towards the local Singapore bus company.

In terms of the direction of investment, it is particularly interesting to note the current controversy concerning the Maxwell printing empire where #300m of pension moneys have in some way been misdirected as a result of investing the money in the employer's company. That is an area that this Committee will be looking at in some detail.

The Committee believes the material is a useful reference point against which the community can address one of the key questions which has emerged from the terms of reference of the inquiry. That question is: what are the objectives of Australia's retirement income policy and what role does superannuation have in it? This and other questions will be further explored in the public hearings the Committee will hold from February next year. Full details on the location and timing of these hearings are included on page ii of the paper I have tabled.

I am pleased to advise the Senate that the Committee has worked in a constructive and non-partisan way to date. It is my sincere hope that this will continue. Although public hearings will not commence until early next year, the Committee has benefited from a series of informal briefings from government agencies and industry bodies at seven separate meetings, as well as attendance by members of the Committee at various conferences that have been held around the country on superannuation. The briefings have allowed Committee members to familiarise themselves with the extremely complex issues on which they are required to report and will greatly assist the examination of witnesses at the public hearings.

This paper is the first in what the Committee hopes will be a series of background papers or public seminars aimed at increasing public discussion of superannuation leading up to the tabling of the final report. I commend the paper to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to touch on three areas in this initial discussion of the work of the Select Committee on Superannuation, and those are: first, the relevance of international experience and comparison; secondly, the question of equity and taxation concessions; and thirdly, the question of the productive investment of superannuation fund assets.

PARA.TAB: Australia has a history of being a very insular and xenophobic nation, for a variety of reasons. Australian politicians have a history of selectively using overseas examples in very inconsistent ways. Whilst there are unique factors applying to Australia, I argue that in the area of superannuation or retirement incomes in general, international experience is totally relevant because of the common human needs of all retired people. As such, I commend the Committee for tabling this important discussion paper which will make an important contribution to public debate. As can be seen from this report, compulsory, government controlled superannuation is the normal system in many comparable countries, not some sort of aberration designed to disadvantage our employers.

The second area that I want to touch on is that of the appropriate form of taxation concessions which should apply to contributions to superannuation funds. The current system of deductions is extremely regressive and must be changed. Even though only a few months ago the former Treasurer, Mr Kerin, acknowledged that the current arrangements were unfair, he stated that the Government did not intend to address the problem. Then, interestingly, the Opposition in its Fightback package has presented an alternative system of concessions which rely on the much fairer principle of tax rebates instead of tax deductions. The dollar value of the tax benefit is then equal for all taxpayers who make contributions which qualify for the concession.

The final area is the question of the investment of superannuation savings. The rationalist line is that the market knows best and that the national interest does not exist. The Democrats' policy calls for a national development fund using funds from superannuation funds and other sources such as resource taxes to be established to assist sustainable industries to grow and to provide some of the development capital which the deregulated private sector financial institutions just have not provided. There is no doubt as to the existence of this market failure in this area, but there is doubt about what should be done to address it. This question is before the Committee. We will be considering the evidence from various sources. I hope that the members of the Committee consider and vote in the national interest in this regard and not in the short term interests of their parties. I commend the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Crowley, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee C.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a report which presents additional information received by the Committee. I am waiting for some information from one of my advisers about some concerns I have about this report.

PARA.TAB: On 13 November I wrote to the Secretary of Senate Estimates Committee C expressing concern about some outstanding responses to questions on notice from the Department of Social Security. I want to go through some of those because I think it is important to make sure that the Department is fully aware of the questions I have asked. It seems to me that when a Department says that it will get information or that it does not have it at the time, we should not have to go through the nonsense of saying, `I therefore put that on notice and ask that you bring it back to the Senate'. For example, when we were discussing the people who had been tendering to carry out an inquiry, I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: And they were all Australian companies?
I received the following answer:
Mr Godfrey—I think the answer to that question is yes, all the companies were Australian companies.
Mr Volker, the head of the Department, said:
We will just have a look at the list and see whether they are Australian.

I presumed from that answer that Mr Volker was going to come back to me to tell me whether those companies were Australian. I do not believe that I need to say, `I therefore want to draw it to the Committee's attention that this question is on notice'. I would presume that the intention there is that I would get an answer to that question, but I have not. There are quite a number of other examples such as that.

PARA.TAB: If the Department does not have an answer to a question we should sit there until it gets the answer. If it is not going to respond to questions on notice, we should sit and wait until it gives us the answer. Obviously when a department does not have the answer immediately we say, `Would you get that for us?', and the officers say, `We will do that'. In this case, the bureaucrats of this Department are responding in a way that I think is reasonable.

In another case the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) was asked about the incidence of people in nursing homes receiving telephone vouchers. I asked whether we could go back and have a look at how many were in that category, because there were quite a few and it would not be correct in the discussion we were having at the time. Senator Richardson said, `Perhaps we could prepare a response for you'. I presumed that the Committee would get a response in that case.

I asked for a list of internal audit titles that had been undertaken by the DSS. It said it would not provide the actual audits but that it would give me a list. That list has not been forthcoming. I asked whether all tenderers for a contract for a child support survey were Australian companies, an example I gave earlier. I also asked the Department why it had not provided me with a copy of the questionnaire of the child support survey. I had asked for a copy of the child support survey and the results. It seems that the Department had something fixed in its head—it did not want to provide the questionnaire until the whole report was available. What I would like, and what I asked for, was the child support survey. I requested a copy of this questionnaire forthwith. I asked for a copy of the report when it became available. I understand that the report may still not be available and I have not seen a copy of the questionnaire.

I have raised those concerns because sometimes the departments might think that they will not go back through the Hansard and look it up and that they can get away with not answering it. That is not the case. We go through the Hansard very carefully. We do not ask these questions for the good of our health; we ask them for a purpose. I ask the Minister to instruct the Department to answer the questions as they have been asked, in the spirit in which they have been asked, without having to make it formal, which is what we may have to do if we do not get the response that I think is appropriate for the Committee.

I put on notice that we are still concerned we have not had those responses. I hope the Department will ensure that we have them before the end of this session; in fact, I think the Department should be able to provide that information for us by the end of this week.

DEBATE.TITLE: CORPORATIONS (UNLISTED PROPERTY TRUSTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last few years the collapse, or near collapse, of several large unlisted property trusts has highlighted an inherent problem in the management of these kinds of trusts. When unit holders bought units in unlisted property trusts, they bought on terms and conditions which were set out in trust deeds. The trust deeds always set out the period of notice which had to be given before they could get their money out.

PARA.TAB: When unit holders of property trusts wanted their money back, they would ask the managers to buy back their investments. The management company usually redeemed the units from the assets of the trust. In the past, unit holders were able to withdraw their investments at relatively short notice. Since March 1988 it has been obligatory, pursuant to a requirement of the NCSC, that all trust deeds contain a 60-day notice provision. Such short periods were essentially inconsistent with the nature of property investment, where underlying assets can only be liquidated in the long term, particularly once the boom was over and the market became bogged down in the recession we had to have.

Borrowing short term and investing long term is an obvious recipe for disaster which is, of course, what has happened. Unlisted property trusts are now facing a huge slump in commercial property values because of the recession. Consequently, the trusts are having difficulty attracting new investments and also selling property. At the same time, investors realised that the assets underlying the trusts were not sufficient to justify the earlier valuations and began to bale out. The inevitable result of large numbers of redemption and buy-back requests at short notice is the liquidity problems which ensued.

Many unlisted property trusts were forced into the highly undesirable position of having to put freezes on withdrawals. Others just crashed. Since July 1990 the NCSC, and since 1 January this year the Australian Securities Commission, have been investigating options for improving the liquidity of unlisted property trusts. The major bank and life insurance owned fund managers have also been advising the Government on the deteriorating state of the property trust industry. In fact, the six major institution backed funds requested that the Government impose a freeze because of the deteriorating state of their, and other, trusts. It was obvious that some sort of Government intervention would be necessary to prevent any further rush of investors seeking to withdraw their funds from unlisted property trusts.

On 23 July this year the Government announced that it intended to legislate to restore confidence in the unlisted property trust industry. In yet another example of legislation by press release, it was announced that there would be a standard 12-month notice period for withdrawal of funds from any of the existing unlisted property trusts, with effect from the date of that announcement. The major concern of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and the former Treasurer, Mr Kerin, in making this announcement was to ensure that small unit holders were protected as property trusts were restructured. They were also concerned to avoid trusts being forced to sell property in an already depressed real estate market. It is fair to say that the market has deteriorated even more since 23 July.

When the announcement was made, about $6 billion in funds invested by about 300,000 investors was affected. In the announcement of 23 July, details of the new regulatory structure, based on recommendations of the Australian Securities Commission, were also revealed. Unlisted property trusts and management companies would be required to maintain adequate liquidity. Breach of the liquidity requirements would result in the investors being able to meet to consider, among other options, the replacement of the trust manager and the listing of the trust or its termination. Borrowing by trusts would be limited to 20 per cent of the gross assets of a trust, and a capital adequacy requirement would be set for management companies based on the value of the assets of the trusts they had under their management.

At the time of this announcement, the transitional rules for fund managers were also announced. The Corporations (Unlisted Property Trusts) Amendment Bill implements all the measures announced in the 23 July press release. It is a matter of some concern to the Opposition that the freeze was announced on 23 July and, therefore, has been in place for over four months with no legislative basis whatsoever. The Bill provides that 12 months' notice will be required in relation to buy-backs and redemptions from unlisted property trusts in existence on the date of the Attorney-General's announcement on 23 July.

There is an exemption in cases of demonstrated financial hardship for unit holders, who will be able to buy back without waiting the 12 months at a discount not exceeding 7.5 per cent. The Bill also provides for unit holders to vary the 12-month period if it is commercially viable to do so. The trustee or the management company will be able to apply to the ASC for any variation to be disallowed. The ASC will also be able to permit the trustee to refuse redemptions from trust assets where it is satisfied that such redemptions are likely to adversely affect the value of remaining units or otherwise prejudice the interests of remaining unit holders.

This legislation is only part of the scheme. There are still regulations being developed by the Attorney-General's Department. This Bill also changes the requirement in relation to unit trusts generally that trust deeds can be changed only where the changes are approved by an absolute majority of unit holders. Under this Bill, amendments may be made where they are approved by 75 per cent of unit holders voting at a meeting. A further amendment provides for unit holders to requisition meetings with the trustee for the purpose of giving directions to the trustee or management company in relation to the affairs of the trust.

This Bill also empowers the corporations and security panel to make interim orders pending its final determinations of applications before it. This is a necessary amendment in view of the decision of the Federal Court of Australia in the recent Keydata case that the panel does not have power to make interim orders. The Attorney-General, in his second reading speech in the other place, noted that the standard notice of withdrawal period of 12 months would not of itself solve the liquidity problems of unlisted property trusts. The intention is that the freeze gives the trust time to restructure its operations in consultation with unit holders.

That time that has been created has been used by most of the trusts to restructure. Many of the major trusts have been meeting with their unit holders and arranging the flotation of their trusts during that period and many more are planned for the period between now and the end of the freeze. But, of course, as the Attorney-General noted, it will not solve the liquidity problems that were created by the downturn in the property market as a result of the recession that we had to have.

The recent revaluation of Grosvenor Place in Sydney is a very good example of a rapid reduction in the asset backing of some of these trusts with a property that probably 18 months ago would have been sold at a capitalisation rate of something around 5 per cent being revalued at a capitalisation rate of 7.65 per cent as recently as last week—which shows the underlying weakness in the commercial property market in Australia. Perth, Melbourne and Sydney, and Adelaide to a lesser extent, have enormous vacancy rates in prime central city office towers which make up most of the portfolios of some of these trusts with vacancy rates, as I have said, of 20 per cent to 25 per cent predicted within 18 months in some of those cities.

We note that the Government expects all necessary restructuring to be completed by the end of July next year. One of the solutions is for such property trusts to be listed. As I have said, that is under way with many of them. On this matter, I note the report in the Sydney Morning Herald of Wednesday, 13 November that Colonial Mutual has decided to merge all of its property funds into one large listed trust. Bankers Trust has also decided to list its property trust. The other financial institutions which have a significant presence in the unlisted property trust market are Advance, AMP, ANZ, National Mutual and Westpac. They have not yet announced their strategies for restructuring, but this report indicates that it is likely they will follow Colonial Mutual's decision to list.

While it is unfortunate in the extreme that the freeze was necessary in the first place and also that it has taken nearly five months so far to introduce legislation by parliament rather than by press release, the Opposition supports this Bill. We express our hope that the restructuring of unlisted property trusts will proceed as expeditiously as possible and, of course, we all hope, more importantly, that the sort of economic policies included in the Fightback package, launched by the Opposition just over two weeks ago, will indeed create the sort of economic environment which will see some of these major properties filled with tenants who can pay rent and will put a bit of value back into the central city and commercial property markets. Indeed, that is the only way these unlisted property funds will return to being secure investments in which the mums and dads and investors of Australia can put their money.

I would also like to make a few brief remarks about the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. This Bill makes amendments to the corporations law, which we passed in this place about 12 months ago. It changes the law principally in relation to Australian company numbers, which was a matter I brought before the Senate in a series of questions to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate. I think when I first started asking the questions he did not know what I was talking about, but he found out fairly soon thereafter.

The Australian company number was a requirement of the initial legislation but the Government, in its great wisdom and after a lot of pressure from me and from business people all around Australia, realised that a moratorium was necessary. This time last year it introduced such a moratorium, initially for six months, and it extended it for another six months. So the moratorium on the ACN was, indeed, for 12 months and it comes to an end at the end of this month.

The information that has come from corporations, companies and small businesses around Australia has led to some of these very sensible amendments. For example, the corporations law currently provides that the ACN must appear on all business letters, accounts, invoices, receipts and orders. As I have said, at the time this legislation was passed, the Opposition expressed some concerns which have been abided by and the legislation has been amended.

As a consequence of these amendments, companies will no longer be obliged to display their ACN on cash register receipts. We welcome that amendment. The abbreviation `ACN' will no longer require full stops; instead of `A.C.N.', we will be able to write `ACN', which will save a lot of printing costs. Pursuant to the redefinition of the term `public document', companies will not be obliged to display the ACN on their advertising or promotional material. This was a matter of great concern to the real estate industry, amongst others, which would have had to place the ACN at the bottom of every little advertisement in Saturday's metropolitan newspapers and thus added on millions of dollars in costs for the already hard-pressed real estate agents who are doing their best to survive in this very depressed market. The companies will be required to display the ACN only on documents signed or issued in the course of, or for the purposes of, a particular transaction.

The Opposition particularly welcomes these amendments in relation to Australian company numbers because we have been pointing out since the corporations legislation was introduced that it was simply unreasonable to expect businesses to comply with the requirement to display the ACN on all business letters, statements of account, invoices, receipts, orders for goods, official notices or publications.

There are various technical amendments in relation to the vitally important area of fundraising. The purpose of these amendments is to remove some uncertainties in the corporations law which have become apparent over the months since the law came into operation. They make it clear that fundraising provisions do not apply to the trading of securities on the stock exchange. They also clarify how the prospectus provisions apply to other secondary trading. The amendments also provide for a defence to civil action from an omission from a prospectus, where reasonable inquiries led to a reasonable belief that there was no material omission.

The amendments enable the ASC to declare certain products to be marketable securities in order to facilitate trading of these products. The amendments also provide for a fixed date settlement regime for transactions on the Australian Stock Exchange. The standard settlement period will be five days after the trade. This amendment accords with international standards approved by the International Organisation of Securities Commissions and is intended to improve the international competitiveness of the Australian Stock Exchange by reducing delays and therefore the risks and costs involved in the settlement and clearing process.

Pursuant to the amendments in this Bill, the national guarantee fund will cover facilities which have been developed by the stock exchange to assist traders to comply with the new settlement requirements. This Bill is part—so the Attorney-General informs us—of an ongoing program of corporate law reform. The Opposition supports this Bill, as it welcomes any improvements in our corporate law which protect investors and creditors and, at the same time, facilitate competition and efficiency in our own domestic financial arrangements.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROCEEDINGS ON POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES LEGISLATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I have spoken to the motion but I wish to speak again in order to help achieve reasonable debate. We have now had a little longer to consider your statement, Mr President, and there are a few points I wish to add to those which I made earlier in the day.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the matter can be reasonably divided into three separate issues. The first issue, which is not covered by your statement, causes us considerable concern. It is something that we expected to be covered and, as a result of it not being so covered, in our minds anyway quite serious questions are left unanswered.

This specific issue, which is to do with the general matter of points of order, arose out of an exchange between my colleague Senator O'Chee and, at one stage, the Chairman. You, Mr President, also played a role. This is reported on page 4246 of the daily Hansard on Thursday 5 December. Basically, my colleague Senator O'Chee was seeking to take a point of order whilst you were in the chair but which you did not receive. You may say that that is covered by your general comments in the statement; I am not sure.
But then the Chairman took the chair and Senator O'Chee again sought to raise that point of order. He was supported by my colleague Senator Lewis. The Chairman said:

SPEECH.PARA: Order! There is no point of order.
I do not know what that meant because Senator O'Chee never got the chance to make his point. But then the Chairman went on to say:
If you wanted to raise that matter, you should have raised it at the time.
Whatever that might mean. The question, of course, is what time, because when you were in the chair at the previous time Senator O'Chee sought to take the point of order.
