PARA.TAB: I do not think that is the way in which the Chair should deal with individual senators. The issue left us with a rather sour taste after the events of the other day. We very reasonably expected an explanation as to why such expressions were made in relation to an honourable senator, but we did not get that in your statement, Mr President.

Depending on what might be the explanation for this course of conduct by the Chair, there are further actions that we may or may not wish to take. With regard to that first issue, therefore, I would respectfully suggest that the best way in which progress can be made would be for you to be prepared to take that away and give us a considered explanation as to why the Chairman responded to my colleague in such terms.

The second group of issues arises out of the substantial part of your statement which you have put down. You said earlier in the day that you do not wish that statement to be interpreted as a presidential ruling but rather as an explanation for your series of rulings on that day. On reflection, I accept that, Mr President. I think it could be argued either way but that is the way in which you have sought to handle the matter—to give an explanation for the decisions you made the other day rather than to provide decisions by this document. Of course, if that is your explanation, it does not attract the stature that, according to the precedents, a ruling of the President attracts; it simply explains why you reached those conclusions.

However, Mr President, as I indicated earlier, we are unhappy with a number of rulings that you made the other day. Your explanation gives us further reason for concern. I mentioned two matters earlier in the day. There are still outstanding issues in relation to the first of these items, that relating to contingent notices of motion. For example, I am not sure whether Senator Harradine's right to use a contingent notice of motion should be lost to him as a result of my moving a motion in similar terms or using the same type of contingent motion to move a motion in different terms. That is an issue. The use of these contingent notices of motion on multiple occasions within the one debate is an issue that should be referred to the Procedure Committee. That Committee can consider it, report back here, there can be an appropriate debate and, if the Standing Orders need to be changed, they can be.

The second point in the ruling by you, concerning the Chairman's ruling—as to whether we are entitled to debate the issue under standing order 145—should also be referred to the Procedure Committee. As I said, I would argue that, after the expiration of time under that particular standing order when you moved to the voting process, the guillotine had been completed. I do not see any argument that convinces me that the Standing Orders should not be paramount and that there should not be debate in terms of standing order 145. I am not even sure that before the guillotine has been completed the right to debate—as you may have said in this statement; the option of debate or some similar expression—is lost. That issue is one that should be referred to the Procedure Committee and dealt with in the same way.

The question on points of order should be dealt with similarly. As I said earlier, I believe, particularly after the guillotine is completed but even at any time, the standing order that gives honourable senators the right to rise at any time to take a point of order is paramount and should be respected. They have a right to ensure that debate is within the terms of the Standing Orders, and they have a right to stand and put that case. As you doubt that in the terms of your advice to us today, that matter should similarly be referred for further consideration and be brought back here at an appropriate time.

Mr President, in regard to the substantive matters in your paper, I think your recommended procedure of taking the matters to the Procedure Committee is right. I would just add one caveat in relation to the last option, that dealing with the right to take a point of order. As I recall the events of the other day, I objected to the fact that you and the Chairman were not taking those points of order and you said that you would take the matter away and consider it. Bringing it back today and saying that this is an opinion and not a ruling has, in effect, taken from me my right to dissent, which I think is unsatisfactory.

I am not making any point other than, hopefully, we might all gain from this experience. It really means that the other day I should have said, `Mr President, notwithstanding that you will take it away and give it some consideration, you have made a ruling and we dissent from it'. We should have taken that action there and then. Obviously we would not want to do that within the spirit of your saying that you would take the matter away and consider it. I just put that on the table because I think it is an unsatisfactory aspect of the matter, but I do not press it any further.

The third item in this package is the decision you have made in relation to the words used by Senator Gareth Evans when he referred to the Senate as a relatively useless institution. It seems to me that that is a ruling by you because you did not make it a decision on that occasion. You said you would take it away and would come back with a position on it. Your considered decision was that to refer to the Senate as a relatively useless institution is not to use words that are offensive against this House. We on this side of the chamber disagree with your interpretation in that regard and, therefore, during this debate we will move dissent from your ruling on that particular question.

I hope that the matter might be dealt with in that way. I put it constructively as a sensible way in which to deal with the three issues that are before us: first, the issue that we say is still outstanding; second, the issues that you have raised by means of your statement today, which we accept to be reasons justifying your decisions of the other day; and, third, what I think on any interpretation must be accepted as a ruling by you from which we have a right to dissent and from which we will dissent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I support everything that has been said by Senator Hill. In respect of the decision that you made denying a right of debate under standing order 145, your ruling then being in terms of standing order 198, I would have to say with the greatest respect that the most obvious and logical reading of the words clearly intend that debate shall take place prior to your deliberation. Frankly, it is pointless for you to arrive at a conclusion and then for us to have a debate following it. The words in standing order 145 clearly state:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and Senators having addressed themselves to it, shall be disposed of . . .

I am sure that it does not mean honourable senators would stand there and look very anxious; it means they would debate the issue. You then, Mr President, being imbued with the wisdom and knowledge which flows from those deliberations, are in a position to make some sort of judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will be waiting for a long time. You will be waiting 20 years.

—That is a very cheap and hurtful shot which does not do the honourable senator any good. Mr President, you quite properly referred to Odgers. I am always pleased when the Government refers to Odgers because it reinforces the view I have always held that he is an absolute authority in matters relating to the procedures.
—When he agrees with you.
—The same goes for the honourable senator.
—I would not publish that rubbish, no.
—I am interested to hear Senator Ray refer to the arguments that you, Mr President, used to reinforce your own ruling as rubbish.
—I said the source is.
—I do not know that there is any distinction between the source and the words.
—It should have been rewritten from scratch.

—I will come to that in a minute, Mr President. We all know the deep and abiding loathing that the Labor Party has for this chamber because it cannot believe that any chamber would be a States House and it cannot believe that any chamber ought to be able to have second deliberations. I find it quaint that the one Parliament the Labor Party has most to criticise is the unicameral system of Queensland, yet here, where we have got a Senate, the Labor Party spends all its time bitterly criticising it simply because of the Standing Orders of 1975. That is not the fault of Mr Odgers.
—You certainly used the upper House in New South Wales to block trade union Bills. You are quite happy to do that.
—And Greiner is quite happy to complain about it.
—Order!
—I am not distracted. I find it fascinating. Mr President, I notice that you, very sensibly and with persuasion to buttress your arguments, used the words of Odgers when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a practice of the Senate, when a decision of the Chairman of Committees is objected to, to permit Senators to address themselves to the question before the President gives a decision.
This, like everything Odgers writes, is eminently sensible and eminently practical. He continued:
The debate on an objection to a decision of the Chairman cannot be adjourned.

Odgers is telling us that it is obligatory to allow debate to take place prior to your ruling, not that we are not entitled to, which, with respect, is the view you held at the time. Mr President, on page 6 you say:
It may be argued that the President is under an obligation to do so when there is an order of the Senate that a bill must be dealt with within a limited time.

With the greatest respect, there is a temptation to say that that has a faint whiff of explanation and justification, rather than buttressing your argument. I support Senator Hill when he says that debate should have taken place at that time. That is a view which was also put by Senator Ray and Senator Collins.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you raised the matter of the constraints that the guillotine has on the exercise of Standing Orders. You referred to it particularly with respect to the contingent notice of motion and points of order. It is my view that, while the Standing Orders are silent on the matter, a practical application of common sense would hold that you would be debasing the intention of the Standing Orders and the intention of the guillotine if you were to allow a liberal interpretation of the contingent notices of motion to the point where they could totally frustrate the guillotine.

It is then argued whether Senator Hill has the right to move the only contingent notice of motion, or whether Senator Harradine and the Labor Party have the right to move contingent notices of motion. That begs the question as to what part the political parties have in the chamber in terms of their rights. I hold that that was never considered at the time that the Standing Orders were written, rather, the Standing Orders were intended for each individual senator and so it is sensible that we only have the right of one contingent notice of motion. There is no practical way that that could be compromised by suggesting that each political party ought to be able to have a shot. It is my view that once a contingent notice of motion has been moved, that is the only one. Mr President, you also refer to the ruling with respect to giving notice of motions of similar words inside six months.

With respect to points of order, it is a compelling argument that, once you have heard sufficient debate on the subject of a point of order, you are entitled to say that you have made up your mind and you need no further assistance from the Senate. That is always a fine point because you do not know what enlightened view will be proffered to you which might be compelling in a way which would have you change your mind. In terms of the practical application, it is sensible that the President says, `I have heard enough to be satisfied that I am in a position to make a determination'. If someone stands up and says, `I have a different point of view', that is in breach of Standing Orders because you have to dispose of each matter as it comes before you.

It is quite wrong, in my view, to suggest in any way that the guillotine inhibits the right of any senator at any time to take a point of order. I am certain it was never intended that the guillotine would prevent the ordinary functioning and exercising of rights by any senator. It requires certain motions to be put immediately and it does talks in terms of taking precedent over all other procedures, but it certainly was not intended to deny the right of senators to draw the President's attention to certain matters in the chamber, for instance, a quorum. Are we suggesting that we are unable to call a quorum because of the guillotine? That does not make sense to me. It would be quite wrong to suggest that the guillotine is that inhibiting.
The final matter is what Senator Hill has described as your ruling in respect of Senator Evans. It is no secret that the Labor Party, by and large, has a loathing for this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —And tradition generally.
—I was going to say for forms, style, dress and proper procedures.
—We eat babies too.
—Senator Ray eats babies, does he?
—We must; we do everything else wrong.
—The fact that Senator Ray loathes the Senate does not necessarily lead me to conclude that he eats babies as well, but that might be something he can tell us about when he speaks.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans repeated that which he has said before—it has been repeated every so often by Senator Walsh—about the general contempt of Government senators for the Senate. It is not only because of the events of 1975 but also because they do not basically believe that the Senate has a right to have the powers that it does. Senator Evans's frustration comes from the fact that he stood for the electorate of Jagajaga and was knocked off. He feels that with his intellect he is really denying the Australian people by being in the upper House.

The Standing Orders are quite clear when they talk about using offensive words against either House of the Parliament. It is offensive to talk about the chamber in the way that Senator Evans did. While you, Mr President, have ruled very sensibly in terms of offensive language that the words have to be seen in the context, the manner and the environment in which they were used to make a proper ruling—the same argument can be put with respect to offensive words being used against either House of the Parliament—I cannot think of an environment where it should be described as a relatively useless institution. I am not being sensitive about it. A sensible and logical reading of the words means that it is offensive—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let the lower lip tremble.

—If Senator Ray disagrees, he had better tell me what the words mean. Do we have to plant a hand grenade in the chamber? Do we have to put swastikas on the walls? What do we have to do to show offensive words against each House of the Parliament? I join my colleagues in suggesting that they were offensive words, that they are unnecessary and that your ruling, Mr President, deserves further consideration.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I wish to make one point in reply to what Senator Hill said and then to what Senator Crichton-Browne said. I do not regard the addendum to the statement as a ruling. I believe it is an explanation. I did not make a ruling then and

INTERJECT.PARA: I have not made a ruling now. I consider it to be one of the issues that the Procedure Committee would look at and bring back into this chamber. I want to put that clearly on the record now.

TALK.START.PARA: —For any set of—
—You're not closing the debate, are you?

—I did not start it, so I can hardly close it. For any set of standing orders to succeed, they need some good will and some common sense. The events of last Thursday afternoon showed very little of either. However, rather than just trying to be partisan—one side of the chamber against the other—we have to read the Standing Orders and try to have them applied consistently. Part of the difficulty with that is when we go back to past rulings. They are somewhat at variance with the actual plain English reading and interpretation that we would put on the Standing Orders. Quite clearly, the clearest example of that is Question Time. If we rigidly applied each of the points and prohibitions against questions, we would not have any. Both sides ask questions that skirt around and completely abridge those Standing Orders. We all agree with that process occurring, apart from when we want to interrupt the flow of the proceedings.
—The corollary of that is that you may as well throw away the Standing Orders.
—But these sorts of prohibitions have served both sides of the chamber at different times when we have been on different sides.
—It depends whether you have the numbers or not.

—Not even that. When the numbers were reversed those same sorts of prohibitions on questions existed, but we asked them just the same and those opposite answered them just the same when they were in government.
—But we answered more.
—That is what Senator Kemp says. If those opposite did not constantly interrupt we might get a better flow of debate.
—We interrupt because you rabbit on.

—Mr President, some people in this Opposition just want to interrupt all the time and not get down to a serious discussion on these issues. As I was saying, there is a small dichotomy between what is literally in the Standing Orders and what has been ruled in the past, and that is what you have tried to resolve here today.

PARA.TAB: Several points have been raised. Senator Hill first of all raised a point of order concerning Senator O'Chee. My understanding is that Senator O'Chee tried to get the call at the end of the division. The President, who was only in the chair to sit in on that division, was then required to leave the chair immediately. That is a fact. There is a subsequent argument as to whether Senator Colston should have recognised Senator O'Chee. That is a separate issue and I will come back to it in a moment.

Senator Hill had a contingent notice of motion that he could move and you, Mr President, ruled that only one such contingent notice of motion could be moved. That is a good ruling but it does have implications. It is a good ruling because if you did not rule that way, every single person around the chamber could put up a contingent notice of motion and frustrate anything. It comes back to who the Chair recognises and whether we have to put up contingent notices of motion to kill off contingent notices of motion. Then we get into a contingent notice of motion escalation that none of us can control.

However, at the same time, what is to say that when Senator Hill gets in first, that is fair on anyone else who has a contingent notice of motion that may go along another line? That is the difficulty we are going to have to confront. We must try, through commonsense, to work out what is fair and that applies to everyone well and truly now and into the future, so that it does not matter what side of this chamber we are on, there will be some fairness into the future.

The second point that Senator Hill raised is this question of debate under standing order 145. I come down in the middle a bit on this. I think a literal reading of the Standing Orders suggests that when the Chairman's ruling is dissented from, the President shall take the chair and he can—maybe he is impelled to by that Standing Order—listen to arguments on it. At the same time, if the first two precepts I have mentioned—no goodwill and no commonsense—have been shown, it is up to any government or any majority in this place immediately to gag the debate if they think it is just a delaying tactic.

It will not always be a delaying tactic. Sometimes the Chairman's ruling will be dissented from for very serious reasons and we will need to have a debate in this place before the President makes a final ruling. It is also possible that many of us could have drawn the conclusion that that three-hour shamble, that display of anarchistic elan that this institution showed, was deliberately engineered out of spite because we had a guillotine going.

It is not the first time this has happened. When I looked back through the records to see which of those opposite have voted for guillotines, I noted some of the dissent at the time from the Labor Party. It was pretty virulent stuff from Senator Georges and Senator Walsh, and they adopted similar sorts of tactics to disrupt and try to destroy. The only difference was that the other side had the numbers to gag at that stage, as well as guillotine, and ruthlessly did so.

When we go into the question of whether standing order 145 should be debated or not, a lot comes from peoples' motives for moving it. A literal reading suggests to me that debate may occur and I am not sure whether the President has discretion on it or not. Mr President, I can understand your ruling one way or the other on this particular issue. That should be sorted out, because dissent from a Chairman's ruling has a different effect from dissent from a President's ruling because standing order 198 has different provisions in it.

However, Mr President, it is certainly open to you to be addressed on the subject, then to make a ruling and then to trigger standing order 198. There is no question that you are able to do that under that standing order. The question is whether you have discretion to rule out debate in the first place. In the end, the discretion did not lie with you, Mr President, because the Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan) decided to take the events forward—and then abbreviate them very much, but at least we resolved them in that particular way.

Senator Hill raises a third point about the paramount right of honourable senators to take a point of order. This is something I cannot challenge; I always assumed it was thus. But there is another responsibility that goes with this. In the last few weeks the Chair has been put under inordinate pressure by people jumping to their feet saying `Point of order', and not raising procedural matters but just putting forward debating points.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Cook did today.

—Yes, I am coming to that. Senator Short, Senator Alston and Senator Teague have all done that recently. At least when Senator Bishop raises a point of order she usually quotes a standing order by number and tries to make it relevant to her point. When Senator Cook did it today, those opposite all jumped down his throat. They do not jump down the throats of their colleagues who have been doing it week in, week out. Those opposite are supposed to respect this institution. They are the ones who want to defend it and respect it, but they abuse it every day. Every time they jump up on a cynical, false point of order, they abuse this institution. They have the luxury of knowing that this institution is quite soft in discipline and there is very little chance they will ever get pulled up.
—Rubbish!

—When it is done in reverse, like Senator Cook did today, those opposite quite clearly and quite properly say there is no point of order, but they never say that when it is their own colleagues. It is this inconsistency and this lack of leadership on these matters that allows these procedures to continue.
—If you choose to abuse Question Time, you will suffer the consequences.

—We have threats now. It is typical of the small mentality of an individual opposite that we now have threats. Mr President, the question of whether points of order should be recognised is something which should be discussed here.
—How do you know what his point of order is if he does not get a chance to state it?
—If Senator Panizza wants to shout me down, he can do so. He can have his go.
—You're not bad at it yourself.

—I am pretty good at it, but I do not want to go to maximum decibels because people get annoyed when I do. Points of order should be recognised at all times, but the concomitant commitment to that is that false and bogus points of order must be dealt with. We all must deal with them and not just laugh when our own side does it and gets away with it and then abuse the other side for doing it. If those opposite respect this institution, and they say they do, and they jump up and take offence when anyone raises false points of order, why do they not practise it? Why do they not make this a better institution?
—Would you do that in the Labor Party? You would get expelled.
—Senator Lewis asks whether I do it. I do not jump up on false points of order. I never have and I never will. My points of order are always related to procedure.
—If someone else over there did it, would you back them?

—I am not asking Senator Lewis to be disloyal to his colleagues. I am not asking him to do anything in this chamber. Most of these things are done offshore when we come to some sort of agreement—on his side or our side or combined—to rectify weaknesses. I am not asking Senator Lewis to sell someone out in this chamber. None of us do that. We are all tribal enough and loyal enough not to do that. But those opposite must recognise that if they come in here and say that this institution should be respected and that this institution is a great one, and whatever else they argue, every time they breach the Standing Orders or stretch the envelope out in a different direction, away from the traditions of the institution, they are denigrating it.
—You're being totally hypocritical.

—I am trying to get a discussion going to get some common ground and all that Senator Baume can do is be abrasive. This has always been his cheap journalist style. He has always been the same. He will never ever change—just a bleating little individual there who thinks a lot of hot air and a lot of noise can in fact substitute—
—You have destroyed Question Time.
—We are not discussing Question Time now. One of Senator Baume's colleagues, who sits behind him, and I have, on other occasions, had debates on that.
—Yes, we are. This is the consequence of your corrupting Question Time.

—I see. What those opposite have said is, `We are at fault. Therefore, you will be at fault'. Then Senator Baume will come in here and moralise to me. That is his attitude. He comes in here and moralises because he believes that we are at fault.

PARA.TAB: The fourth issue raised by Senator Hill—that is, Senator Evans's comment—is, I think, an absolutely trivial one. All of those opposite are upset because he called the Senate a `relatively useless institution'. I suspect that a lot of people who, expecting to watch Question Time, saw the anarchistic effort that this Parliament House put on out of pure spite on that occasion—and then it got worse and worse—might come to the same judgment if those opposite are not very careful because it was not a very edifying spectacle.

The fact is that any Opposition or any group of individual senators can reduce this place to nothing by the misuse and abuse of the Standing Orders. I am not saying that that necessarily happened on that occasion. But because the atmosphere was fairly poisoned anyway as a result of the guillotine, extraordinary efforts were taken on that day to go through that sort of thing.

Senator Crichton-Browne raised a few points. He acknowledged the problem that contingent notices of motion potentially can have, and I agree with that. He said that every point of order should be dealt with. Of course, I agree with that. He and others have said that this should go to the Standing Committee on Procedure. Here I do have my doubts, I am sorry to say. I have been on the Procedure Committee—maybe this is the problem—since July 1981 or thereabouts. I think the Procedure Committee—how can I kindly put it?—has not been the most productive committee in that 10 years. It is sometimes regarded as a sort of fantasy object. When we cannot agree in this chamber, we say, `Let us refer it to the Procedure Committee'. Out it goes to the Procedure Committee, half the time never to reappear again.

The difficulty with that Committee—and I have to acknowledge that there are difficulties—is that many of the people on it are busy people. It has been hard to get common meeting times. We have tried dinner break meetings but there always seems to be problems, including food poisoning at times. We have tried to meet during sitting hours. That is not always possible because various people have appointments. Every decision has to be unanimous, and I must say that I agree with that; I think that is the sensible way to approach it, although occasionally we have even agreed to put in conflicting views and have them resolved in the chamber. But we should not hold our breath in the expectation that the Procedure Committee can solve all these problems, because some of them, such as contingent notices of motion, are almost not `soughtoutable'. Something that is practical and something that is fair are well and truly apart.

Senator Crichton-Browne went on to criticise Labor Party attitudes to the Senate or upper House institutions. This is very interesting. Dr Hewson tells us that he wants to get control of this chamber because he needs it to carry out his mandate. Then it will not be a House of review or a States House; it will just be a Liberal Party rubber stamp. It always is when one has the numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray, I have crossed the floor many times. How often have you crossed it?
—I do not have to. That proves absolutely nothing.
—When someone did, you expelled him.

—It proves absolutely nothing. If those opposite want to go back to the good old expulsion days, what about Charlie Francis and Jennings in Victoria? Those opposite turfed them straight out. They expelled them.
—That wasn't crossing the floor.

—Is not Senator Lewis a member of the Victorian branch? That branch happily expelled them, and there are many others in history. Constantly we hear the sorts of intonations of the Liberal Party President asking for more discipline—as well as staff to do head office work—in the Party. There are moves to discipline MPs; it happens all the time. Those opposite tritely come into this chamber and say, `We have a conscience vote, et cetera'. But what happens when the crunch comes? Six months after the bottom of the harbour legislation they all had a conscience and opposed retrospective legislation. But when their seats were on the line, apart from two or three, most of them voted for it. Two or three did not but the rest did. Then a few months later all of them said, `It is a matter of great principle and we cannot do this particular thing'. Look, we have been listening since 1981 to these trite allegations of the conscience of those opposite and all the rest. And they are still as ridiculous as ever.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has a talented frontbencher. It has a person who speaks his mind. Where is he today? He is not in this chamber because the Party dealt with him. The Party gave him the boot, and that happens constantly in the Liberal Party. If one is a rebel, one gets the flick and out one goes. We have no difficulty with those sorts of questions of party discipline or anything else. That is what we sign up for; that is what we agree with. Opposition members sign up for these things and as soon as someone such as Senator Lewis steps out of line and criticises a leader he gets thrown out of the team during the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has nothing to do with crossing the floor.

—It comes back to this attitude to the upper House. The Liberal Party's attitude is that it is a House of review when it is in opposition. But it pleads, it begs virtually, to get a majority when it thinks it will be in government. What is Mr Greiner's attitude to the upper House? What has Mr Greiner said about the Legislative Council in New South Wales? He has been scathing about it. I feel a bit of sympathy for poor old Nick Greiner, having a bunch of Independents, Fred Nile and the Democrats running around trying to chop up the Liberal Party's legislation. Of course it is frustrating there. It is frustrating here; it is frustrating for him. But different principles are involved. It is a fair thing for the Liberal Party here to use the numbers. It is terribly unfair for the Labor Party in New South Wales. It is appalling that it would do it. It is rank hypocrisy.
—Sit down.
—Senator Kemp will not tell me to sit down. I will stand up as long as I like—but I was actually about to conclude.
—What about talking some sense?
—Why does Senator Crane not fly south for the winter? He should go with the rest of the cranes. He has just arrived back in the chamber; I have not seen him for weeks.
—There is a good reason for that.
—I will not go into that. In summary on these issues, the question of—

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Senator Ray's comment deserves a point of order in that Senator Ray has reflected on my colleague Senator Crane, who has been absent from this chamber for very sound medical reasons. I find Senator Ray's comments quite snide and I ask you, Mr President, to ask him to withdraw an imputation that somehow Senator Crane was away from the chamber without proper excuse and cause.

—I was not inferring any such thing and, if I did, I withdraw any such inference. There was no such inference in what I said and Senator Bishop is very over-sensitive if she reads that into my remarks. I was about to sum up and conclude, if I can do so without too much interruption. The issues raised in Mr President's statement are important. The question of contingent notices of motion will be difficult to resolve simply because it involves two principles, both of which have merit. On the question of debate on standing order 145, it is clear that debate can be entertained provided the chamber is so disposed. If the chamber is disposed to gag the matter, it may do so, as it did last week. If Opposition senators wait until the end of the sentence instead of trying to interrupt, they would understand the meaning.

PARA.TAB: The third point is on the question of entertaining points of order. That should be done, I think, at all times, but it has another side of the coin, that they should be genuine points of order. Points of order with no substance—just argumentative points of order, meant to interrupt debate—should be dealt with seriously by the Chair. The final point is that if the sensitive souls opposite who object to the comments of Senator Evans cannot stand the heat in the kitchen they should pop outside.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to spend a great deal of time here but several issues need to be raised. Following on from what Senator Ray has just said, it is absolutely appropriate that in situations such as the one that we were in the other day the context is absolutely important. That context was one in which, as all honourable senators would know, the debate was initiated at 10 o'clock on the Tuesday morning and a time for the finishing of that debate was set at 7.30 on Wednesday night; within that time we were to deal with one Bill.

PARA.TAB: By any reasonable person's assessment, that was more than enough time to debate by a factor of three or four every issue which came up during that debate. As everyone in this chamber knows, so-called second reading debates are not debates at all. Everybody gets up and makes a completely set piece speech. At the end of that time, one gets involved in the committee stage, which is where the real debate occurs. If the Opposition were really concerned about debating those issues, it would have ensured that the maximum amount of time was available for the committee stage. What did the Opposition do? On the Tuesday it delayed from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why was it so urgent?
—Where was the urgency?

—If senators needed more time, why did they waste from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. taking points of order, suspending Standing Orders and moving other delaying motions? Quite clearly, we were under a process of filibuster by whatever means were at hand to delay the real debate on that important piece of legislation. That is the context that needs to be set firmly into the record.
—The record shows that the Democrats are political prostitutes; that is all.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I do not think referring to another political party as `political prostitutes' is normally allowed in debate. I ask Senator Campbell to withdraw.
—I think it would be better for the general running of the chamber if it were to be withdrawn. I ask that it be withdrawn.
—I feel strongly about it and I do not wish to withdraw it. I think it is a matter of fact.

—I ask Senator Campbell to reconsider his decision very carefully and think about the precedent that he is setting. On many occasions I ask people to withdraw and they do. I ask you again to reconsider what was said and to withdraw it.
—In deference to your office, Mr President, I withdraw.
—You should withdraw unconditionally.
—Mr President, I consider that an unconditional withdrawal.

—Senator Ray was talking about the consideration of the procedures in this place with some deference and some dignity, and the remark which has just passed indicates precisely where the Opposition comes from in important debates such as this.

PARA.TAB: In the context of the debate the other day, it must have been quite clear to you, Mr President, what was going on. There was no attempt to debate seriously the important aspects of this matter. Between midnight and about half past one on Wednesday morning, Senator Kernot and I were still looking at the Opposition's amendments. The Opposition did not really have its amendments ready, which was another reason for the delay which occurred. That brings me to a consideration of the techniques used, which are the substance of the President's statement. In referring to the suspension of Standing Orders, if every one of those contingency motions could be put sequentially, we could be here for a very long time.

It is possible for any senator to rise and speak for five minutes on the suspension of Standing Orders. Within that half hour debate, once that motion has been put, there is plenty of time for other people who have similar contingency motions on the Notice Paper to speak for five minutes and raise the points which they need to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to this motion. I believe that the Senate should adjourn at this stage. I do not think it is appropriate to negative the adjournment. The effect of negativing the adjournment tonight would suggest that we go on until we finish this matter. Unfortunately, I believe that this matter does need a good deal of consideration and that it would go on for a considerable time.

PARA.TAB: Over the last few weeks the adjournment has been negatived on a number of occasions. As a result, a good deal of pressure has been placed not only on the members of this Senate but also on the support staff, the people who very effectively support us: the clerks at the table, the people who serve us in the Table Office, the attendants and the staff in the transport section—a whole range of people.

This is the situation we have to face. We cannot constantly be negativing the adjournment. I do not think it is appropriate to wait until somebody drops dead from a heart attack or suffers considerable medical problems as a result of stress. To wait for that to occur—

TALK.START.PARA: —If people are that sensitive, maybe they are in the wrong job.

—I was selected in 1975 and took my seat in January or February 1976. I can well recall the situation at that time when Senator Ivor Greenwood was Attorney-General. I believe the long hours which Senator Ivor Greenwood worked contributed to his untimely death. He was only a relatively young man. I have heard the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) suggest that, if we do not like the hours we work here, we should get out and get some other job. I do not believe that view should be countenanced. I think there should be some civilised approach to the proceedings here, some civilised hours adopted.

PARA.TAB: I do not mind. I suppose in terms of fitness, I am as fit as the next man or woman around the place. But I do believe that there are people here who could suffer and are suffering as a result of the long hours that we spend in this chamber. We not only spend long hours in this chamber, we are all on committees and have a considerable workload on those committees. I believe it is unfair, particularly to the people who do not have a say as to whether the Senate adjourns or not. They are the people I mentioned initially.

For that reason, on this occasion I believe that we should vote for the Senate to adjourn. I do not know, nor do the people for whom I am speaking know, how long this debate will take. My own view is that this matter ought to be debated at a suitable time and then sent, as has been said, off to the Procedure Committee for a report back in due course, which must be some time next year. Why should we debate this matter for an hour or 1 1/2 hours when it will have to come back to us in any case next year?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, want to speak to the motion that the Senate now adjourn. I want to do so specifically because Senator Harradine has raised some very important points. First of all, he is arguing that it is more important to adjourn now and go home than to look at a question which I think is a fundamental one. It was said earlier in the day that once a ruling has been made by you, Mr President, it then has the effect of an order of the Senate. We are placed in the position where, in good faith, we accepted your suggestion that you go away and consider a number of matters and come back and report to the Senate in a statement, which you have delivered today.

PARA.TAB: You now deny that anything contained in this document called `Statement by Mr President' in fact amounts to a ruling in any way, shape or form and you claim it is merely an explanatory statement. We then had something called an addendum which, quite frankly, I do not think warrants that title at all; I think the addendum stands alone and I will deal with that in just a moment. It is a completely separate document. Going back to the Hansard of 5 December, at page 4251, you said:

SPEECH.PARA: Order! I am on my feet. In reply to Senator Teague's point of order, again it occurred when I was not in the chair. I will investigate it. I will take it in conjunction with the other points of order that were raised and I will report back.

I took that statement—as I would say most people in this chamber did—as your undertaking that you would come back and make a ruling. There is a piece of paper that represents that ruling and, as such, is subject to be dissented from.

PARA.TAB: I return to the document called `Statement by Mr President'. I think that in the course of the ridiculous situation when Mr Chairman was in the chair and we witnessed the farce of the way in which he ruled, we had the dissent from his ruling and the changing of Chairs and who was advising whom, the whole question of the advice that was given and your interpretation of it got in so deep that this document really represents some sort of justification for the behaviour that occurred on that occasion. I think it is too important to allow it to stand. On the question of the contingent notices of motion, I think the action—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, I would also like to take part in this debate, but we are on the adjournment. It is not possible to continue the debate that was taking place prior to the adjournment. I did not take Senator Harradine's remarks as being a continuation of the debate.
—I ask that you put the motion again as to whether the Senate adjourns.
—We are debating the adjournment.
—But you cannot debate the matter that was before the Chair.

—We can debate whether it is suitable for us to adjourn now or whether we should determine a matter which is of fundamental importance to the way this chamber is run. If we are not going to pay any attention to the Standing Orders, then why do we not put a big bin in the middle of the floor and cast all of the copies of the Standing Orders into it and set fire to them; that is the way we seem to be proceeding? I think it is quite acceptable and proper—and I am sure you will rule that way—for us to put the point of view that we ought not to adjourn now, but that we ought to determine this matter, simply because the assertion has been made that, if we do not, we are stuck with what purports to be a ruling; and that is not acceptable.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROCEEDINGS ON POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES LEGISLATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to go on and contrast the guillotine and the gag. I would understand the consternation which the Opposition has expressed if, in fact, the gag had been applied and there had been an attempt to use various other tactics under those circumstances.

PARA.TAB: On this occasion there was a clear, predetermined time for the finish of the debate, which was determined two days beforehand, and the techniques which were being used were being used against that knowledge. Clearly honourable senators themselves were using up the time which was available to them—more than enough time to adequately debate this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, if one were to dissent from your document and to argue that endless points of order, endless contingency motions and other devices can be used to prevent the application of the guillotine—in other words, a predetermined period for the adequate debate of a piece of legislation—then, as Senator Bishop said a moment ago, one could throw all the Standing Orders into a heap in the middle of the room and burn them because this chamber would become absolutely unworkable.

To use Senator Crichton-Browne's term of a few moments ago, it seems passing quaint that the Opposition, which pretends that it will form the next government, should be going down this road and imposing those sorts of conditions on itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Principle.

—Senator O'Chee cannot give me that sort of nonsense about principle. There was nothing to do with principle in the debate the other night. It was a filibustering exercise, and there is no other word for it. We wished to debate the issue and we were given very little time to do so by the filibustering practices of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: A moment ago Senator Bishop said by way of interjection—and it is a standard remark from people from the hard Right like Senator Bishop—that if you cannot stand the heat, get out of the kitchen. I was pleased to hear Senator Harradine pick her up and point out, quite correctly, that if the heat in the kitchen is becoming intolerable, perhaps it is an inhuman environment and we should do something about that rather than simply chuck people out.

Whilst I voted against Senator Harradine, because I hoped that this matter could be concluded fairly quickly, nonetheless I thoroughly object to that tough, uncompromising and unfeeling sort of remark that we heard from Senator Bishop. I would strongly support the document which you put before us this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I do not wish to go on at length and I do not wish to canvass the matters that are in the statement that you brought down. I stand by them, especially in reference to anything that I carried out during the course of that debate. I also stand by them in relation to the matters that relate to you, Mr President.

PARA.TAB: I want to take a small amount of the time of the Senate to mention one matter referred to tonight in relation to the point of order made by Senator O'Chee. I will not canvass the rights or wrongs of the matter that was raised or try to rule on the matter that Senator O'Chee raised. It was mentioned that at one stage I said:

SPEECH.PARA: If you wanted to raise that matter, you should have raised it at the time.

Senator Hill asked what I meant by `the time'? If we cast our minds back to that particular time in the debate, one would understand that things were going rather rapidly. I suppose if it had not been going so rapidly I would have said, `You should have voted at the time that the particular proceeding arose'.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order—
—What the devil are you talking about, Goldilocks?
—I find this a most peculiar system where—
—Withdraw that. Just withdraw it.
—What did he say?
—If you did not hear it, it does not offend you.
—What did he say? I want to know because other people heard. I have heard that before. What did he say? Mr President, what was said?
—On a point of order, Mr President: this sort of conduct is totally out of order and I would ask you to bring Senator Bishop into line.
—Order! We are in a difficult situation—
—Sit down. What he said was unparliamentary.
—And so is that.
—Order!
—I withdraw the comment.

—Mr President, I want your guidance on this curious procedure. You have told us in your explanatory memorandum, as you call it, that you are the person who made the rulings that are a determining factor. Now we have the Chairman, or a senator—
—What number?

—I am asking for the President's guidance as to the proper procedures. We have a Presiding Officer who has said he is making the determination, yet we have the man against whom the dissent was moved, standing up to give an explanation of his own behaviour. Mr President, either you are finally responsible for the decision that was made or, alternatively, the Chairman is. Which is it? It cannot be both.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The very first paragraph of the statement says:

INTERJECT.PARA: This statement covers the question raised with Senator Colston, and he concurs with the statement.
I am sure that he is entitled to speak on it. Everybody else would take the point that they are entitled to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was speaking about the particular matter which was raised when I replied to Senator O'Chee:

SPEECH.PARA: If you wanted to raise that matter, you should have raised it at the time.

I said that everything was going rather rapidly at the time. Had it not been going so rapidly, I suppose I should have said, `You should have raised it at the time that the proceedings which you objected to arose'.

PARA.TAB: Looking at page 4241 of the Hansard, we see there the statement that was made by Senator Gareth Evans in relation to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened next? What about Senator Vanstone's attempt to take a point of order?

—I am speaking about the point of order raised by Senator O'Chee. That is the matter on which I have been criticised this evening. Nothing has been said in relation to the point of order raised by Senator Vanstone.

PARA.TAB: I will say it again. The statement made by Senator Gareth Evans appears on page 4241 Then we turn to 4242 where there is a lot of debate and, on page 4243, more debate. There is more debate and a division of the Senate on page 4244; and on page 4245 more debate and a division of the Senate. It takes from page 4241 to page 4246 for Senator O'Chee to raise his point of order. The point of order that Senator O'Chee raised just as you left the chair, Mr President, is recorded on page 4246.

That is what I meant when I said, `You should have raised the matter at the time'. Goodness me, there must have been five to 10 minutes between the two events. If the Senate decides that sufficient time has not gone by and that a person can still raise a point of order, that is fine.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is incredible. The Opposition wanted to take the point of order.

—I did not deny Senator O'Chee taking a point of order. He took a point of order when we went into committee. All I am saying is that if we look at precedent, we see that a point of order must be taken at the time when the proceedings objected to arise. It cannot be raised later.

PARA.TAB: If the Senate decides that a period of five or 10 minutes is still enough to take a point of order on some proceedings that occurred, that is fine. The point I am making is that I did not believe it was made at the time the proceedings occurred. That is why I made that comment there.

TALK.START.PARA: —An absolute disgrace.

—I am deeply concerned that when I get up to make an explanation all I get is criticism by way of interjection. If there is criticism, that is fine; that can go back to the Procedure Committee. I can see that the Procedure Committee will have a nice time over the Christmas recess. If it has to go back to the Procedure Committee, it can make a determination on whether a person can take a point of order on a proceeding that happened five or 10 minutes previously. If we have a look at the precedent set by Senator Givens on this particular matter, the proceedings were quite different from the ones we are talking about tonight. I still think that that precedent holds. If the Senate decides that points of order can be raised five, 10 or 15 minutes later, that is fine, let us put it in the Standing Orders so that we all know where we stand. Until we know where we stand, the Chairman has to take the sort of action that he did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, but there are a couple of points that I think need addressing. As I said earlier today, there are two elements in this statement: first of all, justification of the events that occurred on Thursday; and, secondly, matters that are properly the concern of the Procedure Committee. I share Senator Robert Ray's views about the Procedure Committee. The progress there is extremely glacial, but we do have to live by a rule of law; we do need to have Standing Orders. I view it as an act of noblesse oblige that some of us serve on that Committee and put up with the tedium of it. Difficult as it is to come to agreement within the Procedure Committee—
—Order! Senator MacGibbon, it has been drawn to my attention that you did speak before the suspension of the sitting. If you wish to speak again you will have to seek leave.
—I seek leave.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for that courtesy. As I was saying, it is infinitely better that the matters are discussed in the Procedure Committee, to the tedium of its members, rather than bringing it to the chamber. As we know, bringing changes to Standing Orders into the Senate itself is a very difficult procedure.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter spoke and made a characteristic contribution to the debate. I go back to the time when I was a student: the line of argument he was using was always described in those days as `situation ethics'. That related to someone who had no morality but just judged the circumstances at the time according to the way that events impacted upon him or her. There was no right or wrong; it just depended on how it affected one at the time. One derived his or her own moral standards from that.

I support what Senator Hill and Senator Crichton-Browne have said. I would like to pick up the approach of Senator Robert Ray. I agree with much of what he said. We need to apply a little bit of commonsense to this matter. The first thing in relation to commonsense is that the Senate is master of its own destiny. We can make up the rules of debate and procedures as it suits us. We look to precedent only as a guide. There is certainly no obligation on the Senate to follow precedents all the time because we are not a court of law and we do not have to be bound by previous rulings that have been made by Presidents in times gone by when the numbers and the circumstances of the Senate were really quite different.
One particular point of difference I have with your statement, with the greatest respect, Mr President, relates to standing order 145. Standing order 145 says in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . before the President, and Senators having addressed themselves to it . . .

Unlike Senator Ray, I do believe that part is obligatory; that no other interpretation can be accepted other than that there has to be debate by senators, if they wish to address the matter which led to the removal of the Chairman from chairing the Committee of the Whole. With the greatest respect, I do not believe that was done in the way the standing order is written and implies.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I refer to contingency motions. In my judgment, the Standing Orders do not mean that only one contingency motion can be moved when a Bill has been declared urgent. Again, as Senator Ray said, the conduct of the chamber can be taken out by a wilful senator from the majority view, whether that be the Government or the Opposition. I think there has to be a degree of judgment as to whether someone is moving in a way to disrupt the intention of the majority of senators or whether someone is using the calling on of a contingency motion to deny the legitimate use of it in a later part of the debate. I recognise that that is a very difficult proposition to resolve. We certainly will not resolve it here tonight; it is a matter for endless hours in the Procedure Committee.

Thirdly, I refer to points of order. I do not believe that points of order can be denied. The right to raise points of order is a fundamental right of debate. I do not find it a valid interpretation of standing order 142 that there is a prohibition when urgency has been declared. I recognise, of course, the right of the Chair to cut short points of order if they are repetitive.

Coming to the whole area of vexatious points of order, there is no doubt in my mind that standing order 203 gives the Chair the absolute power to control the use of frivolous, vexatious or destructive points of order. There is no question in my mind that if senators persistently and wilfully obstruct the business of the Senate by moving irrelevant, fictitious or foolish points of order they ought to be named and removed by the President or whoever is in the chair. I think that remedies exist in the Standing Orders at the present time.

What upset honourable senators on this side of the chamber more than anything else was the fact that certain senators stood and were denied the call during the period in dispute which led to your paper having to be written. As I said earlier, I believe that the Chair has the right to cut short points of order. If an appeal has been made and the President has made up his mind that there is not a valid point of order, he has the right to deny other senators from debating the same point of order. But it has always been a matter of courtesy and custom for the Chair to ask the senator, `Do you have the same point of order?'. That means that senators are recognised and have an opportunity, very briefly, to say why they are on their feet. If that is not done, this chamber becomes absolutely unworkable. If a senator rises in his or her place, is not recognised and is completely ignored, we simply cannot operate. That is the real heart of the matter. That is why we are discussing this tonight—honourable senators rose and were not called.

Finally, I do not want to spend much time talking about Senator Ray's defence of Senator Evans's position that the Senate is not a respectable and responsible chamber. I found it absolutely astonishing that Senator Ray could protest about the Liberal Party trying to have a majority in the Senate and implying, at the same time, that the Labor Party went into elections without the will to win and win a majority in the Senate. That is absolute nonsense and humbug. I can remember a time in the mid-1940s when the Labor Party held 32 out of 36 Senate positions. To my great pride, those four positions which it did not hold came from my State of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three.

—I stand corrected. It was such an imbalance that it led to the proportional representation system under which the Senate operates, which was introduced by a Labor government. With those few words, I cease my comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think you should be congratulated on the statement you have made. I will make some points about it. First, I refer to what Senator MacGibbon said. I agree with him entirely that the Senate is master of its own destiny. That is absolutely true. I do not think anyone would seriously argue with that proposition. On the night that standing order 145 came before us, it was dealt with by a motion from Senator McMullan. There has been considerable criticism of what he did; that is, he moved that the question now be put.

PARA.TAB: Once the Parliamentary Secretary had moved that the question be put, the Senate did become a master of its own destiny and decided by a majority that the question be put and that there be no more argument, under standing order 145. Had that question not been put, I agree that under standing order 145 honourable senators would have had an opportunity to address themselves to the issue. Once the closure has been moved, that is overridden.
The issue of points of order arises under chapter 31 of Senate Standing Orders and Other Orders of the Senate. The overriding rule in that chapter is standing order 184(1), which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Order shall be maintained in the Senate by the President.

Your overriding duty, Mr President, is to maintain order. There is a series of orders setting out how you might do that. One of those concerns raising a point of order. A point of order is a point raised legitimately by a senator to help you maintain order in this House. I do not want to refer to any particular point of order that may have been raised over the last few weeks, but a point of order is a procedure which should be a shield for the way that this Senate is conducted. It should be a shield for the proper running of this place. It should be a shield for our privileges. When it is used as an offensive weapon so that it becomes a means of disrupting procedure for whatever motive, whether it be a good motive or not—if it becomes a procedure for obtaining a political or personal advantage or any other sort of advantage—then it very much becomes an issue as to whether it has been legitimately used and whether the order that it arises from, order 197, is overridden by the provisions of order 184.

PARA.TAB: There is another point I wish to raise about order 197. Subsection (5) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The President may hear argument on the question, and may determine it forthwith, or at a later time, at the President's discretion.

There is no obligation on you, Mr President, to hear argument. You should not use that order as a means of dismissing any argument, but it is in your judgment that the order of this chamber rests. If you make a judgment, it is incumbent upon the Senate to accept that or to take the proceedings which are set out in Standing Orders and Other Orders.

PARA.TAB: Chapter 2 is a very significant chapter. It sets out how a President is to be elected, how a ballot is to be conducted and how Presidents should conduct themselves. I have a feeling that the chamber as a whole—I do not pick out any side of the chamber—has not given you, Mr President, the support that you are entitled to and which is contemplated by these Standing and Other Orders in recent times. The Senate Daily Hansard for Thursday, 5 December 1991, particularly from page 4238 on, is hardly an edifying record of what happened on that occasion. We have a heavy responsibility, not only to this chamber and our parties but also to the electorate as a whole. As senators, and politicians generally, we do not do ourselves justice in terms of our parties or the system in the way we sometimes act.

Mr President, it is my proposition that you have prepared a document which should form the basis for an improvement in the way we have conducted ourselves here. The matters that you have sent to the Procedure Committee should be treated seriously, but overall the matter comes back to whether or not we as a Senate are willing to accept not only the letter but also the spirit of chapter 31 to give the President the proper help that he deserves and to go on from there.

The last issue in that context is the question of contingent notices of motion. I think they are a very legitimate procedure, but again the order of the Senate cannot be helped if a whole array of contingency motions can be passed one after another. That would not help the proper running of the Senate which, after all, is the responsibility of us all and the responsibility of you in particular, Mr President, and because it is your particular responsibility you need help from this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney is quite correct in saying that senators do not do any good to the chamber or to themselves if they misbehave. The Standing Orders exist and senators have a right to raise a point of order to ensure the good conduct of the chamber and also to assist the President in observing and enforcing the rules. This brings me, therefore, to a very important point, one raised by Senator Colston this evening. In attempting to defend what he did or did not do on Thursday, 5 September, Senator Colston raised the allegation that I did not attempt to rise on a point of order immediately Senator Evans claimed that the Senate was a useless institution.
—I did not say that at all, and you know it.

—I listened to the honourable senator in silence and he can listen to me in silence. Not only did Senator Vanstone rise to that point of order, but a number of other Opposition senators rose to that point of order as well. It is a fact that Hansard records only Senator Vanstone saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Point of order. Point of order.
Whereupon you, Mr President, said:
Order! Resume your seat, Senator Vanstone.
On a number of other occasions I attempted to raise this point of order. On each occasion—

TALK.START.PARA: —And Labor senators jeered at you.

—And Labor senators jeered at me. It was well known in this chamber that I was attempting to raise a point of order. On numerous occasions other points of order were raised by other colleagues, but at no time did I have the opportunity to put this particular point of order in relation to Senator Evans's conduct. That does not mean that I was not intent on raising the point of order and that certainly does not mean that I was not on my feet attempting to do so. The fact that I was not standing here screaming at the top of my voice is the reason why it was not recorded in Hansard. For the good conduct of this chamber I was patient and observed the Standing Orders and rose in my place. It was only out of frustration, having failed to get the call to raise a point of order before a division, that I attempted to raise a point of order, recorded at page 4246, when I called to you:

SPEECH.PARA: On a point of order, Mr President. Mr President!

But you had vacated the chair. I then attempted to raise it again in the committee stage. It was clearly a matter that I had been attempting to raise a number of times. Senator Button interjected across the chamber and Labor senators continued to jeer. I was standing on my feet raising a matter that I had been trying to raise for a time, and that reflected upon the dignity and good conduct of this chamber. I was very upset that Senator Colston, then the Chairman—

TALK.START.PARA: —Gratuitously.
—Gratuitously, indeed, said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no point of order. If you wanted to raise that matter, you should have raised it at the time.
I do not know what an honourable senator is to do in this chamber if he wishes to enforce the Standing Orders and do so without lowering the demeanour and good conduct of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —And that set off the whole issue.

—That created the problem, as Senator Baume said, because then Senator Teague again tried to raise this point of order and the Chairman would not recognise him. In fact, Senator Teague tried on three occasions and eventually the Chairman said:

SPEECH.PARA: If we have spurious points of order, I will deal with the senators concerned.
But he did not take the point of order; in fact, he ignored Senator Teague. That started an exchange with Senator Baume.

PARA.TAB: Page 4247 shows that Senator Alston rose to raise, I assume, the same point of order. We will never know, because Senator Colston did not take the point of order. The exchange that went on is interesting. Senator Alston got up and said, `Pursuant to standing order—', and he was cut off by the Chairman who said, `Order! You do not have the call'. Senator Alston said, `Well, I am seeking the call'. The Chairman said, `Senator Alston, you do not have the call'. Senator Alston said, `Mr Chairman!', and Senator Colston replied, `I am putting the question that the remaining amendments circulated by the Government be agreed to'. With Senator Alston still protesting, the matter went to a vote. Immediately after the vote, Senator Colston vacated the chair with at least three Opposition senators still on their feet trying to raise this point of order.

Very clearly, not only I, but also many of my colleagues on this side of the chamber, did everything in our power to ensure that the dignity of this Senate was preserved, yet we were thwarted and frustrated. That is a matter of grave concern to me. I suppose the defence that Senator Colston must now rely upon is the fact that the Committee was operating under a guillotine. But the guillotine, as laid down in standing order 142, does not preclude the taking of points of order and, indeed, never has. Nor does the guillotine preclude a procedural motion being put. Rather, it says that certain questions shall be put forthwith. It does not say, `immediately and to the exclusion of all other matters before the chamber'. It is interesting to see exactly what it does say. Standing order 142(4) says:

For the purpose of bringing to a conclusion any proceedings which are to be brought to a conclusion on the expiration of the time allotted under any motion passed under the provisions of this standing order, the President or the Chairman shall at the time appointed put forthwith the question on any amendment. . .

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on to list a number of matters. It further states:
and any other question requisite to dispose of the business before the Senate or committee, and no other amendments, new clauses or schedules shall be proposed.

It is very clear from the wording of that paragraph of standing order 142 that it does not preclude the taking of points of order, nor does it preclude the moving of a procedural motion which relates to the disposal of the business before the Senate. In fact, it only specifically precludes three types of motions being put: motions relating to amendments, new clauses or schedules. They are the only things that cannot be put at that stage. Clearly, one can rise on a point of order and, clearly, one can move a procedural motion. That applies whether the Senate is in the Committee of the Whole or is sitting as the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The best exposition of this comes from something which occurred on 14 September 1972. This is interesting. The wording of standing order 142(1) in relation to a matter being declared urgent is almost the same as the putting of a Bill or clauses upon the guillotine falling. Standing order 142(1) says:

SPEECH.PARA: a Minister may declare that a bill is an urgent bill, and move that the bill be considered an urgent bill, and such motion shall be put forthwith without debate or amendment.
That is almost identical wording. The important thing is that the motion be put forthwith.

PARA.TAB: On 14 September 1972, a motion was moved by Senator Greenwood that a particular Bill be considered urgent. A number of points of order followed and there was an objection to the ruling of the President. There was a full debate on that. Half an hour or three-quarters of an hour later, the matter was finally resolved and the Senate proceeded with the Bill. Clearly, the same provision in standing order 142(1) applies to standing order 142(4). It is unsatisfactory to say that just because there is a guillotine there can be no further points of order and no procedural matters.

I conclude by discussing the matter of contingent notices of motion. It has been argued that it is not possible to move a second contingent notice of motion in this chamber when a guillotine has fallen on a Bill, a first contingent notice of motion having been used. I assume that is based upon the proposition that the same question is not to be proposed twice. But there is a difference between one contingent notice of motion and another. Certainly a contingent notice of motion may replicate a previous one in moving a procedural motion relating to a Bill which is substantially the same as the previous procedural motion, and it would be improper to have that considered again.

For example, upon the falling of the guillotine, it would be improper to first move that the time allotted be extended for 10 minutes and then use a contingent notice of motion to move that the time allotted be extended for 15 minutes, the first contingent notice of motion having failed. Indeed, if it is something like that, it is appropriate that the contingent notice of motion be amended. But it is a completely different matter to say, if a motion has been moved that the time allotted for consideration of a Bill be extended for 10 minutes and that has been concluded and resolved in the negative, that it is not proper to say that honourable senators are precluded from moving pursuant to a contingent notice of motion that the Bill be referred to a committee. That is a completely different matter. It is substantially different. I think that should weigh in your mind, Mr President.

In conclusion, on this side of the chamber, there is no satisfaction with the handling of the points of order nor, indeed, is there any satisfaction with Senator Evans's remarks which not only are contrary to standing order 193(3) but also are a contempt of the Senate and should be dealt with at least by Senator Evans's withdrawal, if not by further measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief as there are only two areas I want to speak to. I am sure Senator Cooney has missed the point we were making. On taking points of order, Senator Cooney referred to standing order 197(2) which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A Senator may draw attention at any time to a point of order or a matter of privilege arising in the proceedings then before the Senate.
Then Senator Cooney referred to standing order 197(5) which states:
The President may hear argument on the question, and may determine it forthwith, or at a later time, at the President's discretion.

We have no argument about that at all. The point we are making on this side of the House is that the Chair at no stage recognised the senator on his feet. I have only to turn to page 4246 of Hansard when Senator Teague was attempting valiantly to take a point of order to illustrate this. At the time Senator Colston was in the Chair and he said:
Order! The Committee will come to order.
Senator Teague, who was on his feet, said:
Mr Chairman—
The Chairman ignored him completely and said:
The time for consideration of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill has now expired—
Senator Teague said:
Mr Chairman—
The Chairman said:
The question is that the remaining amendments circulated by the Government be agreed to.
He completely ignored Senator Teague, who was on his feet. Senator Teague said again:
Mr Chairman—
The Chairman said:
Order! I intend to do what the Senate and the Committee require me to do and that is to put the questions that are before us.
Senator Teague said again:
Mr Chairman—
The Chairman said:
If we have spurious points of order, I will deal with the senators concerned.

At no stage did the Chairman call Senator Teague by name or refer to him or acknowledge the fact that he was on his feet. The Senate cannot work in that fashion. Every senator in this place has certain rights. I agree with Senator Cooney that it is a matter on which the President can make a decision and say, `I do not want to hear any more points of order', but at least he says, `Senator Teague, I have made a decision, I do not want to hear any more points of order'. He does not ignore Senator Teague's existence while he is on his feet. That is the point that we on this side of the chamber have been attempting to make.

PARA.TAB: The second minor point that I would like to mention concerns standing order 145. Senator Ray, in his speech tonight, deliberately misread the standing order, which says in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . The matter having been laid before the President, and Senators having addressed themselves to it. . .
Not `may', as Senator Ray said, but very definitely an obligation. That is another area where we disagree.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ray adopts a supposedly laid back, `you know, we all do this sort of thing' attitude. But this side of the chamber has totally different party rules from the Government. Let me make it perfectly clear: I have crossed the floor four times in my career and never once have I been reprimanded in any way. My selection was never, at any time, threatened. The only person from the other side of the chamber whom I have ever seen cross the floor was Senator Georges. He was thrown out because he dared to have the courage to do what has been done on this side of the chamber so many times. One of my colleagues from Tasmania, former Senator Wright, must have crossed the floor on 50 occasions; at no stage was his selection ever threatened and at no stage was he ever reprimanded.

It has to be recognised, not only by the Labor Party but also by the Democrats, that we behave totally differently from the way they do. The Democrats are a fairly new party; I do not think any of them were here when we were in government. They do not have a clue about how we behaved when we were in government. We never behaved like lap-dogs to the Ministers as we see back bench Labor members performing today. When we were in government, no Minister ever dared to hand us dorothy dix questions. We would not have accepted them; we would have considered them an insult. But we have never heard anything else in Question Time from the Government back bench—nothing is ever put up by backbenchers that is original and might be a bit tricky for Ministers. Dorothy dixers are all we ever get. Now is not the time to expand further on what Senator Ray tried to get across. He was just so totally wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there are only three points that I wish to make this evening. I will be brief, as my colleagues have been, because I think the points have been well made by other speakers. The first matter I wish to address is whether a senator seeking the call to raise a point of order should at least get the call.
