I agree with many other speakers who have said that you, Mr President, or whoever is in the chair at the time, have the right, if not the obligation, in order to conduct the place properly, to alert the chamber to the fact that you have made a decision and you regard yourself as needing no further assistance in that respect. At that time, I think it is fair enough to call the chamber to order and say that you are ready to rule on the point of order and do not need further assistance.

PARA.TAB: I agree that, after that time, a senator seeking the call on that point of order may have to miss out, and in fact should miss out if you have had all the assistance you need. Of course, that is not the point that has been raised by the failure to call Senator O'Chee, which could easily have been raised as the failure to call me or a number of other people who were raising a point of order on that day. It is quite a separate matter.

As I recall, anyway, none of these refusals to see a senator standing and calling a point of order related to a continuing commentary on a point of order that had already been raised but rather to the desire to raise a point of order. I would have been interested to hear what Senator Colston or you, Mr President, might have had to say. I do not recall who it was and I think sometimes the Hansard just records `Mr President' if either one of you is in the chair, though I am not sure. In any event, I wished to raise a point of order and was told to sit down.

I do not say that I have never raised a point of order that could not properly be described as one. But I do say that people could hardly characterise me as someone who frequently raises improper points of order in order to disrupt this chamber. That would be one of the last descriptions which could be applied to me. Other descriptions of a much less attractive and more insulting nature than that could be applied, but that one would be unfair. I am therefore at a loss to understand why, when I stood on my feet to raise a point of order, I was told to sit down without even getting the opportunity to say what the point of order was. This did not happen only to me; it happened to others.

The importance of this is that it does not matter where we are in the debate—whether we have a guillotine or a gag or whatever—if proceedings are not being conducted properly, any senator should have not only a right but also an obligation to bring the impropriety in the proceedings to your attention, Mr President, by using the Standing Orders. Whether we are acting under a gag or a guillotine—it does not matter what we are doing—we have to do it by virtue of the Standing Orders. That one standing order allowing a senator to stand in his or her place and raise a point of order actually gives the person in the chair a right of access, if you like, to the views of all the senators in the chamber and alerts the Chair to when something may not be in accordance with the Standing Orders. For that reason, it is a very dangerous precedent to just barge through proceedings and not give the call to a senator who has sought it—ab initio, if you like—to raise a point of order.

Secondly, as to the right to speak when a Chairman's ruling has been disagreed with, a number of speakers have made the point that the standing order indicates that, when the matter has been addressed by senators, the President can make a ruling. Mr President, I understand that you were advised or had decided that you could come in, you could make a ruling and then any dissent from your ruling would be dealt with under the other standing order.

With the greatest respect, I disagree with that as the appropriate course of action. I think the reason for there being two separate standing orders is so that a disagreement with your rulings can be dealt with under one and a disagreement with the Chairman's rulings can be dealt with under the other. The standing order dealing with the Chairman's rulings makes it quite clear that there is an expectation that debate will take place. Senator Cooney, quite wisely, I think, says he agrees with that proposal. But, he says, Senator McMullan saved us from that.

There are two things I want to say about that. Firstly, Senator McMullan in a sense saved us—or you, Mr President—from being in the position of having gone down that path of not having allowed debate. He did that by inferring—and I do not think I am doing him a disservice here—that he understood the desire for debate and he understood the desire to deal with the issue under the relevant standing order. The inference was that it was so that debate could take place. I do not think I am alone in coming to that conclusion. It was because of his having created that inference that leave was granted for him to move the relevant motion that he did. Having moved it, he then, appropriately, moved the gag.

I for one will not now agree to do anything Senator McMullan wants, unless the detail of what will happen following that, and following that, and following that, is spelt out so that we know exactly where we are going. I took his actions to be as close to deceptive to the chamber as we can get. As I say, he gave the inference that debate would take place and then immediately moved the gag. That means that in future, when he gives an inference that one course will be followed, there will need to be serious questioning before any leave is given to do what he wants to do.

That is all I have to say in relation to the right to speak—namely, that I am quite convinced that, under the standing order, the right to speak should be given. Secondly, I say to my colleague Senator Cooney that, whether or not he regards what Senator McMullan did as a save, I certainly do not.

The third point I want to raise is that of contingent notices of motion. I see that there is some difficulty there. It is quite clear that if the Senate has set itself some time limit, we do not want the question of that time limit being recommitted and recommitted. But I also understand that if Senator Harradine were to move a contingent notice of motion in his name, that would then deprive people on this side of the chamber—Senator Hill or whoever—of the opportunity of raising that contingent notice of motion. So that is a problem which needs to be addressed by the Procedure Committee.

I suspect the answer is that if the contingent notice of motion seeks some extension and someone wants to move almost the same question, then he or she should be deprived of the right to do that because all that person wants to do is recommit the question again and again. But that is perhaps a matter for longer consideration on another day.

Last but not least, I want to direct some remarks to Senator Evans who, the chamber is told by some of his colleagues, when he made his remark was of a certain temperament and so we should not be too upset about it. But I think it is a disgraceful exercise to refer to the chamber in which one is employed as being `a relatively useless institution'. If Senator Evans thinks this is a useless institution he must, by implication, think the House of Representatives is where all the sensible people are. It must be sad for him to have it as a matter of public record that he tried to get into that place, where the more useful people are considered to be, in his mind, and was rejected. I am referring of course to Senator Evans's attempts to be the member for Jagajaga—a seat now held by Mr Staples.

The remark also flies in the face of Senator Evans's answers to questions this afternoon. When giving an explanation of why there are so many Victorians in the inner Cabinet of this Government to the exclusion of proper representation of other States, he indicated that cream always rises to the top—clearly meaning that he sees himself as being at the superior end of the Labor Party talent.

We can see that when we sit here in Question Time; we can see the disdain in which he holds some of the poor suckers on the other side who are given the task of coming up with dorothy dixers. He clearly does see himself as being way above the intellectual capacity and standing of anyone else on that side. It must be an enormous strain for him therefore to be placed in this chamber which he sees as being `relatively useless'. But not only that; it must be a strain for him to realise that not only has he not got what he wants but also that his Party has been so silly as to put such an intelligent person in what he regards as such a relatively useless place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I want to make a couple of points with regard to your statement entitled `Statement by Mr President'. I do not know whether you claim authorship of it as well, but I think a couple of points need to be made, particularly with regard to page 5, `Ruling by the President on the Chairman's Ruling'. The statement sets out standing order 145 and the stages that have to be gone through. It states that when the objection is taken it has to be in writing. That occurred. The standing order continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairman shall then leave the Chair, and the Senate resume.
That was when you came back into the chair, Mr President. I continue:
The matter having been laid before the President,—
that is, you—
and Senators having addressed themselves to it,—
which clearly indicates debate—
shall be disposed of,—
which predicates some decision by you—
and the proceedings in committee shall be resumed where they were interrupted.

So we go back to the Chairman. The reason it is important to go through the rest of what is on page 5 is that I can see we are likely to get into this situation again. That is an unfortunate thing to have to say, but from the way that rulings are being made in this chamber now and the way that Standing Orders are being paid so little heed I really think we have to put on the record our solid objection to the way this argument runs so that when we are faced with this situation again—which, as I have said, I have no doubt we will be—we will have an argument with which to run.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the part with which I take singular exception. Having set out standing order 145, the paragraph then reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The reference in the standing order to the matter being disposed of means disposed of by a ruling of the President, which can then be objected to under standing order 198.
Which of course is done without debate. The statement continues:

In other words, the President rules on the correctness of the Chairman's ruling. This interpretation has always been followed since the standing orders were adopted in 1903. The procedure is described in Odgers' Australian Senate Practice as follows:
I will go through that and compare it with the Hansard in a moment. What is dishonest about that statement is that it fails to address that part of standing order 145 which states:
The matter having been laid before the President, and Senators having addressed themselves to it, shall be disposed of, and the proceedings. . .
It goes on. The thing that is left out of that second paragraph is the need for the matter to be addressed by senators. It is deliberately misleading.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, when you made your ruling on 5 December, recorded in Hansard on page 4243, you selectively read from Odgers at page 677. The part that you left out is the part that is now included on page 5 of your statement. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: When the President has taken the Chair of the Senate, the Chairman reports the dissent.
It then says:
It is the practice of the Senate, when a decision of the Chairman of Committees is objected to, to permit Senators to address themselves to the Question before the President gives a decision.
It could not be clearer. Let us hear it again:
to permit Senators to address themselves to the Question before the President gives a decision. The debate on an objection to a decision of the Chairman cannot be adjourned.

It then goes on to the part you read into the Hansard starting `After hearing the views of Senators'.Mr President, I can only say that a mistake seems to have been made with regard to the ruling and with regard to dealing with the motion for dissent. It would be a great pity if people let pride, or a need for their own standing to be enhanced—

TALK.START.PARA: —Vanity.

—Or vanity—it could be the vanity of whoever wrote the document or somebody else. I do not know. It would be a great pity if we allowed that to stand and for the wrong that is contained in this statement not to be redressed. I say to you, Mr President, in all sincerity that Odgers is clear and the standing order is clear. What is not clear is why there is this dogged determination to stick to the error that was made back on 5 December. It is important, as I said at the beginning, that this matter be placed on the record because I fear we will encounter it again.

PARA.TAB: I think I said enough about the point of order question when I spoke earlier on the motion to adjourn about why it is important for us to deal with this tonight and have matters on the record. With those few words at this stage, Mr President, I will leave the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my comments on this debate as I spoke before I was aware of the fact that it was to be brought back.
—Briefly?
—Briefly.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Mr President, I only want briefly to address one aspect—although I have strong feelings about various other aspects—and that relates to the point of order. In particular, I want to challenge the following proposition in your statement:

SPEECH.PARA: It must be within the discretion of the Chair to decline to hear any further points of order and to put the questions for determining the proceedings on the urgent bill. If this were not so, it would be open to individual Senators to raise successive points of order and by that means to defeat the determination by the Senate that an urgent bill must be dealt with.

The reason I object to that with great vigour is that if this situation were to prevail it would be open to senators on the Government side, for example, deliberately to breach Standing Orders with impunity. The Opposition would not be in a position to take points of order on clear breaches of the Standing Orders because the Chairman, President or whoever is occupying the chair, may have taken the view, totally opposed by the Opposition, that what was going on was acceptable.

PARA.TAB: That is a compliant chairman in that situation, without necessarily using it as a pejorative which is capable of all interpretations. It would be absolutely intolerable if, by this ruling, a government were to be given the power to steamroll matters in this place, denying the Opposition the right to take points of order. I find that so unacceptable that I am astounded it is seriously proposed.

That leads me to the next point. I have been a member of each House of Parliament, with total service of 14 years. Never before in my parliamentary career have I been dealt with as I was dealt with by the Chairman of Committees, Senator Colston. I have never been put in a situation where I have refused what to me was a totally improper request to withdraw a statement that was patently true.

Mr President, this all stemmed—despite Senator Colston's attempted explanation to skirt the issue by not quoting in full page 4241 of the Hansard—from Senator Vanstone, immediately on Senator Evans's statement which she found unacceptable, very loudly saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Point of order! Point of order!
Mr President, you then said:
Order! Resume your seat, Senator Vanstone.

Mr President, at that point, if your position was that no points of order were to be entertained because of your view of the impact of the guillotine, I believe it was your duty to explain to the Opposition that you would not entertain points of order, in which case your ruling could then have been disagreed with immediately. I put it to you that when an Opposition has cause to feel aggrieved by what it perceives to be unfair treatment from the Chair the good conduct of the House is at risk.

PARA.TAB: In that situation, Mr President, I believe that, if that were your view at the time, you were in error not to put it so that we could dissent from it. To allow a situation where members of the Opposition, Senator O'Chee for example, were constantly rising and not being called—as you know, we both received telephone calls from viewers of the ABC, after those persistent attempts, saying, `You advised Senator Colston, as he took over the Chair, that if Senator O'Chee tried to take a point of order you were not in the Chair any more'—clearly indicated your awareness of the fact that you had deliberately, for whatever reasons, good or bad, not called Senator O'Chee and had not called other people who were standing. If you listen to the tape of the event, as I have, you will hear that the issue could and should have been resolved by your taking that point of order.

My anger—as you could see, Mr President, it was genuine anger at what was happening in this chamber—was based on the gratuitous remark made by the Chairman, Senator Colston, in denying what was a perfectly proper point of order; a point of order which you found serious enough, when you eventually had the opportunity to rule on it, to discuss at some length in your ruling which is appended to your statement. It was a matter of substance which was dismissed out of hand by Senator Colston on the basis that it should have been made at the time.

We had wall to wall points of order at that time. It was simply inappropriate and wrong for Senator Colston to gratuitously make that remark to Senator O'Chee and, by the extent of its unfairness, it incited and invited an angry response. That is not the way to conduct the proceedings of this place. I regret that my anger prompted me to refuse a request which I regarded as totally improper, and still do. I say to you, Mr President, that had you ruled appropriately at the instance of Senator Vanstone the issue would have been a different one in terms of arguing about the propriety or correctness of that decision. If the Chairman had not made that gratuitous remark, the issue would not have become as inflamed.

There is a duty on the President and the Chairman of Committees to conduct proceedings in this place so that no side feels aggrieved. In this case, that duty was not executed in an effective and proper way. To that extent, I regret that your statement has not dealt with the issues that prompted anger, disappointment and clear unhappiness in general on this side of the chamber. We felt that we were unfairly dealt with. It is a duty of the Chairman of Committees to do what he can to ensure that that perception is not held by the Opposition. Regrettably, in my view, what passed as an explanation from Senator Colston tonight did nothing to justify his position and did nothing to explain the gratuitous nature of his remark to Senator O'Chee. On all those grounds, I would hope that the conduct of the chamber is better in the future.

I conclude by saying that I may be wrong, but I am also concerned about the position in which Senator McMullan moved the gag. I was under the impression—it may be wrong—that Ministers can move the gag at any time, but I thought that someone who is not a Minister would have to seek leave to do so. That may not be so. That was in the back of my mind, but I may be confusing the issue.

While I acknowledge the clear point that points of order must be made at the time, it is infuriating when one is denied the right to take a point of order to then be told that it is not a point of order because it was not taken at the time. That is not the way to conduct the business of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some brief remarks, mostly in response to what Senator Robert Ray said, relating to the goodwill and good sense that must endure if this chamber is to conduct its affairs in the manner to which the people of Australia would expect the Federal Parliament, particularly the senior House—also known as the States House, the House of review and the Senate—to conduct its affairs. Clearly, Thursday was not a red letter day for the Senate. Senator Ray referred to it as anarchy. But it is important that the Senate not just take Senator Ray's comments without challenging them.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus, on behalf of the Government, reintroduced this legislation and brought in an enormous raft of amendments, followed by amendment after amendment, when we knew that the Australian Democrats had clearly done a deal—between $2m and $5m—which would benefit that political Party. Opposition senators who had a very fundamental, principled objection to the legislation and the detail of that legislation would seek to do whatever they could to use the forms of this chamber and the opportunities the debate in this chamber presented to them to ensure that the Australian people had an opportunity to be aware of the very important issues contained in it. Of course, the Government expected that. The Government ensured that we were given a number of hours to debate the legislation, knowing full well that as long as the guillotine applied—a guillotine that it had to take off twice in a row—there would be a very heated and vitriolic debate, but still the message would not seep through.

It took the editorial writer of the West Australian until today to uncover the issues. Basically, the matters were discussed in the chamber in a very heated debate. That did not seep out into the broader community. The point that Opposition senators have made time and time again is that it does not matter whether we give the chamber 30 hours, 60 hours or two weeks to debate something. Until the community can see the importance of what is being debated here and the political pressures upon senators, quite properly, it does not matter whether we have one week, two weeks or a year to debate these matters. That was what made Opposition senators very agitated, very frustrated and very angry about the way this debate was conducted.

My comments earlier this evening in relation to the Australian Democrats, which I had to withdraw, are yet another monument to that frustration. We saw the Democrats basically selling out for the price of between $2m and $5m in benefits to their political Party. I think it is fair to say that the term I used—political prostitutes—even though it was considered at the time to be unparliamentary, did not relate to any individual; it related to the Australian Democrats. Anyone who analyses the behaviour of the Australian Democrats in relation to this legislation would have to apply that term.

The other point that Senator Ray raised was the way that points of order are being used to disrupt Question Time. Again, I think the matter of goodwill and good sense needs to be applied. Of course, when we have a government which is under extreme pressure, as is the Government at the moment—with its leadership woes and the woes of an economy in recession—Question Time will be a trying time for it. This morning we heard Senator Richardson saying on the radio that he would not like to be Leader of the Government, answering the questions every day, and that Senator Button does the job very well. Clearly, the Government finds some problems there. The Government brings on Senator Cook and Senator Bolkus every day to filibuster out Question Time, answering dorothy dixers. Senator Cook must have told us about industrial relations in New South Wales and New Zealand 50 times in the last session. He must almost be getting sick of his own voice.

I put it to you, Mr President, and to my Senate colleagues, that when we have a government that is seeking to abuse Question Time in that way the Opposition will not sit here mute and allow that sort of behaviour to go on. Of course we will use points of order; we will always try to make sure that those points of order are not spurious. There is a time when frustration takes over. I admit that my point of order last Thursday, in relation to the proposal for Paul Keating to introduce a goods and services tax, was frivolous. I apologise for that. This is the level of frustration which occurs. It relates to the very issue that Senator Ray pointed to; that is, goodwill and good sense.

Goodwill and good sense left this chamber a few weeks ago. Until they return, Ministers should understand that if they want to deceive the Australian people by attacking the Fightback package and using lies to attack it, the goodwill will evaporate. If the Government wants to put the debate onto a higher plane and talk about the philosophical aspects of the Fightback package, goodwill will prevail. If the Government seeks to mislead the chamber and the Australian people in relation to the aspects of the Fightback package, of course the proceedings of Question Time will not contain goodwill.

The next point I want to make—I am nearing my conclusion—concerns goodwill in relation to the chairmanship on Thursday. Senator Colston did not show goodwill towards Senator Teague. I really got angry when Senator Teague was clearly seeking the attention of the Chair while Senator Colston was sitting there, clearly knowing that Senator Teague was seeking his attention. That was something that I could not abide. Obviously, Senator Baume could not abide it either. If there had been a bit of goodwill in the full knowledge that the Opposition was totally frustrated and very angry about this legislation, and if honourable senators had been allowed to take their points of order, we would have got out of here and we would not be spending all of these hours tonight discussing the ramifications of what happened last Wednesday and Thursday.

Lastly, I wish to refer to Senator Evans's remarks about the Senate. Senator Evans has a reputation for having an incredibly quick temper. It is something that Senator Evans has been trying to control for most of his time in this Parliament. On some occasions he has been successful, on others not so successful. Last Thursday tested Senator Evans. He was unable to pass the test and lost his temper again. He reflected on this chamber where his old mate Lionel Murphy spent his years. It is not a reflection on this chamber; it is a reflection on Senator Evans. When anyone spends as much time as Senator Evans does in this chamber and holds the chamber with such a lack of respect as Senator Evans does, it is clearly a reflection on him. All it says about that particular honourable senator is that it is well and truly time that he gave up and got out of this chamber. If he cannot move to the House of Representatives successfully, he should get out and go to the Bar or do something else constructive because he is wasting our time here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, earlier this evening you made remarks which I said were unparliamentary and I asked you to withdraw them. I think you used the same remarks again during your recent contribution.

—I respect that, Mr President. I did respect your previous ruling. I was just trying to put it in a broader context without making it an interjection. I have been advised that relating it to a political party was not a reflection on any individual or senator. I was advised that, if I were to say that the Government is a pack of liars, that would not be particularly unparliamentary. My remarks were meant in the same context as that.
—I will look at the Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like you, Mr President, to refer to the second last paragraph on page 6 of your statement to the Senate today, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it should be pointed out that proceedings in the bill in question were extended for almost 3 hours beyond the time specified by the Senate, due to the suspension motions, the motion of dissent and points of order.

I have gone through Hansard to see how you can justify that three hours. I fail to see where that motion of dissent and the points of order did take up time. I know that we did go over time on the debate as a whole, but I did not consider that three hours of extra time were taken up. Any extra time on this Bill would have been well worth having. Another week, if necessary, would have given us time to debate it properly.

PARA.TAB: I wish to support my colleagues. They said that we had some rather biased chairmanship on the day in question. The Hansard shows that an honourable senator called three times for the Chairman's attention and was totally ignored. We have had a good debate on this matter this evening. The Government could go away and come back with some solutions. The Government put this Bill forward as a matter of urgency. I cannot see the urgency of it, unless there is an election coming.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no urgency when they decided we were coming back on the 19th.
—That is right. Otherwise, there is something we do not know about, such as a Federal election before we start again next year.

—That can happen. We did that in 1990. After we left in 1989 there was an election before we came back. There is a precedent for Senator Bolkus. There may be an election at Lakes Entrance. Who knows? There may be an election in Tasmania. The Government had to set the legislation in place so that it could afford an election by `forcified' donations. With those words, I would like you, Mr President, to turn your attention to the issue of the three hours, because I certainly disagree with that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop asked only a few moments ago whether I was the author of this document. I have been the President of this Senate for five years. This was a rather unique situation. I think anybody looking at this document would understand that naturally I would require some assistance. So, I say to Senator Panizza, it is very difficult for me to work out whether or not debate was extended by three hours. I did seek the assistance of the Department of the Senate, but I will check the times and the point that you have made. But I want to make it quite clear that this is my statement.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume alleges that I made a mistake. I will go back and have a look at that in the Hansard. As I recall it, I think I reached the point where I did not believe that I could keep listening to every point of order that was made. But I have given that undertaking, and I will go back and look at it. It is one of the things that we will have to put before the Procedure Committee.
As far as the situation with Senator O'Chee is concerned, which relates to me, I believe that it is completely clear. If honourable senators look at the top of page 4246 of Hansard, it says:
Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.PARA: The moment I said that I was technically out of the chair. When I was standing up to leave the chair and I asked Senator Colston to take the chair, Senator O'Chee said:
On a point of order, Mr President. Mr President!
There is no way that I could have accepted that point of order, because the moment that the question was resolved in the negative I was no longer in the chair.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague asked why there was an addendum to this statement. This statement had been completed and distributed. Senator

INTERJECT.PARA: Teague approached me in the chair and said that the point that he had referred to me had not been dealt with. I looked through the statement and I realised that that was correct. So this was put out very hurriedly as an addendum. It is not a ruling and I wish to make that quite clear; it is an explanation. The Chair did not make a ruling then and I have not made a ruling now, because in fact the ruling has to be made at the time. So that addendum does not have the status of being a ruling from the Chair.

PARA.TAB: Let me deal finally with the status of the document. There are no rulings involved in the statement that I made earlier today. It is an explanation of the two rulings that were made and an explanation of the approach adopted by the Chair last Thursday. One of the rulings was the subject of a dissent motion which was negatived. There is therefore nothing before the Chair at the moment that I believe can be dissented from. So, I suggest we await the consideration of the matter by the Procedure Committee. I undertake—and I have already spoken to the Leader of the Opposition on this matter—to call a meeting of the Procedure Committee as soon as it is possible to do so. I believe there will then be a report back to this chamber and we will be able to give more careful consideration to all the matters that have been raised tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the discontinuation since November 1990 of shipments of live sheep from Australia to Saudi Arabia:
(1) Have other Middle East markets been found for Australian live sheep.
(2) How many live sheep were exported to Saudi Arabia in 1989 and 1990.
(3) How many live sheep are presently exported from Australia to the Middle East.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: (1) Australian live sheep exports to regions in the Middle East other than Saudi Arabia have continued despite the problems experienced in the Saudi market. In 1990 Australia continued to export live sheep to Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, the UAE, Bahrain, Jordan and Yemen. Live sheep exports to Oman, Qatar, and other Middle East areas showed increases in 1990 from 1989.

As part of the Government's commitment to consolidating and further developing Australia's live sheep and sheepmeat trade to the Middle East region, an officials' delegation drawn from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade visited Australia's principal markets in the region from 11-28 October.

Consultations were held at a senior level with the Saudi Arabian Ministry of Agriculture and Water in which the issue of the re-establishment of the live sheep trade between the two countries was discussed. These discussions were held in a positive, co-operative spirit and the perspectives gained from these talks are being examined in consultation with the Australian industry.

(2) Australia suffered a total of 12 rejections of live sheep from Saudi Arabia in 1989 and 1990. In 1989, 2,074,300 head were exported to Saudi Arabia. Live sheep exports to that market in 1990 were 900,800 head.
(3)At present live sheep exports to the Middle East for nine months ending September 1991 are 2,704,732 head.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the composition and terms of reference of the Standing Committee on Agriculture which is carrying out a detailed review on animal diseases in Australia.
(2) What is the timetable for the completion of the report.
(3) Will the report be made available to the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following to answer the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Standing Committee on Agriculture (SCA) consists of the heads of the State/Territory and New Zealand Departments of Agriculture, the Executive Director of the Agriculture and Forestry Group of the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and representatives from the CSIRO and the Commonwealth Department of Finance. An official from the Papua New Guinea department responsible for agriculture is invited by the Chairperson of the Australian Agricultural Council to attend regular SCA meetings as an observer. The Terms of Reference of the Standing Committee on Agriculture, in addition to advising the Australian Agricultural Council, are:
(a) to secure co-operation and co-ordination in agricultural research throughout the Commonwealth;
(b) to advise the Commonwealth and State Governments, either direct or through the Council, on matters pertaining to the initiation and development of research on agricultural problems; and

(c) to secure co-operation between the Commonwealth and States,and between the States themselves, with respect to quarantine measures relating to pests and diseases of plants and animals, and to advise the Commonwealth and State Governments with respect thereto.

Animal Health Committee (AHC) is one of six permanent technical committees reporting to SCA and has recently appointed a Working Group to take responsibility for advising AHC on endemic animal diseases (first meeting held on 12 November 1991).

The initial task to be undertaken by the Working Group is to carry out a detailed review of endemic animal diseases in Australia to identify possible control/eradication programs, and determine research priorities where information is lacking.

(2) The task of carrying out a detailed review is highly complex and is expected to take around five years to complete. The Working Group will provide an interim report to AHC in April 1993 outlining preliminary findings.

(3) The majority of reports to SCA are not available to the public. However, some technical reports may be released for general publication. This would require SCA's endorsement of an AHC recommendation for a report to be published as one of the Standing Committee on Agriculture Technical Series documents. The value of the final report by the Working Group on Endemic Diseases to industry and research organisations could well result in the document being released to the public through this mechanism, although this cannot be guaranteed.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the main methods of disposing of sheep and other livestock when: (a) numbers need to be reduced due to downturns in demand; or (b) when animals need to be disposed of during fires and drought.
(2) What is the typical amount of blood and bone that can be extracted from dead sheep and other livestock.
(3) What other ways are used to extract nutrients (such as composting) from dead stock.

(4) What federally funded research has been, or is being, undertaken into methods of, and opportunities for, recycling nutrients from dead stock using: (a) small scale technology; and (b) more capital intensive methods.
(5) What are the costs (in terms of foregone nutrient sources) and benefits to be derived from disposing of unwanted livestock in pits or by burning.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Flock reduction made necessary by a downturn in demand is done through normal commercial channels, namely sale to registered meatworks for slaughter for human consumption and abattoir by-products, or sale to rendering or knackery works for use in petfood and by-products. Where large numbers need to be disposed of quickly, commercial disposal is supplemented by on-farm destruction of animals for which the likely sale price would not cover the cost of transport to the point of sale.

The main means of on-farm destruction is by firearm, usually a .22 rifle, or, where small numbers are involved, by captive bolt or electrical stunning and bleeding out by severing the major arteries of the throat. Both these methods are approved under the Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals - Sheep, endorsed by the Australian Agricultural Council.

Carcases are buried in on-farm pits or pits managed by local councils, or, where burial is impractical due to lack of suitable equipment, the nature of the soil or the location of the water table, burnt or left to decompose on the surface. Surface decay over time is the least expensive disposal option and requires no equipment, although a large concentration of carcases may give rise to environmental and health concerns.

Of the 10,543,831 sheep disposed of under the Flock Reduction Scheme which operated for 5 months until February 1991 as part of the Australian Wool Corporation's business plan to support the Reserve Price Scheme, approximately 88% were disposed of in on-farm pits, 2% were disposed of in council pits, 4% were sold to rendering and knackery works and 6% were sold through the Computer-Aided Livestock Marketing (CALM) Service to registered abattoirs.

(1) (b) Sheep which have been severely burnt are usually shot on site. Less severely affected sheep must be treated in accordance with veterinary medical guidelines and may be transported to abattoirs for salvage slaughter within 24 hours, before any secondary infection develops.

If pasture has been destroyed, supplementary feeding, agistment to unaffected areas or commercial disposal may be necessary. Where none of these options are viable, humane destruction and on-farm or off-farm pit burial may be carried out as a last resort.

In the current economic climate salvage slaughter would be an unlikely option, as the return for burnt stock is low. The current revision of the Model Code of Practice for the Transport of Livestock will take into account the need for guidelines on transport of stock affected by fire.

Drought affected stock are disposed of through the normal commercial channels, including the sale of livestock to farms unaffected by drought. As a last resort, where animals can no longer be fed and their condition is such that they have no commercial value or they are too weak to be transported to the point of sale, the animals are destroyed on-farm, by the same means as for flock reduction. Preferential culling to maintain flock or herd structure may be included in this exercise.
State Departments of Agriculture have guidelines on the management of stock affected by fire and drought, and also on emergency destruction and disposal.

(2) Blood and bone is an abattoir by-product utilising the waste from carcase processing, being based mainly on blood and bone tissues rather than on whole carcases, and is used as a fertiliser to provide the plant nutrients nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium and sulphur.

Figures are not available for determining how much blood and bone fertiliser may be obtained from the whole carcases of sheep or cattle. A whole 30kg sheep carcase will provide approximately 300 grams of phosphorus, 740 grams of nitrogen, 60 grams of potassium and 45 grams of sulphur, but the material making up blood and bone is of different composition to a whole carcase. Commercial blood and bone fertiliser contains 4% to 7% nitrogen and 3% to 9% phosphorus by weight.

(3) There are clear health risks associated with decomposing carcases. As composting is the process of obtaining fertiliser through the decomposition of organic matter, it is not a viable option for nutrient extraction from dead stock. Sterilisation by heat treatment as employed in the blood and bone production process or in the rendering process is essential to remove the health risk associated with animal decomposition.
One other option which has not yet been explored could be the mining of pits at some later time for nutrient extraction.

(4) In 1989 the Meat Research Corporation, formerly the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRDC), as part of its program to maximise returns from sheep in over supply, funded a project to examine on-farm processing of cast-for-age sheep which was carried out by the CSIRO Meat Research Laboratory. The project was completed in March 1990. A similar project was carried out by CSIRO Division of Food Research in 1987 as a direct response from the Corporation in preparing for the possibility of a flock reduction exercise, and was reported in AMLRDC Report No. 87/11.

The objective in both cases was to develop a low cost method of converting carcases to meat meal with a mobile unit which would process animals on-farm. The process was found to be not feasible economically due to the high capital cost of equipment, although most of the technical problems were overcome and meat meal of acceptable quality was produced. The processes examined included drying, shredding and drying, freezing and the use of stabilised slurries of carcases with special chemical agents.

(5) The cost of pit burial of unwanted and unsaleable livestock can be viewed in terms of human, animal or plant nutrients. Assessment of whether this resource is lost by the humane slaughter of animals and the disposal of carcases in pits depends on the suitability of the recovered product, the cost of energy involved in recovery of product and the monetary cost of recovering product.
As an example, for the 9.5 million sheep disposed of under the recent Flock Reduction Scheme, based on an average liveweight of 25kg or 35kg, this would have represented:
in terms of human nutrition, approximately 39,600 or 55,400 tonnes of bone-out meat for human consumption, assuming one-sixth of liveweight can be recovered as bone-out meat

the benefit of recovery would have to be assessed against the cost of providing refrigeration, canning or other methods of preservation for this quantity of a relatively unmarketable product and the dependency of such an exercise upon a short-term processing capacity which was not and is not available;
approximately 73,750 or 103,242 tonnes of meat meal for feeding to pigs, poultry or pets
as the quality of meat meal is essential to efficiency of pig and poultry production, the benefit of recovery would depend upon the unlikely event of all product being used within its shelf-life;
in terms of plant nutrients, approximately 2,375 or 3,325 tonnes of phosphorus equivalent

ANSWER.PARA: to 26,400 or 37,000 tonnes of single superphosphate, 5,858 or 8,200 tonnes of nitrogen equivalent to 7,140 or 10,000 tonnes of anhydrous ammonia, 475 or 665 tonnes of potassium equivalent to 228 or 320 tonnes of murate of potash and 360 or 500 tonnes of elemental sulphur

PARA.TAB: as an example of quantities required, 100 to 125kg of single superphosphate per hectare is the recommended yearly rate for topdressing tablelands grazing country in south-eastern Australia, and 400 to 500kg of single superphosphate per hectare is the recommended yearly rate for topdressing irrigated pasture.

The benefits of disposal in pits or by burning, apart from rendering unnecessary the costs of recovering, processing, storing and marketing what is largely an unwanted product, include preservation of community health and environmental standards through the sanitary disposal of carcases. Additional benefits include the minimising of blowfly breeding in carcases which would otherwise be left to decay in the open, environmental repercussions such as smell and contamination of water supplies, weed growth and accessibility to scavengers and predators.
For epidemiological and legislative reasons these methods may be a necessary exercise in preventing the dissemination of endemic or exotic disease organisms.
